title: Smart water meters set to be delayed as water companies fail to spend green funding
lead: Water companies were given permission to invest £793m on green projects after the pandemic, but are currently behind the spending target
author: Lucie Heath

body.text: Major water infrastructure projects, including the rollout of hundreds of thousands of smart meters, are facing delays as water companies struggle to spend funding they were allocated to help with the UK’s “green recovery” from the pandemic.

Water companies are falling behind on schemes including the replacement of lead pipes and the installation of smart meters, with one company yet to install a single smart meter out of a target of 204,700 by 2025.

In 2021, the water regulator Ofwat gave five water companies permission to invest a collective £793m by 2025 on projects to support the country’s green economic recovery following the Covid-19 pandemic.
However, in an update published late last month, the regulator confirmed that water companies had spent just 10 per cent of this funding by March 2023.
While Ofwat said it expects spend to increase significantly in the final two years of the programme, it noted that all five water companies have currently spent less than their original forecasts.
This includes Thames Water, which by the end of 2022-23 had spent only £1m out of the £72m it has been allocated to install 204,700 smart meters in customers’ homes.
According to Ofwat, the water companies had spent the following amounts by the end of March 2023 (the deadline for spend is March 2025):

In its latest annual report, the struggling water company admitted it had failed to install a single smart meter by March 2023. It’s understood the firm has installed more than 15,000 meter boxes as part of its preparatory work.

A spokesperson for Thames Water told  its ability to recover the full £72m from Ofwat was dependent on its ability to deliver at least 98% of its leakage performance commitment, which it failed to do last year due to “the impact of drought and freeze-thaw events”.

They said: “We asked Ofwat to review the Green Economic Recovery funding conditions in response to these challenges, but our request was recently declined. We are carefully reviewing our next steps and remain committed to driving down leakage and encouraging our customers to use water wisely.”
The firm said it has installed almost one million smart meters in customers’ homes as part of a wider rollout of the technology.

South West Water has also faced delays as part of its plan to install 76,000 smart meters by 2025, having installed just 930 to date. However, the firm insists the project is still on track to be completed by 2025.
A separate project to upgrade the Knapp Mill water treatment works in Christchurch, which was first built in 1897, is currently facing delays due to a planning challenge from Natural England.
Other projects, including schemes to improve river water quality and investigate sewage discharges, are currently on schedule.
With an allocation of £565m, Severn Trent has received the majority of the green funding from Ofwat and has currently spent £67m (12 per cent).

While a number of its projects are currently delivering on target, the company has reduced the scope of a £75m project to replace a maximum of 26,000 lead pipes in Coventry and Bomere Heath, and is now forecasting it will deliver 13,000 by the 2025 deadline.

Chris Wand, Severn Trent Green Recovery programme director said: “We’re on track, and in some cases accelerating work that will bring benefits and improvements to the communities we serve as we deliver what is the biggest green economic recovery programme in the sector.”
A spokesperson for United Utilities said it was currently on track to deliver all of its Green Recovery projects despite having spent less than 5 per cent of its allocated £64m by March 2023.
However, in its latest annual report the firm admitted it was unlikely to meet targets on projects to restore peatland and improve river water quality before 2025.
Meanwhile, South Staff Water, which has received the smallest allocation from Ofwat to deliver upgrades to a water treatment plant appears to be on track to deliver by 2025.

The delays to the green programmes raise fresh questions over water companies’ ability to carry out large infrastructure projects as they pledge to invest £96bn by 2030 to improve Britain’s water and sewage network.
It comes after Ofwat found that water companies spent just 73 per cent of the approximately £7bn in funding they were allocated to invest in infrastructure between 2020 to 2023.

At the end of September seven water companies, including Thames Water and Southern Water, were ordered to cut a collective £114m from customers’ bills after failing to meet key targets on tackling pollution, leakage and supply interruptions.

title: The evidence that shows climate change is already impacting our bills, homes, health and businesses
lead: i canvassed leading researchers’ opinions and looked at key reports into the impacts climate change is having – this is what we found
author: Tom Bawden

body.text: Climate change is already affecting the everyday lives of British people in profound ways – from food and the weather to our health and leisure activities, an analysis has found.

We canvassed the opinions of leading researchers and institutions and combed through key reports on the effects of global warming – and they have painted a picture of nation that is already going about things differently in all sorts of ways.

“The UK’s first 40°C day, in summer 2022, was the clearest indication that climate change has arrived in this country,” said Richard Millar, head of adaptation at the Climate Change Committee, the Government’s official climate change adviser.
“Last year’s record-breaking temperatures brought unprecedented numbers of heat-related deaths, wildfire incidents and significant infrastructure disruption.

“These, and impacts from other events, highlight the UK’s critical exposure and vulnerability to extreme weather even today. Climate change means many weather extremes driving these impacts will continue to get worse for several decades at least,” he said.
Mark Maslin, a professor at University College London, with a keen interest in how people’s lives are affected by global warming, has also noticed significant changes.
“I have observed lots and lots of adaptations everywhere. People are becoming much more focused on hydration, for example, and you increasingly see people taking water with them on the Tube.

“A lot of people are changing their work pattern to make sure that during the hottest part of the year they are either working from home,  if it’s cool enough, or they’re working at work because of the air conditioning. And people try to go in earlier to make sure don’t have extreme heat on their journey,” added Professor Maslin, a member of the Climate Crisis Advisory Group (CCAG).
Meanwhile, 23 per cent of people in the UK say “climate change has already had an impact on me personally”, according to a survey of 2,064 conducted in May for the National Trust.
Here are some of the ways in which life in the UK is already being affected.

Climate change is clearly affecting the nation’s mental health. A 2021 paper by Imperial College London concluded that there “is clear evidence of a relationship between higher temperatures and increased suicides” and “clear evidence for severe distress following extreme weather events”.

It said: “The available evidence suggests that climate change has a significant and multi-faceted impact on mental health and emotional wellbeing. Data show that there is a clear relationship between experiencing the effects of climate change – such as rising temperatures or more frequent and severe extreme weather events – and worsening mental health, even resulting in more suicides,” according to the paper.
It goes on to give examples of how climate change can impact our mental health.

“Experiencing the effects of climate change first-hand, for example by a flooding event, directly raises the risk of experiencing post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), depression or low mood, and extreme distress.

“People with mental illness are also more vulnerable to impacts of the changing climate, such as high temperatures, which worsen their physical as well as mental health. Damage to infrastructure and supply chains arising from climate change impacts also risk disrupting the provision of mental healthcare,” it adds.
There is good evidence that high temperatures can increase the risk of injury, particularly in children.

A review of existing scientific studies,  published in the British Medical Journal found that the increased injury risk varied between 0.4 per cent and 5.3 per cent for every 1°C increase from a moderate temperature.

“Our review confirms that hot weather can increase the risk of unintentional injuries and accidents,” wrote report author Eveline Otte Im kampe, of London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, in the study.
-Heat typically leads to a reduction in work intensity or an increase in breaks, according to a report prepared for the Climate Change Committee.

– A study focused on the US, by the National Bureau of Economic Research in Boston of found that average productivity in the US on individual days declines roughly 1.7 per cent for each 1°C  increase in daily average temperature above 15°C.

-Meanwhile, another study by the Grantham Research Institute suggests of the UK suggests that 2°C warming trajectory (which the world is currently surpassing) could cost around 0.4 per cent of economic output for London in a warm year due to a reduction in productivity.

Exposure to heat also slows the development of cognitive skill development in students, according to research which has shown that hotter school days prior to tests have resulted in lower test outcomes.
Another study by the National Bereau of Economic Research found that without air conditioning, each 0.6°C increase in school year temperature reduces the amount learned that year by one percent.
And another found that taking an exam on a 32°C day leads to around an 10 per cent lower likelihood of passing compared to a 22°C day.
More than 4,500 people died in England in 2022 due to high temperatures, the largest figure on record, with the number of heat-related deaths increasing over recent years, the ONS said last month.
Between 1988 and 2022, nearly 52,000 deaths associated with the hottest days were recorded in England, with a third of them occurring since 2016, data from the Office for National Statistics shows.
More than 2,000 people died in Wales due to the warm temperatures over the same period.
While heat-related deaths in the UK hit a record last year, the ONS pointed out that they have been at significantly elevated levels for some years.

It noted that from 2016 to 2021, deaths were above average in every hot spell – defined as days when the average temperature is greater than 20°C in central England – and 9.3 per cent higher on average.
“Across the 2016 to 2021 ‘heat-periods’, excess deaths ranged from 3.0 per cent (2 to 9 August 2018) to 27.7 per cent (6 to 9 September 2021)” above average,” the ONS said.

A government study found that overheating was found to reduce good sleep by one or two hours – or cause an equivalent reduction in sleep quality – although considerable variation across the population is expected.

Another government study estimated that relative to sleeping seven to nine hours, “productivity loss” was estimated to be 3.7 working days per year if sleeping six to seven hours and six working days if sleeping  less than six hours.
UK homes are starting to change, with more people buying fans, installing air conditioning and shutters and painting external walls white, scientists say.
But most households are still very unprepared for the new era of high temperatures, studies have shown.

Some 4.6 million English bedrooms – one in five households – and 3.6 million living rooms (15 per cent) overheat in the hot weather, according to a study by Loughborough University last year in partnership with the BRE (Building Research Establishment).
Meanwhile, a study by London South Bank University in 2018 found maximum internal temperatures of almost 50°C in a London office building converted to apartments, when they had no shading.

Furthermore, research by the University of Bath, presented to the Environment Audit Committee in August as part of a review into UK household preparedness for climate change, concludes: “Many of the coping solutions reported by respondents in our research would likely prove insufficient in the face of sustained heatwaves”.
Overheating is also regularly recorded in other building types such as hospitals, care homes and schools occupied by some of the most vulnerable people to heat-health impacts.
Overheating is defined as occurring where the daily maximum temperature exceeded 26˚C in a ward or clinical area.

The number of overheating incidents in clinical areas reported by NHS trusts has almost doubled over the past five years, with directors saying ageing estates make them vulnerable to extreme weather events.
And in , a survey of teachers found that 90 per cent reported taking additional measures to reduce classroom temperature, including purchasing portable air conditioners.

Schools in London have also reported that concentration levels of children had been affected due to high temperatures in recent years, with the annual period for public examinations being one of the hottest parts of the year.
There is also increasing evidence of overheating in  and other care settings.

Meanwhile, A HM Inspectorate of Prisons’ report included concerns from during inspections which included difficulty of breathing, the heating in cells being continuously on, high ambient temperatures in cells and limited oxygen.

A report on food prices in 2022 by the Energy & Climate Intelligence Unit research group found that extra costs relating to climate change added £170 a year to the average UK household food bill – representing 37 per cent of food inflation.
One example of how this is translating into increased meal prices is with Britain’s favourite curry.

The cost of making a chicken tikka masala has rocketed by 17 per cent in a year – and it’s largely the fault of climate change, according to a separate new analysis, by ECIU for the climate change charity Round Our Way.

This finds that the cost to an average family of four of producing ‘the nation’s favourite dish’ has shot up by £3.67 in the past year as prices of key ingredients have jumped. Supermarket canned tomato prices has risen by 32 per cent over the period, while onions are up 26 per cent and cooking oil by 38 per cent.

British people barbecued 86 million times last summer about 7 per cent more times than they did before the pandemic and continuing “a new normal” level of elevated bbq consumption, according to the latest figures from the Agriculture and Horticulture Development Board (AHDB).
The board puts a large part of this down to changes in our lifestyles as a result of the pandemic – but it comes against a backdrop of warming temperatures that make barbecueing a more viable option.
“Despite living without restrictions, we continue to work differently than before, which keeps us in the home more and cuts back on out-of-home occasions,” a spokesperson for the board said.
However, part of the reason could be rising temperatures, experts said – although extreme temperatures may be considered too hot.

As the board spokesperson noted: “The latter part of summer saw a rise in temperatures which was matched by a spike in BBQ occasions in August, however the same did not happen for the record temperatures in July”

A report from the government’s climate change advisor, Committee on Climate Change, finds that, according to UK businesses, “extreme weather is already a significant source of supply chain disruption”
The study gave UK wheat yields as an example.

Wheat yields in 2020 (9.7 million tonnes) were the lowest since 1981, with the value of wheat output falling by £526m or 25 per cent compared to the average for 2016 to 2019. This was due to unusually poor weather conditions at critical points of crop production: very wet weather for preparing the soil and sowing, too dry in the spring when the crops should have established, and bad weather for harvesting.

There is not yet enough data to know how the number of football matches cancelled in the UK due to climate change-induced extreme weather has changed over time, but there is a growing body of anecdotal evidence that the situation is getting worse.
At the same time, there are many scientific studies saying that extreme weather is increasing – and that this is as a result of climate change.
A 2021 study from energy company Utilita estimates there are 40,000 amateur football teams in the UK, which have an average of 5.4 games postponed or cancelled a year.

And another study, by the Sport and Recreation Alliance, found that more than a third of grassroots teams lose two to three months of playing time a season due to the weather. And the situation has deteriorated since then, experts say.

“Today, we’re witnessing undeniable impacts of climate change on football, with the grassroots and women’s game being impacted the most. And things are getting worse,” said Elliot Arthur-Worsop, founder of Football For Future, a charity set up to make football sustainable that has worked with Tottenham Hotspur, Chelsea FC, and Fifa, the international governing body of football.
One of the most obvious ways in which the UK is changing is in the steps that are being taken by large numbers of the British public to cut their greenhouse gas emissions.
These include eating less meat, buying an electric vehicle, ditching their gas boiler, cycling more, using public transport, flying less and switching to a green energy  supplier.
Polling by the Met Office in March showed that more than half the British public are consciously making low-carbon choices, with nearly two-thirds wanting to do more.

In a YouGov survey, a representative sample of the British public was asked about the action they are taking to reduce their carbon footprint and their perceptions as to whether people in the UK are doing enough to reduce their carbon footprint.
The data show 59 per cent of those surveyed are making conscious decisions to live a low-carbon lifestyle, including 17 per cent who make these decisions even when it is inconvenient for them.
When asked if people in the UK are doing enough to lower their carbon footprints, nearly two-thirds of respondents said we should be doing more.

“Everyone can see that we’re experiencing frequent extreme weather… the UK public are already engaged in reducing their carbon footprints and many people indicate they want to do more,” said Professor Jason Lowe, Head of Climate Services at the Met Office.

“The only way we are going to avoid the very worst impacts from climate change is by lowering our emissions of greenhouse gases, and quickly. But we also need to adapt our lifestyles and the world around us to cope with the impacts from the climate change we’re already committed to.”

Dr Camilla Mathison, lead on Climate Mitigation Science at the Met Office, said: “Even small changes to daily life make a big difference when it comes to your carbon footprint. A simple example is personal travel, by walking or cycling short journeys you are not only saving CO emissions but also improving air quality and improving your personal health.”

title: Chicken tikka masala price soars due to climate change
lead: The cost of the ingredients for a chicken tikka masala has soared by 37 per cent in two years – and climate change is largely to blame
author: Tom Bawden

body.text: The cost to make Britain’s favourite curry, the chicken tikka masala, has rocketed by 17 per cent in the past year – and it’s largely the fault of of climate change.

One of the UK’s most loved dishes, and according to one theory, said to have been created by Glaswegian chef Ali Ahmed Aslam in his Indian restaurant in Scotland in the 70s, it combines pan-fried chicken marinated in a spice-laden yogurt base with a creamy tomato curry.

The key ingredients have helped it become a firm favourite among British curry lovers – but they are also most vulnerable to the effects of a changing climate, according to new analysis for UK climate change charity Round Our Way.
Supermarket canned tomato prices have risen by 32 per cent in the past year, while onions are up 26 per cent and cooking oil by 38 per cent.
The total cost to make the dish from scratch now stands at £25.81, as the ingredients needed have risen by £6.94, or 37 per cent – since 2021, the analysis finds.
Some ingredients in these calculations, such as butter and olive oil, probably won’t be used up in a single meal while others, such as canned tomatoes and chicken, probably will be.
So there may well be some ingredients left over after the family has made a curry but that is the cost of buying the ingredients needed to make one from scratch, the researchers said.
“Many of us are having to cut back on takeaways and now even a home-cooked curry is rocketing in price, thanks to climate change’s impact on the weather,” said Roger Harding, Round Our Way director.
Rising energy prices are a significant driver of the increase of this dish – and the high rate of food inflation generally.

But the additional costs of dishes such as chicken tikka masala are also largely a direct result of climate change, which is estimated to be responsible for about a third of the price increase, according to the Energy & Climate Intelligence Unit (ECIU) research group which carried out the analysis on official ONS data.
These additional costs come from increased heatwaves, droughts, storms and rainfall that are happening as a result of climate change – both at home and abroad.
These reduce yields, destroy crops and affect livestock health which, in turn, leads to supply shortages and pushes up prices.
Researchers warned that prices will continue to rise unless more is done to tackle the climate crisis.
Tom Lancaster, land analyst at ECIU, said: “British people love a curry, but climate change is forcing us to fork out more for one of our nation’s favourite dishes.

“With climate-driven extreme weather wrecking harvests in the UK last year, and around the world this summer, we can expect to pay more for our weekly curry in the future unless we do more to reach net zero emissions, as an essential step to preventing the worst impacts of climate change.”
Floods and heatwaves are the biggest weather events responsible for driving up the cost of curry ingredients. Essentials hit include tomatoes, peppers, onions, rice and cooking oil.

Drought in 2022 reduced UK onion yields by 30 per cent, while extreme weather in North Africa and Southern Europe in early 2023 led to shortages and price increases for tomatoes and peppers, Mr Lancaster said.
Meanwhile, unpredictable weather is threatening supplies of rice in south and south-east Asia including in India, which banned exports of basmati rice in July after damage to crops from heavy rain.
Mr Lancaster added: “We know that climate change has had a major impact on food prices this year and last.

“If the ingredients for a chicken tikka are representative of other foods, it is likely that climate change accounts for around a third of the price increases that shoppers have seen since the beginning of 2022.”

Last year a separate report from ECIU on food prices in 2022 found that extra costs relating to climate change added £170 a year to the average UK household food bill – representing 37 per cent of food inflation.

Professor Wyn Morgan, University of Sheffield, and one of the authors of that report said: “The analysis underpins how the UK food system as a whole is exposed to global climate change and events on world markets and points to the importance of action to promote a more resilient food and agricultural sector in the UK.”

Nicky Amos, public affairs chair of the National Federation of Women’s Institutes, added: “Although it may not say climate change on the till receipt, it’s definitely showing up on our shopping bills.”

And Professor Corinna Hawkes, director of the centre for food policy, at City, University of London, said: “This important piece of analysis is one of the first times we have seen how important climate change is in influencing food prices. Climate change is not a distant threat, but affects the money we all have in our pockets every day.”

title: How flooding due to climate change is wrecking the UK’s football pitches – with grassroots teams most affected
lead: Awareness of the problems being caused by climate change is growing but not nearly enough action is being taken to tackle the problem, experts warn
author: Tom Bawden

body.text: Bromley Heath United football club in Bristol has to call off so many games due to flooding that teams often have to play three matches a week towards the end of the season to catch up.
The club, set up in 1966 and home to more than ten youth and adult teams, frequently suffers from waterlogged pitches in the autumn and winter.
And in the summer it can be hit by rock hard, largely grass-free surfaces as drought conditions replace intense rainfall.
This means that anything from a third to a half of fixtures have to be postponed in a season, according to club chairman Jamie Andrews-Britton.

He says the situation has deteriorated significantly since he joined the club 16 years ago, when he estimates around 10 per cent of games were postponed, as climate change has made weather ever more extreme.

“It’s getting worse because you get such a substantial amount of rain in such a short time these days. Before, a game would probably be called off if you had two weeks worth of rain. But now you might only get a day’s worth of rain and that’s it, everything’s called off,” he told.

“We’re not on a flood plain but we’re certainly on a wet plain. We had a really good drainage system put in when we were built but the subsoil on top of it wasn’t so great – it was backfilled from the building site so the drainage has been a bit of a disaster,” he said.

While Bromley Heath is being hit particularly hard by extreme weather it is far from alone, with the Football Association estimating that about 150,000 grassroots games a year are cancelled in the UK due to poor pitches, with most of the cancellations occurring after bad weather.

There is not yet enough data to know how the number of football matches cancelled in the UK due to climate change-induced extreme weather has changed over time, but there is a growing body of anecdotal evidence that the situation is getting worse.
At the same time, there are many scientific studies saying that extreme weather is increasing – and that this is as a result of climate change.
A 2021 study from energy company Utilita estimates there are 40,000 amateur football teams in the UK, which have an average of 5.4 games postponed or cancelled a year.

And another study, by the Sport and Recreation Alliance, back in 2014, found that more than a third of grassroots teams lose two to three months of playing time a season due to the weather. And the situation has deteriorated since then, experts say.

“Today, we’re witnessing undeniable impacts of climate change on football, with the grassroots and women’s game being impacted the most. And things are getting worse,” said Elliot Arthur-Worsop, founder of Football For Future, a charity set up to make football sustainable that has worked with Tottenham Hotspur, Chelsea FC, and Fifa, the international governing body of football.

“The frequency and intensity of extreme weather events, like flooding, storms and heatwaves continue to disrupt matches across the UK annually, impacting the social and physical wellbeing of players,” he said.

The experience of footballers on the ground tallies with Met Office data about the UK’s changing weather.“The UK has experienced unprecedented rainfall events in recent years, and since 1998 the UK has seen six of the ten wettest years on record,” said Met Office science fellow Elizabeth Kendon.

“Recent Met Office attribution studies have shown that some recent heavy rainfall events in the UK associated with flooding can be linked to human-caused climate change. Events such as the wettest February on record in 2020, or the record-breaking rainfall seen on 3 October, 2020, are expected to become more frequent by 2100 due to climate change,” she said.
Tadcaster Albion, a semi-professional club based near the banks of the River Wharf in North Yorkshire, is a club that has been hit much harder than most by extreme weather.
Andy Charlesworth, a director at the club, said game cancellations have “doubled if not tripled” in the past decade.

“It can be an absolute nightmare. It’s always flooded and it’s just that over the last few years it’s been more frequent and it’s been to a larger degree with a greater intensity of rain and depth of flood water, which has caused significant problems,” he said.
While grassroots teams are worst affected by climate change because they have less money to deal with it, professional clubs are also at risk – especially those outside the Premier League.

A new report from the Zurich UK insurance group found that football faces severe disruption from climate change as increasing cases of flooding, windstorms and drought threaten to disrupt or postpone matches on a regular basis.

It predicts that one in five of England’s 92 professional football club grounds will be at “high to very high” risk of severe flooding by 2050 unless they take significant action – meaning they could see floodwater more that half a metre high “multiple times a decade or even per year”.
Lower league and amateur sides, in particular, face risks as many lack the pitch maintenance budgets of bigger clubs, the report warns – as are clubs involved in other sports.
Grimsby Town, which plays at Blundell Park less than 200 metres from the North Sea, is based in the most at-risk location, with high risk of flooding and heavy rain.
It is followed by Lincoln City and Norwich City – with Leeds United, Huddersfield Town, Leicester City and Blackburn Rovers all high in the climate change league.
Crystal Palace is the sole Premier League club to make the top 20, with the risk of strong windstorms putting it at number 14 in the table.

Overall, the report, based on climate modelling, found that 42 per cent of England’s professional football clubs face heightened risk of severe disruption from severe floods, torrential rain, droughts and windstorms over the next 30 years.
These extreme weather events could damage stadiums, lead to flash flooding and water-logged pitches and disrupt or cancel matches if the sport fails to adapt, the report warns.

The analysis does not factor in any actions that may have been taken by clubs or local authorities to protect against climate hazards, such as flood defences, although it is thought that, by and large, very little action has been taken.

“When you walk into a ground can you see temporary flood barriers that could be slotted into place? I’ve yet to see any. From a visual perspective, I think most clubs are really relying on what the town’s infrastructure has in place. There’s no visual indication that clubs are taking floods seriously in protecting their locations,” said Kumu Kumar, head of Zurich Resilience Solutions UK.

Garry Nelson, a former professional footballer who made more than 750 first team appearances for clubs, including Charlton, Brighton and Plymouth, said: “Ask any player what conditions they dislike most and strong winds will be the universal answer. Quality of play is always diminished, the spectacle in the stadium and for the live TV audience is reduced, and results can hinge on a weather-related incident, rather than a sublime piece of skill. Intense rainfall also poses a threat to matches, impacting the flow of the game and heightening the risk of injury to players.”
Although the report only looked at professional English football clubs, the authors said the findings also broadly applied to amateur clubs – and to venues for other kinds of venues – across the UK.
David Goldblatt, author of and said climate change is “a big threat” to football that is hardly being addressed.
“We are focusing a little bit on the top end but the huge bottom of the pyramid is just not being looked at at all,” he said.
It is the job of many organisations to tackle climate change in football – such as local authorities, the Environment Agency and the clubs themselves, he argues.

But the Football Association, in particular, needs to do more to highlight and tackle the threat and lead the process, as it represents tens of thousands of clubs around the UK, giving it the best national platform for the sport, he argues.

A spokesperson for the Football Association (FA) said: “The climate crisis presents one of the most pressing issues of our time, and we are determined to play our part in inspiring positive and meaningful change. In July, we launched our new five-year Playing for the Future sustainability strategy, which sets out our clear ambition to make a positive impact on the environment and the communities that we serve.

“Across grassroots football, our ambition is to transform grass pitch quality in England to improve player experience and withstand adverse weather conditions. We currently support around 6,000 pitches through the Football Foundation Grass Pitch Maintenance Fund to help clubs, towns and parish councils, and school sites across the country to improve, maintain and manage their pitches – and we would encourage anyone eligible for this fund to come forward.”

As part of the programme, clubs, schools, and town and parish councils have free access to PitchPower, the Football Foundation’s innovative digital assessment tool to understand the current state of play with a grassroots pitch.

Following this assessment, each site will receive a recommended maintenance programme to get the pitches in a good condition, alongside some funding to implement the new maintenance programme, the FA explains.

Grants for machinery and equipment are also available and easy to apply for, such as tractors, irrigation and maintenance tools, and includes new and innovative robotic mowers which help to cut the grass more regularly and save volunteer time.
approached Grimsby Town, Lincoln City, Norwich City, Newport County, Leicester City, Blackburn Rovers, Huddersfield Town, AFC Wimbledon, Wigan Athletic, Crystal Palace and Morecambe for comment.

Damian Froggatt, director of operations at Lincoln City, said: “Sustainability features high on the club’s agenda and over recent years the club has already invested significant sums into a range of environmental and infrastructure projects, all designed to help reduce our carbon footprint as part of our long term climate action strategy.

“We are also members of the Lincoln Climate Commission, are fully signed up to the EFL Green Club sustainability programme, and are committed to working with all our partners to reduce our carbon footprint.

title: October heatwaves set to become more likely and Britain must prepare, climate scientists warn
lead: Parts of the UK are expected to record temperatures as high as 26C this weekend
author: Lucie Heath

body.text: UK autumns are likely to become more summer-like in the future and the shifting seasons will have a huge impact on nature, agriculture and energy demand, climate scientists have warned.
The UK is expected to record temperatures as high as 26C this weekend as parts of the country continue to experience a spell of unseasonably warm weather.
While the forecast temperatures are still far off the October record of 29.9C recorded in 2011, the Met Office said the current warm weather is unusual for this time of year.
It follows the news that last month was officially the hottest September on record globally, which followed the hottest July and hottest August ever recorded.

Met Office spokesperson Oli Claydon said the current warm October weather is “not an event that we could necessarily attribute to climate change”, but said projections show “we would expect to see more and more high frequency and more intense warm spells” across the UK due to global warming.
Research published by the Met Office last year found that UK autumns are set to become warmer and drier, which could lead to an increased drought risk from the mid-2020s onwards.
“One of the key ramifications around that is around biodiversity and how ecosystems respond to that,” Mr Claydon said.

David Coley, Professor of Low Carbon Design at the University of Bath,  said the frequency with which we are seeing unseasonable weather events is “growing at a rate that I don’t think people are ready for”.

“You get unseasonable temperatures once every 50 years or once every 20 years, but once they’re happening every third year or something it does start to have a much greater impact on flora and fauna and agriculture,” he said.
He said universities and the Government should focus more on work to adapt Britain to its new climate, alongside work to achieve net zero.
Dr Matt Patterson, an atmospheric physics expert at the University of Oxford,  said the UK is essentially having an “extended summer season” and that this will become more common in the future.

He said the shifting seasons will have a massive impact on energy demand, adding that while people will probably be pleased to not be putting on their heating right now, in the future these benefits will be outweighed by the demand for air conditioning in the summer.
Climate experts believe there is a good chance this month could be the hottest October on record globally as an emerging El Niño adds to the effects of global warming.
El Niño is the name of a climate pattern in the Pacific Ocean, which occurs every two to seven years and increases global temperatures.

Scientists were left stunned on Thursday after new data on global temperatures showed September 2023 surpassed the previous warmest September on record (2020) by 0.5°C, the largest annual jump in temperature ever recorded.

title: World could be heading for hottest October on record – after hottest July, August and September ever
lead: 2023 is on track to be the hottest year on record as an emerging El Niño adds to the impact of climate change
author: Lucie Heath

body.text: This month could be the hottest October on record globally as an emerging El Niño adds to the effects of global warming, forecasters are warning – and a mini-autumn heatwave is expected in parts of the UK.
July 2023 currently holds the record for the hottest month ever, while August 2023 is the second-hottest month ever.
This September, meanwhile, was the hottest September ever recorded.
And climate scientists believe it is likely that October will follow the trend, as the planet continues to be hit with a double whammy of global warming and an emerging El Niño.

Every two to seven years, climate patterns in the eastern Pacific Ocean switch between El Niño and La Niña phases. The former leads to unusually warm surface waters, while the latter leads to unusually cold water. There is typically a neutral period in between.

Dr Matt Patterson, an atmospheric physics expert at the University of Oxford, said climate change “is absolutely the main driver” of the record-breaking temperatures, but described the emerging El Niño as a “secondary factor” that “can push up global temperatures by a few tenths of a degree or nearly half a degree in certain years”.
As El Niños typically peak in December, and Dr Patterson said global temperatures “are going to continue to be much higher than average”.
He added that he would “not be surprised” if October, November and December all ended up being record-breaking.

“It’s something we are still trying to grapple with to understand exactly why the temperatures are so high. Climate scientists are perhaps running out of superlatives. The word unprecedented no longer really cuts it,” he said.

Countries closest to the Pacific are most affected by the El Niño-La Niña weather cycle. While some areas, such as Peru and Ecaudor, are typically hit with heavy rains and flooding, others, such as Indonesia, are likely to be affected by drought.

Richard Allan, professor in climate science at the University of Reading, said weather can be “fickle” so the combination of global warming and El Niño “doesn’t mean that every single month is going to be record hot.
“But it does mean when you look at this year, and next year, they’re probably both going to be record hot years compared to what we’ve measured previously with thermometers,” he said.
The EU’s Copernicus Climate Change Service confirmed that 2023 is on track to be the warmest year on record on Thursday when it released its global climate data for September.
Latest data from European scientists confirmed that September 2023 surpassed the previous warmest September on record (2020) by 0.5°C, the largest annual jump in temperature ever recorded.
The month was the joint-warmest September on record in the UK, according to the Met Office, with the mean temperature of 15.2°C on level with 2006’s record figure.
The record global temperatures come as the UK continues to experience unseasonably warm October weather.
Temperatures as high as 27°C are expected in the south and east of the country this weekend, with the warm weather expected to continue into the middle of next week.
Met Office spokesperson Grahame Madge said it was “too early to say” whether October will be the hottest on record in the UK.
“In terms of an injection of warmth into October’s figures, we’ve got a considerable boost in the first week, 10 days, even sort of half of the month,” he said.
However, the UK is not expected to hit the highest ever October temperature of 29.9°C, which was recorded in 2011.
Dr Patterson said the UK was only “indirectly” affected by El Niño, and the current warm weather here is more influenced by the ongoing warm sea surface temperatures in the North Atlantic this year.

title: The news is full of bedbug horror – here’s how worried you should really be
lead: Nobody likes their house, let alone their bed, to be the home of blood-sucking insects
author: Stuart Ritchie

body.text: City of Lights? More like City of Bites. According to reports this week, Paris is subject to a massive infestation of bedbugs. They’ve been spotted in hotels, homes, and even on the subway.
Bedbugs don’t spread disease, but they can ruin your sleep and fill you with anxiety – nobody likes their house, let alone their bed, to be the home of blood-sucking insects.

Bedbugs are much more common now than they were just a few decades ago. A big part of the story, as in so many epidemics and pandemics, is mobility: people travel around the world more, and take germs and pests with them.

It’s possible that it really is worse this year. But all rates of pest infestations are likely to fluctuate from year to year, due to random chance: Paris could simply be at an unlucky peak of a bedbug spike right now for no specific reason. You have to remember that bedbugs are pretty common anyway.

When people become aware of something they start to notice it everywhere: the so-called “Baader-Meinhof Phenomenon”. Now that the word is out that there’s a bedbug problem, people’s expectations, or a higher propensity to report seeing bedbugs, might be part of it.

Much of the anxiety is due to the Olympics, which are coming to Paris next year. But since the Opening Ceremony isn’t until July 2024, it’s possible that people will have forgotten all about it before then.
As mentioned above, mobility is a big driver of bedbug infestations. This means that, yes, there is a strong risk of the Paris bedbugs making it to the UK.

But this isn’t like the first COVID infections arriving on our shores in early 2020: we already have a thriving population of bedbugs of our own. As Professor James Logan, an entomologist at the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine points out, it’s just as likely that British bedbugs are hitching a ride to Paris as the other way around.
Eurostar have said that they would step up efforts to disinfect their trains: but then, what do you expect them to say?

As with so many similar problems, those with less are affected more. Way back in the 15th century, a source observed that bed bugs afflicted the poor more than the rich: “They infest both the chambers of rich and poor, but are more troublesome to the poor… For they do not breed in beds of which the linen and straw is frequently changed…”.

That’s no less the case nowadays. A 2020 analysis of data from Chicago found that bedbug infestations were “strongly associated with income [that is, those with lower incomes had more bed bugs], eviction rates, and overcrowding”. There’s no reason to think it’s any different in Paris, or indeed the UK.

At one point, we almost did. Up until the Second World War, bedbugs were everywhere: some estimates say a third of the population of London were affected in 1930; the advent of central heating at the beginning of the 20th Century had helped to increase their numbers.

Then came DDT. The pesticide (full name dichloro-diphenyl trichloroethane) became available for household use in the 1940s and was much more effective against bedbugs than previous, often quite dangerous methods, which included dusting bedclothes with mercury, soaking sheets in petrol, or fumigating rooms with hydrogen cyanide.
DDT decimated the bedbug population – to the point where scientists in the 1950s found it hard to find any of the bugs to study.

In a word: evolution. Just like viruses adapt to escape vaccines and bacteria adapt to resist antibiotics, bedbugs evolved resistance to DDT over time. It’s a standard story of natural selection: the bugs carrying genetic mutations that helped them survive against DDT tended to reproduce more often, and over time this left us with huge populations of DDT-resistant creatures.
It’s not just that DDT is now banned in most countries: even if we tried using it on bed bugs, it would no longer work.

There are other insecticides that still work – but experts recommend never relying on just one, because this can help spur the evolution of resistance. Many people poison themselves every year with bedbug pesticides. Some pest-control companies use heat treatment rather than chemicals for these reasons.
What to do:
If you’re worried about bed bugs, following well-worn behavioural advice, like above, is your best bet.

title: Record-breaking heat in September stuns scientists – the numbers explained
lead: According to the Met Office, September’s record-breaking temperatures would be ‘virtually impossible’ without climate change
author: Lucie Heath

body.text: Last month was officially the hottest September on record, with global temperatures experiencing the largest annual jump ever seen.
Scientists have been astounded by the latest global temperature figures, which confirm that 2023 is on track to be the warmest year in our history.
The record-breaking September follows the hottest July and hottest August ever recorded. The extreme weather has brought wildfires and heatwaves to much of the planet.
Here’s the summer of extreme heat in numbers:
Latest data from European scientists has confirmed that September 2023 surpassed the previous warmest September on record (2020) by 0.5°C, the largest annual jump in temperature ever recorded.
September 2023 was 0.93°C warmer than the 1991-2020 average for the month, while the mean European temperature was 2.51°C higher than the 1991-2020 average.

The UK experienced a record-breaking heatwave in September this year with the country recording seven consecutive days of temperatures above 30°C. This surpassed the previous longest runs of five days in September 1929 and 1911.
The month was the joint-warmest September on record in the UK, according to the Met Office, with the mean temperature of 15.2°C on level with 2006’s record figure.
The latest global temperature figures have alarmed scientists. Zeke Hausfather, a scientist at the Berkeley Earth climate data project, called the data “absolutely gobsmackingly bananas”.

The first global temperature data is in for the full month of September. This month was, in my professional opinion as a climate scientist – absolutely gobsmackingly bananas. JRA-55 beat the prior monthly record by over 0.5C, and was around 1.8C warmer than preindutrial levels. pic.twitter.com/mgg3rcR2xZ
Samantha Burgess, deputy director of the EU’s Copernicus Climate Change Service, said the “unprecedented temperatures” have broken records by an “extraordinary amount”.

She added: “This extreme month has pushed 2023 into the dubious honour of first place – on track to be the warmest year and around 1.4°C above preindustrial average temperatures. Two months out from COP28 – the sense of urgency for ambitious climate action has never been more critical.”

According to a Met Office study, which looks at the likelihood of temperature thresholds being reached in climates with and without human emissions of greenhouse gasses, September’s temperatures in the UK would have been “virtually impossible” without human-induced climate change.

Global temperatures have risen around 1.1°C since the industrial revolution. As a result, the Met Office study found there is now a 3 per cent chance of mean September temperatures hitting the same level as we saw in the UK this year.

Met Office Senior Scientist Jennifer Pirret said: “While a 3 per cent chance of these September temperatures occurring in the current climate might seem like a small amount, in a pre-industrial climate these temperatures would have been nearly impossible for the UK in September. It shows how climate change is moving the dial on mean temperatures.”

She added: “As global temperatures continue to rise as a result of human greenhouse gas emissions, we expect these chances to increase over the coming decades, though the natural year-to-year variability of the UK climate will obviously continue to play a role.”
The record-breaking September follows the hottest July and August in living memory.
July 2023 currently holds the record for the hottest ever month in living memory, following a month that saw many countries hit with extreme heatwaves and wildfires.
Local temperature records were hit in various countries; 48°C was recorded in Sardinia, while Algeria and Tunisia reported temperatures as high as 49°C.
All-time temperature records higher than 37°C were recorded close to the Arctic Circle at two sites in the Canadian Northwest Territories, while China reported its highest ever temperature of 52.2°C.
Meanwhile, August 2023 now holds the record for the second warmest month on record.

title: Will the Paris bedbugs infestation hit London? Why experts warn that the outbreak has already reached UK
lead: Pest control experts said it is ‘very likely’ that bedbugs from Paris have spread to the UK already
author: Jason Arunn Murugesu

body.text: A rise in bedbug sightings has caused havoc in France in recent weeks, especially on public transport in Paris.
The deputy mayor, Emmanuel Grégoire, has called for the French government to fight the “scourge” of bedbugs ahead of the country’s 2024 Olympics.
The issue has caused so much worry that a inter-ministerial bedbug crisis meeting will be held by the government on Friday, according to media network France24.
But how likely is it for the infestation to travel across the Channel? Here’s everything you need to know.
It is “very likely” that bedbugs from Paris have spread to the UK via people travelling by plane or Eurostar in recent weeks, Mihail Velev at Fantastic Pest Control told i.

“Bedbugs can hang onto your clothes or suitcase and travel the world along with you,” he said. “There are no particular disinfecting areas, especially for different types of pests, for your luggage or yourself when flying, so the chances are pretty high.”
Tommy Bull at Bed Bug Specialist UK said that bedbugs are already widely prevalent in the country.
“We treat bedbugs in hospitals, hotels and people’s homes,” said Mr Bull. “We do probably about 12 to 20 treatments each day.”
People travelling back to the UK from infested accommodation in France are likely to bring back bedbugs, but Mr Bull said this is also true for UK travellers returning from a wide range of countries.
“New York has a far bigger bedbug problem than here,” he added.
Mr Bull said bedbugs have been seen on the Tube in London, and buses and taxis around the country.

He said the problem globally has become worse in the past 10 years because people travel internationally a lot more than they used to. “If you’re visiting an infested place, there’s a high chance that you’ll bring back some bedbugs home,” he said.
A spokesperson for Eurostar said: “The safety and wellbeing of our customers is always our number one priority and the presence of insects such as bedbugs on our trains is extremely rare.”

“The textile surfaces on all of our trains are cleaned thoroughly on a regular basis and this involves hot-water injection and extraction cleaning, which has proven highly effective in eliminating bugs.

“Any reports on hygiene matters are taken very seriously and our cleaning teams, in addition to the usual cleaning, will also disinfect a train on request or as soon as there is the slightest doubt. We also plan to introduce preventive treatment across our entire network.”
Mr Bull said that he does not believe the bedbug outbreak in France right now is anything out of the ordinary.
“I think this has been a problem for years but they’re only noticing it now,” he said. “Probably because of the Olympics or because they’ve finally had enough of it.”

Professor Roger Butlin at the University of Sheffield said that it’s important to remember that while bedbugs are very unpleasant, they aren’t known to actually transmit any disease. “One shouldn’t overpanic,” he said.
DIY treatments to kill bedbugs often fail, said Natalie Bungay at the British Pest Control Association.
This is because bedbugs are increasingly becoming resistant to common insecticides such as pyrethroids, said Professor Butlin.
“If you don’t kill off the whole infestation using insecticides, then you are likely to produce more resistant individuals that can then reproduce and spread,” he said.

Ms Bungay added that professional pest control services have access to a “wider range of chemicals and strengths to tackle bed bug infestations” and they know about the “biology and behaviour” of insects which helps when treating infestations.
The best way to ensure that you have not brought back bedbugs from your holiday is to immediately check your luggage when you get home, experts told .
“Wash everything at high temperatures and steam or dry clean your clothes,” Mr Bull said. “Otherwise it’s impossible to protect yourself.”

Ms Bungay told i: “Make sure if you’re staying in a hotel, motel or bed and breakfast, that you double check the mattress and other soft furnishings for signs of bed bugs, especially before putting your luggage on the bed or chairs.”
Signs for bedbugs include small reddish-brown clusters that look like ink dots which can be found on a bed frame or on the underside of a mattress, she said.

Rentokil, the pest control firm, have started using sniffer dogs to detect early bed bug activity and say that the dogs are four times more effective at detecting early bed bug activity compared to humans.

Paul Blackhurst at Rentokil said: “These canine detectives are highly accurate at detecting bed bugs, and can do so in areas that might be challenging for humans to access or inspect thoroughly. They are particularly useful in large buildings and hotels where bed bug infestations can quickly spread if not detected early.”

title: Sycamore Gap: Dozens of UK’s oldest trees ‘at risk of being felled’ as vandalism hunt continues
lead: The Woodland Trust has warned that a lack of legal protections for ancient trees means many are routinely felled or at risk of destruction and safeguards similar to those applied to historic buildings are urgently needed
author: Cahal Milmo

body.text: Campaigners have warned that dozens of ancient trees across the United Kingdom are at risk of being felled as police made a new arrest in the hunt for those responsible for the “sickening” destruction of a 300-year-old sycamore abutting Hadrian’s Wall.

The Woodland Trust said the chopping down of the Sycamore Gap tree in Northumberland under cover of darkness on Wednesday represented an “irreplaceable loss” for both the region and the UK as a whole – but it also warned that many similarly venerable trees are being lost, often to legal felling.
Northumbria Police said a man in his 60s was arrested on Friday evening in connection with the felling of the tree and he remains in police custody assisting officers with inquiries.

A 16-year-old boy arrested on suspicion of causing criminal damage in connection with the vandalism at Sycamore Gap was released on police bail on Friday as officers appealed for further information after the tree was cut down using a chain saw, causing a wave of revulsion across the country.

Experts suggested that the sycamore, once voted Britain’s favourite tree and a decades-old place of pilgrimage for visitors drawn to its beguiling setting in a dip along a section of Hadrian’s Wall, could yet take on a new form by sprouting new shoots from its stump. Arboriculturists said the process could nonetheless take decades and is unlikely to result in a tree of similar shape and stature to its predecessor.

Conservationists said that the attack on the Sycamore Gap tree proved the difficulties in protecting trees from single acts of violence. But they also warn that similarly ancient or veteran trees are being lost from across the British landscape because of what they argue is a failure to extend the sort of protections that exist for the UK’s built heritage to its oldest and most precious trees.

The Woodland Trust said the absence of such legal safeguards for the UK’s oldest trees – some of which may be as ancient as 3,000 years of age – means they are being routinely, and more often than not legally, felled.

The conservation body pointed to the case of the Cubbington Pear tree, a 250-year-old fruit tree in Warwickshire thought to be the second-largest in Britain, which was cut down to make way for HS2 in 2021. Other natural landmarks under threat include the Darwin Oak, a 500-year-old oak that is facing destruction along with 30 other veteran trees to allow for a relief road in Shrewsbury, Shropshire, and nine veteran trees in an area of ancient woodland standing in the way of the proposed new Lower Thames Crossing in south London.

Jack Taylor, lead campaigner for the Woodland Trust, which is campaigning for new legal protections for the oldest trees, told : “Trees store carbon and are home to valuable wildlife, but they also hold the memories of people. The Sycamore Gap tree is a truly irreplaceable loss.

“While this sort of illegal felling is rare, legal felling is much more common. We must, as a nation, continue to fight for better legal protection for our oldest most important trees. At present they have no or little legal protection, unlike our built environment.”

Recent research suggests the number of ancient and veteran trees in Britain is grossly underestimated. While there are currently some 115,000 officially recorded across England, a study by Nottingham University last year found the true number could be as high as 2.1 million.

The Government said it has a range of policies in place to protect the country’s oldest trees, including a Tree Action Plan for England which seeks to provide safeguards for ancient woodland and forest as well as undertaking research into the “interaction between ancient woodland and new development”.

A spokesperson for the Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs said:  “The felling of the iconic Sycamore Gap tree is a loss for not only the local community, but the country as a whole. We are committed to ensuring our irreplaceable ancient trees and woodlands are adequately protected and suitably managed  – and we regularly review our policy around these irreplaceable habitats.

“As part of our Keepers of Time policy, we strongly recognised the value of England’s ancient and native woodlands and ancient and veteran trees. It restates our commitment to evaluate the threats facing these habitats and sets out our updated principles and objectives to protect and improve these habitats for future generations.”

The National Trust, which looks after the Sycamore Gap site along with the Northumberland National Park Authority, said yesterday that it may prove possible to coppice the stump of the felled tree – an ancient technique allowing side shoots to grow in place of a main trunk. But the organisation said it was in the early stages of planning the future of the site.
In the meantime, police said they were continuing the investigation into the vandalism, with forensics officers taking measurements and samples from the remains and photographing the area.
One was heard saying: “In 31 years of forensics I’ve never examined a tree.”

title: Left-wing Labour MPs join Jeremy Corbyn in condemning Israel’s retaliation against Hamas
lead: Fresh divides emerge with Labour over Israeli response to Hamas attacks
author: Richard Vaughan

body.text: Left-wing Labour MPs have defied Sir Keir Starmer by condemning Israel’s response to the terror attacks just days after Jeremy Corbyn condemned the bombing of Gaza.

The Labour leader has repeatedly insisted that Israel has a right to defend itself in the wake of the atrocities committed by Hamas, but has stressed it must be done in accordance with international law.

Sir Keir has resisted pressure to criticise the Israeli response to the Hamas attacks by cutting off the water, electricity and fuel supplies to the region in a bid to draw a distinction between his leadership and that of his predecessor.
But fresh divides emerged within the party after several left-wing MPs spoke out against Israel’s retaliation to the terror attacks.

Richard Burgon, MP for Leeds East, condemned the Hamas massacre of Israelis as a “heinous act of terrorism”, but he criticised what he described as the “collective punishment” of Palestinians by Israel.

“That is what we’re seeing in Gaza – civilian areas bombed, food, electricity, water, medicines, all cut off,” he said, before asking Rishi Sunak whether he would “make clear to the Israeli government that this collective punishment of Palestinian civilians must end immediately”.
Other MPs could be heard appearing to condemn Mr Burgon’s remarks, saying “shame” and “disgraceful”.

His comments were echoed by Imran Hussain, MP for Bradford, who urged the Prime Minister to make it clear to the Israeli government that “laying siege to civilians” in Gaza is in “clear violation of international law”.
Mr Sunak replied: “The entity responsible for the suffering we are seeing is Hamas and Hamas only.
“Now, of course, we and the international community will do our best to alleviate the impact on innocent people, which is why today we’ve announced further aid to the region.”

Shadow minister Labour MP Afzal Khan was heckled as he asked Rishi Sunak to review his statements about the Israel-Hamas conflict to avoid adding to the “further vilification of Palestinians and Muslims”.

The comments in the Chamber come just days after Mr Corbyn told a controversial pro-Palestine rally in central London, that “if you believe in international law, if you believe in human rights, then you must condemn what is happening now in Gaza by the Israeli army”.
Last week, he drew criticism for refusing to condemn Hamas directly for the murders and kidnapping of civilians, saying only that he was “against all violence”.
He vowed to continue to hold marches in central London in support of the Palestinian cause.
But Labour sources insisted that Mr Corbyn’s re-emergence off the back of the Israel/Hamas conflict was not a concern for the party, having stripped him of the party whip in 2020.

More pro-Palestine rallies are being planned in central London this weekend, prompting Home Secretary Suella Braverman to warn that the Government will not tolerate the chanting of “From the river to the sea, Palestine will be free”, which she said meant the destruction of Israel.

“The slogan was taken up by Islamists, including Hamas, and remains a staple of antisemitic discourse,” she said on Twitter/X. “To hear it shouted in public causes alarm not just to Jews but to all decent people. Those who promote hate on Britain’s streets should realise that our tolerance has limits.”

Downing Street said the Prime Minister had personally worked closely with the police in the run-up to the pro-Palestine marches to tell them to “step in when there is any sign of people breaking the law, including showing any support for Hamas, which is a proscribed terrorist group”.

title: Rishi Sunak calls for Middle East peace process and two-state solution amid Israel-Hamas war
lead: Rishi Sunak called for two-state solution during talks with Turkish president Erdogan and Palestinian president Mahmoud Abbas
author: Jane Merrick

body.text: Rishi Sunak has called for the Middle East peace process to be restarted amid the escalating crisis in Israel and Gaza.

In what will be seen as a step-change in international diplomacy in the wake of the Hamas terror attacks, the Prime Minister told the president of Turkey, Recep Tayyip Erdoğan, that he wanted to work with him and other world leaders to reinvigorate efforts to find a two-state solution in the Middle East.

While the PM has been engaged in regular discussions with regional and western governments since the crisis unfolded, it is the first time he has specifically suggested a restart of the peace process, which has been given little attention by the West for more than a decade.
It is nine years since a British prime minister has taken an official visit to Israel or the Palestinian territories.
A Downing Street spokesperson said: “The Prime Minister welcomed the opportunity to speak to President Erdoğan at this critical time, as an influential regional partner and Nato ally.
“The leaders shared their concerns about the risk of violence spreading in the region and agreed to work together to mitigate against further escalation.
“The Prime Minister updated on the UK’s military deployments to the region, which provide surveillance capabilities and offer a platform to support humanitarian operations if needed.

“The Prime Minister reaffirmed the UK’s support for Israel’s right to defend itself following last week’s abhorrent attack, noting that Hamas does not represent the Palestinian people. They discussed the importance of facilitating humanitarian aid to Gaza and taking all reasonable measures to protect civilians caught up in the violence.
“The leaders also agreed to work together with international partners to reinvigorate the Middle East Peace Process and bring about a peaceful and lasting resolution to this conflict.”
Mr Sunak also spoke by phone on Monday to Palestinian president Mahmoud Abbas.

In the wake of the Hamas attacks, the UK formed an alliance with the US, Italy, France and Germany, known as the Quint, to try to restore stability and prevent any conflict spilling over into a regional war.
Mr Sunak and other western leaders also held talks with regional powers, including the leaders of Israel, the Palestinian Authority, Egypt, Jordan and Turkey.
Western engagement in the peace process has fallen away over the past decade or more, particularly since Hamas – which is opposed to the state of Israel – took control of Gaza in 2007.

While in Downing Street Tony Blair and Gordon Brown visited Israel and the Palestinian territories several times, but their immediate successor, David Cameron, undertook just one trip, in 2014. No British Prime Minister has visited Israel in nearly a decade.

Mr Sunak’s official spokesman insisted, however, that the UK was an “active partner in seeking a two-state solution, that’s been our longstanding role both working with countries like the US and with regional partners to that end”.

There had been progress between Israel and other Arab states in the region under the 2020 Abraham Accords, which normalised relations between Tel Aviv and both the UAE and Bahrain. Talks were also under way between Israel and Saudi Arabia before the Hamas attacks.

Diplomats believe there is little hope of reinvigorating any peace process while Israel is poised to launch a ground invasion of Gaza, and after the killing of so many Israeli and Palestinian civilians, trust between both sides will be at an all-time low.
Given the lack of Western engagement in the peace process over the past decade, there are also risks that any UK, US or other leader trying to reinvigorate talks now would lack credibility.
In a phone call with President Abbas, Mr Sunak expressed his condolences for the deaths of Palestinian civilians who have been caught up in the aftermath of Hamas’s terror attack, Number 10 said.
A spokesperson added: “The Prime Minister reiterated the UK’s position that Hamas does not speak for ordinary Palestinians.
“The leaders agreed on the importance of avoiding further regional escalation and ensuring calm in the West Bank.

“The Prime Minister committed the UK’s support for the Palestinian Authority in trying to establish peace and stability. They also discussed support for Gaza, including humanitarian aid and measures to protect civilians.
“More broadly, the Prime Minister and President Abbas agreed that the international community must intensify efforts to break the cycle of violence in Israel and the Occupied Palestinian Territories.
“The Prime Minister affirmed that the UK continues to support a two-state solution, with a Palestinian state existing alongside a safe and secure Israel.”

It comes as US President Joe Biden was reportedly considering a trip to Israel to show solidarity with the country after being invited by Israeli President Benjamin Netanyahu. A visit would follow that by US Secretary of State Antony Blinken who has been in the region attempting to ensure the conflict is contained and does not spread more widely throughout the Middle East.

title: ‘No, no, no’: Tory chairman on Nigel Farage joining the party despite Rees-Mogg calling for the red carpet
lead: ‘I don’t think that Nigel Farage is truly a Conservative with a large C.’ the party’s chairman told i
author: Francis Elliott

body.text: Nigel Farage would not be allowed to join the Conservatives if he applied, says the party’s chairman Greg Hands.
The former Ukip leader was warmly welcomed by some Tories at their annual conference earlier this month and hailed as a Brexit hero by former home secretary Priti Patel.
Mr Farage has since left the door open to joining the party after Jacob Rees Mogg said the Conservatives should “roll out the red carpet” to bring him into the fold.

In an interview with , however, Mr Hands was adamant that any application from Mr Farage would be refused. “No, no, no,” he said. “I don’t think that Nigel Farage is truly a Conservative with a large C. He spent most of his political career trying to damage and undermine the Conservative Party.”
Mr Hands, who supported Remain in the 2016 referendum, said that a “decision had been taken” to allow Mr Farage to attend the conference as “a media person rather than a political person”.
The positive reaction to his presence in the Manchester conference was used by some as evidence that the Conservatives are being taken over by those on its right flank.
The party chairman rejects claims of so-called entryism, however. “Entryism is normally where people not previously known infiltrate – nobody can argue Nigel Farage is not known.
“When he’s wandering around the conference you don’t say, ‘Look at that guy – he’s actually not one of us’. Everyone knows he’s not one of us.”

Nevertheless, the charge that the party is becoming more right-wing grew in force when Andrew Boff, a Conservative member of the London Assembly, was ejected from the conference hall for objecting to Suella Braverman’s attack on so-called “gender ideology”

Mr Boff, who later told reporters that the home secretary was “making our Conservative Party look homophobic and transphobic” was spotted leaving Mr Hands’ office immediately before his interview with .
Had the party chairman apologised? “We are old friends. I just genuinely wanted to discuss his perspective on what he was saying…It was a private meeting.”

In fairness to the 57-year-old, he has a tough job made still harder by a series of by-elections triggered in controversial circumstances. If the Tories lose both Tamworth and Mid Bedfordshire, CCHQ will not be a happy place on Friday morning.
Mr Hands won’t be drawn on preparations for a full election campaign. He won’t say, for example, whether Rishi Sunak wants to have head-to-head TV debates with Keir Starmer.

He demurs when asked when Isaac Levido, the Australian strategist who ran the 2019 campaign, will start working for the Tories full time. It’s hard to escape the conclusion that these are questions above the chairman’s paygrade.

The Tory MP for Chelsea and Fulham is nothing if not combative, however. How does he feel about his reputation as one of the most tribal MPs at Westminster?  After all he delights in winding up opponents with reposting Liam Byrne’s infamous remark that “there is no money” a signature bait.
He insists he is on good terms with his opposite number Anneliese Dodds and after a pause offers up a couple of other Labour politicians he likes before admitting the charge.
“George Osborne used to say to people who said he was very political, ‘Have you ever met Greg Hands?’”
As is often the case, appearances can be deceptive and Mr Hands is a more complex and interesting character than his hyper-partisan social media persona.
He is worried that the party is going backwards on selecting women as potential MPs (they make up just 35 per cent of the approved candidate list).

There is a move, across both main parties, to select local candidates. Men, he says, are more likely to treat local politics as a stepping stone to Westminster. Women he says have more ‘rounded’ reasons for becoming councillors.

He is open to cross-party working to combat so-called “deep fakes” like the doctored audio clip that circulated on social media during Labour conference that purported to show Keir Starmer berating aides.
After being alerted by a Tory MP, Mr Hands said that his suspicions were confirmed by an expert. Much more sophisticated AI-generated fakes are certain to be spread in the future.

“My message to everybody, whether in politics or not, would be to take great care. Don’t for a moment think that there’s a reason. Libel and defamation laws are in place in this country and they apply to Twitter as much as they apply to anywhere else.”
His Conservatism was inherited from parents and especially his father, one of 16 siblings who realised his potential as a missile engineer thanks to grammar schools.
It was fed by his exposure to dissidents struggling to free themselves from Soviet control in the 1980s that also led to him meeting his wife Irina, a German national.

Her father, who recently passed away, was Martin Hundt, an authority on Karl Marx and Frederick Engels. Mr Hands speaks five languages including Slovak, Czech, German and French. “I can say, ‘there is no money left’ in them all.”

title: Jeremy Corbyn accuses Israel of war crimes in speech at pro-Palestinian rally in London
lead: ‘It is right to condemn the killings that have happened… but it’s also right to condemn the continuing occupation of Palestine,’ the former Labour leader claimed
author: Nick Duffy

body.text: Former Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn has addressed a crowd of thousands protesting events in Gaza on Saturday, accusing the Israeli government of war crimes.

Mr Corbyn, whose leadership was dogged by repeated rows over alleged failures to tackle anti-Semitism within the Labour Party, told protesters in central London that they must “carry on demonstrating as long as it takes to bring about peace and recognition of the rights of Palestinian people, and an end to arms sales [to Israel]”.

The MP – who in 2009 referred to members of militant groups Hamas and Hezbollah as “friends” but as leader said he regretted those remarks – avoided singling out Hamas by name on Saturday as he criticised both the massacre of Israeli civilians at a music festival and the killings of Palestinians in Gaza.
Instead, he referred to “young people who died in the Negev desert [and] young people who’ve been killed by Israeli forces in Gaza at the moment”.

Mr Corbyn continued: “Those killings are wrong, murder is wrong, the loss of human life is wrong. What we’re searching for is a process for peace, for justice, for honour, for the people of Palestine.

“It is right to condemn the killings that have happened, it is right to condemn the targeting of civilians, which is of course a war crime within international law, but it’s also right to condemn the continuing occupation of Palestine by the Israeli military forces.

“To demand that the entire population of Gaza move, and a million people leave their homes within 24 hours, is dangerous, it is going to kill people, and they are dying in their thousands. To deny innocent civilian people water, electricity, is also a war crime.”
Mr Corbyn continues to sit in Parliament as an independent after being stripped of the Labour whip by his successor Sir Keir Starmer over comments he made about anti-Semitism.
He has not ruled out running as an independent at the next election in 2024, which would pit him against Labour in his Islington North constituency.

The pro-Palestinian rally in London, accompanied by others in cities across the UK, comes after police warned of surging reports of antisemitic and Islamophobic hate incidents amid tensions over Israel.

In an apparent response to critics who have accused pro-Palestinian campaigners of insufficiently condemning the terrorists responsible for slaughtering more than a thousand Israeli civilians and taking at least 150 hostages, Mr Corbyn said: “There are many who say that nobody should be today because they’ll be condoning terrible things. None of us are here to condone killing, to condone occupation, to allow this assault on the people of Gaza and of the West Bank to go on.”

He warned politicians: “Do not condone war crimes and the starvation and denial of medicine to desperate people. If you believe in international law, if you believe in human rights, you must condemn what is happening now in Gaza by the Israeli Army.”
More than 1,000 officers were deployed by the Metropolitan Police for Saturday’s demonstration in the capital.

A protest ban was in place near the Israeli embassy in Kensington, with the police force warning that any protesters straying from an agreed route from the BBC’s headquarters to Westminster “may be subject to arrest”.

As marchers arrived in the thoroughfare and made their way to a stage outside Downing Street, chants of “Rishi Sunak, shame on you” and “From the river to the sea, Palestine will be free” rang out among the crowd.
