Western engagement in the peace process has fallen away over the past decade or more, particularly since Hamas – which is opposed to the state of Israel – took control of Gaza in 2007.

While in Downing Street Tony Blair and Gordon Brown visited Israel and the Palestinian territories several times, but their immediate successor, David Cameron, undertook just one trip, in 2014. No British Prime Minister has visited Israel in nearly a decade.

Mr Sunak’s official spokesman insisted, however, that the UK was an “active partner in seeking a two-state solution, that’s been our longstanding role both working with countries like the US and with regional partners to that end”.

There had been progress between Israel and other Arab states in the region under the 2020 Abraham Accords, which normalised relations between Tel Aviv and both the UAE and Bahrain. Talks were also under way between Israel and Saudi Arabia before the Hamas attacks.

Diplomats believe there is little hope of reinvigorating any peace process while Israel is poised to launch a ground invasion of Gaza, and after the killing of so many Israeli and Palestinian civilians, trust between both sides will be at an all-time low.
Given the lack of Western engagement in the peace process over the past decade, there are also risks that any UK, US or other leader trying to reinvigorate talks now would lack credibility.
In a phone call with President Abbas, Mr Sunak expressed his condolences for the deaths of Palestinian civilians who have been caught up in the aftermath of Hamas’s terror attack, Number 10 said.
A spokesperson added: “The Prime Minister reiterated the UK’s position that Hamas does not speak for ordinary Palestinians.
“The leaders agreed on the importance of avoiding further regional escalation and ensuring calm in the West Bank.

“The Prime Minister committed the UK’s support for the Palestinian Authority in trying to establish peace and stability. They also discussed support for Gaza, including humanitarian aid and measures to protect civilians.
“More broadly, the Prime Minister and President Abbas agreed that the international community must intensify efforts to break the cycle of violence in Israel and the Occupied Palestinian Territories.
“The Prime Minister affirmed that the UK continues to support a two-state solution, with a Palestinian state existing alongside a safe and secure Israel.”

It comes as US President Joe Biden was reportedly considering a trip to Israel to show solidarity with the country after being invited by Israeli President Benjamin Netanyahu. A visit would follow that by US Secretary of State Antony Blinken who has been in the region attempting to ensure the conflict is contained and does not spread more widely throughout the Middle East.

title: Left-wing Labour MPs join Jeremy Corbyn in condemning Israel’s retaliation against Hamas
lead: Fresh divides emerge with Labour over Israeli response to Hamas attacks
author: Richard Vaughan

body.text: Left-wing Labour MPs have defied Sir Keir Starmer by condemning Israel’s response to the terror attacks just days after Jeremy Corbyn condemned the bombing of Gaza.

The Labour leader has repeatedly insisted that Israel has a right to defend itself in the wake of the atrocities committed by Hamas, but has stressed it must be done in accordance with international law.

Sir Keir has resisted pressure to criticise the Israeli response to the Hamas attacks by cutting off the water, electricity and fuel supplies to the region in a bid to draw a distinction between his leadership and that of his predecessor.
But fresh divides emerged within the party after several left-wing MPs spoke out against Israel’s retaliation to the terror attacks.

Richard Burgon, MP for Leeds East, condemned the Hamas massacre of Israelis as a “heinous act of terrorism”, but he criticised what he described as the “collective punishment” of Palestinians by Israel.

“That is what we’re seeing in Gaza – civilian areas bombed, food, electricity, water, medicines, all cut off,” he said, before asking Rishi Sunak whether he would “make clear to the Israeli government that this collective punishment of Palestinian civilians must end immediately”.
Other MPs could be heard appearing to condemn Mr Burgon’s remarks, saying “shame” and “disgraceful”.

His comments were echoed by Imran Hussain, MP for Bradford, who urged the Prime Minister to make it clear to the Israeli government that “laying siege to civilians” in Gaza is in “clear violation of international law”.
Mr Sunak replied: “The entity responsible for the suffering we are seeing is Hamas and Hamas only.
“Now, of course, we and the international community will do our best to alleviate the impact on innocent people, which is why today we’ve announced further aid to the region.”

Shadow minister Labour MP Afzal Khan was heckled as he asked Rishi Sunak to review his statements about the Israel-Hamas conflict to avoid adding to the “further vilification of Palestinians and Muslims”.

The comments in the Chamber come just days after Mr Corbyn told a controversial pro-Palestine rally in central London, that “if you believe in international law, if you believe in human rights, then you must condemn what is happening now in Gaza by the Israeli army”.
Last week, he drew criticism for refusing to condemn Hamas directly for the murders and kidnapping of civilians, saying only that he was “against all violence”.
He vowed to continue to hold marches in central London in support of the Palestinian cause.
But Labour sources insisted that Mr Corbyn’s re-emergence off the back of the Israel/Hamas conflict was not a concern for the party, having stripped him of the party whip in 2020.

More pro-Palestine rallies are being planned in central London this weekend, prompting Home Secretary Suella Braverman to warn that the Government will not tolerate the chanting of “From the river to the sea, Palestine will be free”, which she said meant the destruction of Israel.

“The slogan was taken up by Islamists, including Hamas, and remains a staple of antisemitic discourse,” she said on Twitter/X. “To hear it shouted in public causes alarm not just to Jews but to all decent people. Those who promote hate on Britain’s streets should realise that our tolerance has limits.”

Downing Street said the Prime Minister had personally worked closely with the police in the run-up to the pro-Palestine marches to tell them to “step in when there is any sign of people breaking the law, including showing any support for Hamas, which is a proscribed terrorist group”.

title: Israel-Gaza conflict: At least 6 Britons have died and 10 are missing after Hamas attacks, Rishi Sunak says
lead: A number of Britons are also feared to have been taken hostage by the militant group and are being held in Gaza
author: Jane Merrick

body.text: Six Britons were killed by Hamas’ terrorist attacks in Israel and a further 10 are missing, Rishi Sunak has revealed.
A number of Britons are feared to have been taken hostage by the militant group and are being held in Gaza. The Prime Minister called for the “immediate release” of all hostages.

He told the Commons: “The terrible nature of these attacks means it is proving difficult to identify many of the deceased but with a heavy heart, I can inform the House that at least six British citizens were killed a further 10 are missing, some of whom are feared to be among the dead.”
Some of the family members of missing Britons watched the statement from the Commons gallery.

Mr Sunak said of the 10 who are missing, some are feared to be among the dead. The UK government is working with Israeli authorities to identify those killed and is supporting the families through their “unimaginable pain”.
Mr Sunak expressed his horror at the way Hamas had targeted civilians in Israel, with more than 1,400 murdered, over 3,500 wounded and almost 200 taken hostage.
He added: “The elderly, men, women, children, babes in arms, murdered, mutilated, burned alive. We should call it by its name: it was a pogrom.”

The Prime Minister spoke to Mahmoud Abbas, the leader of the Palestinian Authority, by telephone on Monday as he steps up the UK’s diplomatic efforts to ensure the conflict does not spread beyond Israel and Gaza.

Efforts are continuing from the PM and Foreign Office to persuade Egypt to open up the Rafah crossing, on its border with southern Gaza, to allow civilians to leave and more humanitarian aid to enter.
UK Border Force officials are already in Egypt working with the British embassy to assist British nationals leaving Gaza if and when the crossing opens.

Mr Sunak also announced that the UK’s humanitarian aid to the Palestinian territories will increase by more than a third, from £27m to £37m, to support civilians who have been forced to leave their homes in Gaza due to Israel’s bombardment.

title: Tory MP Peter Bone facing six-week suspension over bullying and sexual misconduct
lead: New by-election possible after parliamentary panel finds he acted in a ‘mocking, belittling and humiliating’ manner towards a member of his staff
author: Eleanor Langford

body.text: Tory MP Peter Bone is facing a six-week suspension from the Commons after being found to have committed bullying and sexual misconduct against a staff member.

Parliament’s Independent Expert Panel (IEP) said the MP for Wellingborough “committed many varied acts of bullying and one act of sexual misconduct” against a member of his staff between 2012 and 2013.
If the suspension is approved by MPs, it could lead to the Conservative MP facing a recall petition that would pave the way for another possible by-election.
In a statement, Mr Bone said the IEP investigation into him “was flawed, procedurally unfair and didn’t comply with its own rules and regulations.
He added: “As I have maintained throughout these proceedings, none of the misconduct allegations against me ever took place. They are false and untrue claims. They are without foundation.
“The allegations by an ex-employee refer to events of more than 10 years ago that spanned no more than a few months.”

He claimed that the initial Independent Complaints and Grievance Scheme (ICGS) investigation against him, which he has since appealed via the IEP, had “operated outside of the powers given to them by Parliament”.
“I am currently discussing with lawyers what action could and should be taken,” Mr Bone added.
According to the IEP report, five allegations by a Westminster staffer were made in October 2021, having had a complaint in 2017, to then-prime minister Theresa May, unresolved.

The report into Mr Bone claims he “verbally belittled, ridiculed, abused and humiliated” his employee, and “repeatedly physically struck and threw things” at him, including pencils and rolled-up documents.
He is also alleged to have imposed an “unwanted and humiliating ritual” on the employee by forcing him to sit with his hands in his lap when the MP was unhappy with his work.

The complainant also alleged that Mr Bone had “repeatedly pressurised” the member of staff to give him a massage in the office and, on a visit to Madrid with the All-Party Parliamentary Group on Human Trafficking, indecently exposed himself to the complainant in the bathroom and bedroom of the hotel room they were sharing.

The Parliamentary Standards Commissioner upheld all four allegations of bullying and the allegation of sexual misconduct relating to the incident in Madrid. Hoever it found the demands for massages were bullying, not sexual misconduct.

Mr Bone appealed against the decision, which was then upheld by a sub-panel of the IEP, which described it as a “serious case of misconduct” including “a deliberate and conscious abuse of power using a sexual mechanism”.

The sub-panel said: “The bullying involved violence, shouting and swearing, mocking, belittling and humiliating behaviour, and ostracism. It was often in front of others… The respondent specifically targeted the complainant.”

If Mr Bone’s suspension is approved by MPs, it will trigger a recall petition in his constituency in Northampstonshire. If the petition is signed by 10 per cent of eligible voters, it will trigger a by-election.
A petition can be launched if an MP is suspended for more than 10 sitting days or convicted of a criminal offence.

The mechanism was most recently used to oust former SNP MP Margaret Ferrier after she was suspended from the Commons for 30 days for breaching the Code of Conduct for MPs by breaking coronavirus regulations during the pandemic.
A by-election was held in her seat of Rutherglen and Hamilton West, which was won by Labour candidate Michael Shanks.

Former Tory MP Chris Pincher was set to face a recall petition after the Committee on Standards recommended he be suspended for eight weeks for sexual misconduct, but he resigned as an MP before the sanction could be voted on.
The by-election in his Tamworth seat is due to take place on 19 October.

title: MPs call for pro-Hamas supporters to be deported amid anger over protesters celebrating Israeli deaths
lead: Home Secretary Suella Braverman warned ‘the police are coming’ for protesters who celebrated Israeli deaths
author: Eleanor Langford

body.text: MPs are calling for pro-Hamas supporters to be deported amid anger over some protesters at Palestine solidarity marches celebrating Israeli deaths.

Thousands of people joined pro-Palestinian marches in London and other cities in the UK in Saturday, while the Metropolitan Police warned ahead of the rallies that anyone showing support for Hamas could face arrest.
Following the protests, the force said it arrested 15 people for a range of public order offences, while a man in his sixties was arrested for making racist comments to a police officer.

The Metropolitan Police are also seeking information on a woman pictured at the protest with an image of a paraglider taped to her shirt, which is widely believed to reference the Hamas fighters who used paragliders to enter Israel.

Writing on X on Sunday, Home Secretary Suella Braverman warned that “the police are coming” for anyone attending the protests who “saw fit to promote genocide, glorify terrorism and mock the murder of Jewish people”.
Several MPs have backed calls for non-UK citizens who praise Hamas or promote anti-Semitism to be deported.

The  reported earlier this week that immigration minister Robert Jenrick has asked officials to look at how they could revoke visas on national security grounds for people who commit hate crimes or express support for the terror group.

Tory MP and former minister Jonathan Gullis told  he supported the move to revoke visas. He said: “Terrorist sympathisers and supporters who don’t hold a UK passport must be immediately deported to ensure the safety and security of not just our Jewish community, but law abiding British citizens too.

“Those who choose to celebrate on the streets of our United Kingdom the kidnapping, murder, and beheading of innocent Israeli men, women, and children pose a severe threat to our national security and deserve to have the full force of the law thrown at them.”

Backbench Tory MP Brendan Clarke-Smith would be “more than happy” to see pro-Palestine marches banned, as has already happened in France, and he supports plans for those supporting Hamas to be deported.
Brendan Clarke-Smith: “I’d be more than happy to ban the marches altogether (as other countries have).”

Justice Minister Mike Freer, who represents Finchley and Golders Green, which has a large Jewish population, called for police forces to provide “regular updates” on the number of arrests in order to reassure the Jewish community amid a rise in antisemitic attacks.
“The visible presence on the streets locally has been much appreciated. The police have made arrests following the demonstration in central London yesterday,” hes aid.

“To continue to retain the confidence of the Jewish community the Met should provide regular updates on the number of arrests. The zero tolerance approach needs to be visible from demo to the charging of individuals to break the law.”

But he cautioned against police adopting a heavy-handed approach, suggesting that to have moved into large protests to make arrests would have risked rioting. Police, he said, “can’t wade into a large crowd in case they triggered a major public order problem”.
“Arresting people when safe to do so is right. The police have been incredibly supportive in a very difficult situation.”
Community Security Trust (CST), a Jewish charity, said that in the past four days it had recorded 89 anti-Jewish hate incidents in the UK.
This included six physical assaults, three cases of vandalism towards Jewish property and 66 of abusive behaviour.

Several schools – including Torah Vodaas Primary School in Edgware, Ateres Beis Yaakov Primary School in Colindale, and Menorah High School in Neasden – informed parents last week that they would temporarily shut amid fears of antisemitic attacks.

title: Scottish independence to be on ballot paper at general election as SNP approves new strategy
lead: SNP members agreed that winning a majority of seats in Scotland will constitute a mandate to begin negotiations with the UK Government
author: Chris Green

body.text: The SNP will put Scottish independence on the ballot paper at the next general election, with party members agreeing that winning a majority of the Westminster seats north of the border will constitute a mandate to begin negotiations on IndyRef2 with the UK Government.

Following a two-hour debate on the opening day of the SNP conference in Aberdeen, members approved a heavily amended motion which was first put forward by Humza Yousaf and Westminster leader Stephen Flynn.

The approved text states that the SNP will seek to add the words “Independence for Scotland” alongside its name and logo on the ballot paper, to make it “clear beyond doubt” to voters that this is its primary purpose at the election.

It adds that if the party then wins 29 or more of Scotland’s 57 Westminster seats, Holyrood ministers can “begin immediate negotiations with the UK Government to give democratic effect to Scotland becoming an independent country”, potentially including the transfer of powers to hold indyref2.

The party’s manifesto at the election, which is expected to be held next year, will also say on the first line of its first page that people should “vote SNP for Scotland to become an independent country”.

The decision ends a long period of uncertainty about the SNP’s independence strategy which began after the UK Supreme Court ruled nearly a year ago that Holyrood does not have the power to hold indyref2 without Westminster’s permission.

SNP members rejected the idea of treating the general election as a “de facto” referendum in which it would seek to win 50.1 per cent or more of the overall vote, an idea first put forward by Nicola Sturgeon before she resigned in February.

Its new aim of winning a majority of seats to achieve a mandate for negotiations with the UK is easier to achieve, but more difficult than the route favoured by Mr Yousaf, who wanted the bar to be set at merely winning more seats than any other party.

Opening the debate, he described Ms Sturgeon’s plan as the “wrong approach”, adding: “Let’s not fall into the trap of setting ourselves a bar no other party sets itself to win … in an election a majority of seats is a victory, plain and simple.”

Mr Yousaf, who has faced a tumultuous first six months as SNP leader, also made a plea for his party to unite behind the newly agreed strategy and “move on from talking about process to talking about policy”.
“After today, when we’ve democratically decided as a party together on the way forward, let us unite. For it is our unity which is our greatest strength as a party,” he said.

MP Tommy Sheppard, meanwhile, said only a referendum like the one held in 2014 could bring about independence, and that the only way to “keep alive the possibility” of this happening was by winning the election next year.
“If we lose that election, then that journey stops. The debate will be closed down and it will be taken off the table. So we cannot afford to lose that election,” he added.

title: Newcastle will reject any Man Utd approach for director of football Dan Ashworth
lead: Man Utd’s incoming minority owner Jim Ratcliffe is an admirer of Ashworth but sources tell i he remains ‘fully invested’ in Newcastle
author: Mark Douglas

body.text: Sir Jim Ratcliffe is expected to assume a “hands on” role in the restructure of Manchester United‘s football department – but any move for Newcastle United director of football Dan Ashworth will be met with fierce resistance at St James’ Park.
United’s board will meet on Thursday morning to vote on proceeding with Ratcliffe’s proposal to take a 25 per cent stake in the club in return for control over its football operations.
No issues are anticipated as the 10-month takeover process finally reaches a conclusion, even if it is one that comes with the contentious prospect of the Glazers remaining in majority control.
“We are in the end game now,” one source close to the process told . But in reality, the hard work starts here for Ratcliffe and his team of football advisors.

Although the INEOS camp are reticent to get drawn on the exact details of the agreement or how much work remains to be done on the structure of the deal, there is an acknowledgement that Ratcliffe has done his homework ahead of becoming a co-owner.
And he has strong ideas about what needs to be done at Old Trafford to make them competitive again.
While faith remains in manager Erik ten Hag despite a downturn in results this season, there are expected to be wholesale changes at executive level.

Ratcliffe’s due diligence on where the Red Devils are falling behind will have identified recruitment as a major failing and the spotlight will undoubtedly fall on director of football John Murtough and chief executive Richard Arnold.
The squad looks unbalanced and disjointed, the result of several different managers being backed expensively in the transfer market.

Worse still, many of those no longer in favour are on long contracts that interested clubs are not prepared to match. Ratcliffe himself accused the club of being the “dumb money” in 2019 and in truth little has changed since then.
A proposed restructure of football operations is one potential solution with a new director of football possible.
Likely candidates include Paul Mitchell, who has recently left Monaco and is based in Manchester, and former Liverpool sporting director Michael Edwards.

And Ratcliffe has been greatly impressed by the work done by Ashworth, who has overseen the second phase of Newcastle’s development after their 2021 takeover by the Saudi Arabia Public Investment Fund.

Any approach would most likely fail,  understands. The Magpies no longer see themselves as a stepping stone club and in addition to huge compensation that any rival would need to pay to poach Ashworth, there is confidence he would not be interested in leaving Newcastle at such an important stage in their development.
Indeed  understands that Ashworth is committed to his role in the North East and is “fully invested” in a sporting project that aims to secure the club a place in Europe’s elite.
Although Newcastle are playing Champions League football this season they remain – in relative terms – in the early stages of the club’s transformation.

Ashworth is engaged in a huge and well-financed restructure of Newcastle’s football operations, including a total overhaul of scouting systems and the integration of a new data department into decision-making.

He is also putting a new overseas scouting network into place. As Informfully reported last week, a new partnership with Northern Irish side Larne FC is a model the club are looking to replicate in other countries.

It is typical of the sort of challenges Ratcliffe and INEOS are set to face when they finally get the keys to Old Trafford. There are no easy wins and a pack of well-funded, smart rivals who have overtaken United in recent years are not likely to take any approaches for key men lying down.

title: No Ben Stokes and too much golf: What’s gone wrong for England at the Cricket World Cup
lead: England are staring down the barrel of their most humiliating World Cup exit to date following defeats to New Zealand and Afghanistan
author: Chris Stocks

body.text: England‘s hopes of defending the Cricket World Cup are hanging by a thread after Afghanistan caused one of the biggest shocks in the tournament’s history.
Afghanistan set England a target of 285 after taking advantage of some loose bowling at the death, before Jos Buttler‘s men were bowled out for a mere 215.
The loss has left England in danger of missing out on the semi-finals and comes ahead of them having to face South Africa in Mumbai on 21 October.
Chris Stocks takes a look at where it has all gone wrong after such a disappointing start to the campaign.

From the moment Ben Stokes came out of retirement in August, England’s World Cup build-up was overshadowed by off-field issues. The news on Stokes, who had retired from ODIs in the summer of 2022, was good. But his selection forced Harry Brook out of the initial squad for the tournament in India.

That precipitated a weeks-long discussion about why the best young batter in the world could be overlooked for the World Cup. It proved a massive distraction and inevitably Brook scored serious runs in the T20 series against New Zealand that followed and was on the plane to India when Jason Roy’s back injury flared up again. Brook then ended up playing when Stokes picked up a hip injury and was ruled out of the start of the tournament – another huge talking point and yet another distraction.

The Jofra Archer soap opera hasn’t helped either, the fast bowler named as a reserve who could only play towards the back end of the World Cup and who will only arrive in India this week. He’s not near match fitness either but the narrative around Archer, one of the heroes of the 2019 World Cup win, isn’t helpful.

India is an unforgiving place to tour with conditions markedly different from the UK. The three ODIs against New Zealand in September were England’s first for six months and of little value in terms of preparing for India.

Having the first of two warm-up matches rained off once they arrived in the country didn’t help, with a sole match against Bangladesh the only run out in Indian conditions before England got their tournament underway. Fail to prepare and prepare to fail as the saying goes.

England’s players love a round of golf or five. Most spent the days leading into the Afghanistan match dragging their clubs around the DLF Country Club on the outskirts of Delhi where the course was designed by Gary Player.
Touring life is hard and the players deserve to unwind away from cricket.
But maybe if the players worked as hard on training as they do on their handicaps they wouldn’t be in this mess.

There’s no danger of naughty boy nets in Mumbai this week either given there is another golf day on Tuesday – a social fixture that has caused coach Matthew Mott’s long-awaited first press conference of the tour to be delayed until 5.30pm local time.

Somewhere along the line England have lost the aggressive intent that was the hallmark of their white-ball revival under former captain Eoin Morgan following their first-round exit from the 2015 World Cup in Australia and New Zealand.
There were moments before this tournament, namely during their defeat by Ireland in last year’s T20 World Cup in Australia and during the recent home ODI series against New Zealand.
But in India their defeats by New Zealand and Afghanistan have been characterised by uncharacteristic passive batting. On Sunday, not one player was caught in the deep.
This is reminiscent of England before the white-ball revolution and the buck stops with Mott and Buttler. They need to regain that no-fear approach or they will perish in this tournament.

The lack of aggressive intent can be linked to both Mott and Buttler. One dressing-room source has told  that Mott is very much a backseat driver and not one to lay down the law. Buttler by his very nature is never going to give Churchillian speeches or dressing-room dressing downs.
It’s telling that it was Stokes who spoke up in the dressing room after that Ireland upset in the T20 World Cup in Melbourne last year. The fact he has not played in India has surely had an effect.

Are England suffering from a lack of firm leadership? The results so far here would suggest as much and you cannot blame them for suffering from the loss of Morgan, whose iron-will and determination filtered down through the squad.

title: Why Maro Itoje and Joe Marchant are key to England beating South Africa
lead: South Africa’s 29-28 win over France shows they have few weaknesses, but this is how England can exploit the reigning world champions
author: Louis Doré

body.text: While Steve Borthwick pores over the footage of South Africa’s 29-28 victory over Rugby World Cup hosts France, looking for a gap in the armour, he may be rather dismayed at the extent of its coverage.
The World Champion Springboks looked a well-rounded, imposing side in their narrow victory over the home team in Paris who had been widely backed to go to the whole way in the tournament.

A reminder of the formidable qualities the Boks possess had been overdue after a 13-8 pool stage loss to Ireland in which they seemed a little less on-song, but this was a performance which suggested they’d sealed up the weaknesses the Irish had temporarily exposed too.

The Boks had a point to prove with their scrum on Saturday. It had been less than dominant against Andy Farrell’s side, but was a notable point of strength against France. They won seven out of eight on their own put-in won, nobbling four of France’s nine.

They felt so much in the ascendancy in that part of the game that at one point full back Damian Willemse opted for a scrum in his 22 after calling a mark – an option casual fans may even have forgotten is available to a side such is the frequency with which a clearance kick to touch is deployed. The Boks won a scrum penalty from that mark, by the way.
England’s scrum is by no means poor, but they will have to be on their game and clever in their communication with the referee to defuse the famed ‘bomb squad’.

Borthwick can also draw some element of predictability from their lineout – albeit with a pinch of salt. The Boks almost never throw to the back, presumably because sending RG Snyman up in the middle or front rarely results in a turnover.

If Maro Itoje is truly back to his disruptive, combative best as he claims, there may be some fruit to pick there. That said, the excellent French second row Cameron Woki didn’t manage to overwhelm the Springbok line, so the challenge is evidently fearsome.

When it comes to defence, England have a large problem. For the last year, England haven’t looked a side particularly potent at getting around an organised rush with ease, and looked a tad predictable about kicking behind it – though it must be said in recent matches there has been more variation there.
Matthieu Jalibert and Antoine Dupont reaped some rewards with a little chip over the top of the defence between front line and full-back – the sort of which Joe Marchant is excellent at chasing.

The problem England have is that the man recovering the kick is often Cheslin Kolbe, who was in simply electric form on Saturday. Two clean breaks and four defenders beaten, with a try and a charged-down conversion. That suggests he is a fast and agile man to whom one should maybe not give the ball in broken play.

Another ominous point was how the Boks responded to a France line break or half-break. The Springboks cover defence against France was simply immense. Only 12 missed tackles in a match against France is, in a word, astonishing.

In the words of head coach Jacques Nienaber: “We were broken up defensively, we were opened up a couple of times. But the amount of work rate and scramble and effort that the players put in was enormous.”

Captain Siya Kolisi added: “We scrambled a lot and we scrambled hard, especially when we were short of numbers. We talk about chasing lost causes as a group, and you don’t give up until they put the ball down on the tryline.”
England will need to be clinical when they get a half-break, because the Springboks have shown when they shut the door on you, they shut it hard.

Then to top it all off, they bring on the likes of Kwagga Smith. In five minutes he made two turnovers, effectively sealing the win for the Springboks. He has six in this tournament despite mostly operating from the bench.
When the play is broken late in the game and legs are tired, England need to be keenly aware of getting isolated in attack around Smith, who can end the game all on his own.

In attack, the Boks were adaptable and pacey. They were as comfortable relying on set-piece as forcing a high-tempo attacking game through the hands, as they were pumping high balls into the channel for the likes of Kolbe to rise high and catch for yardage.

When they brought on Faf de Klerk and Handre Pollard, they both calmed the game down and the latter looked impressively on-pace despite his long injury lay-off. This is a side that can play a number of ways to defeat a foe.

All in all there are no obvious weaknesses to exploit in a team that showed the fortitude to face down the tournament favourites in their back yard, in front of nearly 80,000 fans all bellowing to the referee to sway him.
Over to you, Steve Borthwick.

title: Italian football rocked by new betting scandal – what’s next for Newcastle’s Sandro Tonali
lead: Allegations into Tonali and Aston Villa’s Nicolo Zaniolo have thrown the Azzurri’s Euro 2024 hopes into disarray
author: Alasdair Mackenzie

body.text: On the eve of Italy’s trip to Wembley, faces of three Azzurri stars stared up from espresso-stained newspapers in every coffee bar across the peninsula – but they had nothing to do with the crunch Euro 2024 qualifier against England.
The build-up to Tuesday’s game has been tumultuous to say the least, as an illegal betting probe threatens to throw Italian football into chaos once again.

Newcastle midfielder Sandro Tonali and Aston Villa winger Nicolo Zaniolo are at the epicentre of this rapidly moving story; both were sent back to their clubs from the Italy camp last Thursday after police began investigations into them as part of a probe into illegal betting platforms.

“Regardless of the nature of the events, considering that the two players are not in the necessary condition to face the matches scheduled for the next few days, the federation has decided, also for their protection, to allow them to return to their respective clubs,” said an Italian FA (FIGC) statement.
The sudden announcement of Tonali and Zaniolo’s departure came a day after news broke that the same Turin prosecutors were investigating Juventus midfielder Nicolo Fagioli.

The Premier League pair’s electronic devices were seized, and there has since been endless debate around what will happen next amid swirling reports of several more unknown players imminently being named in the investigation, and the potential punishments that could be dished out.

On Monday, ’s headline said “Tonali at risk” in relation to alleged bets made on football games, while Corriere dello Sport claimed that the three players so far involved in the investigation “will miss the Euros” next summer.
Zaniolo’s lawyer said the Galatasaray-owned forward has “never placed bets” but had “possibly played poker and blackjack on illegal online platforms without knowing that they were.”

This is a significant point, as Article 24 of the FIGC sporting justice code forbids players from betting on FIGC, UEFA or FIFA-organised events, with a minimum three-year ban and €25,000 (£21,600) fine being the punishment for anyone who does.

If those rules are broken, one way of reducing the suspension is by collaborating with the authorities, and Italian media reports on Monday said that Fagioli will accept a plea bargain that could see him get a reduced ban due to self-reporting his actions and helping the investigation.
According to , Tonali has accepted help from a therapist for a gambling addiction, and there has been some sympathy shown to the players implicated in the investigation from the football world.
Italy Under-21 coach Carmine Nunziata called gambling “a sickness that must be cured” and added that “we must give a big hand to these guys to help them understand certain things.”

The story has dominated Italian news for much of the last week and provided an unwanted distraction for the Azzurri ahead of a massive game for their qualifying campaign, at the very venue where they were crowned European champions two years ago.

Since the two sides last met in Naples back in March, much has changed for Italy. They have a new coach in Luciano Spalletti, the man who masterminded Napoli’s first Scudetto in 33 years last season, after Roberto Mancini’s controversial decision to quit and quickly take the Saudi Arabia job.
“It was a tough night with a lot of bitterness about what has happened. The whole team is close to Tonali and Zaniolo,” Spalletti said after the pair were sent home.
The coach later called Tuesday’s clash “a match that will tell us what the future holds,” as, despite Saturday’s 4-0 win over Malta, the reigning European champions are at a crossroads.
A win would send Italy joint-top with England and three points clear of Ukraine with two November qualifiers remaining.

However, defeat would leave them level in second and facing a nerve-wracking finish next month against North Macedonia – the team that knocked them out of the World Cup play-offs last year – and a Ukraine side also bidding to break the top two.
For a team with a very shaky qualifying record in recent years, that is not a welcome prospect.

title: Fiji have been the best team to watch at the World Cup – why does rugby treat them so badly?
lead: Teams from outside the elite of world rugby continue to struggle financially and tier-one sides won’t even play against them
author: James Gray

body.text: “Everyone’s second-favourite team.”
That was the rather patronising epithet ascribed to Fiji after they were knocked out of the Rugby World Cup on Sunday. They deserved better.

But in truth they would be more than happy to be more people’s second-favourite team, including those in charge of rugby union. Because at present, Fiji, and everything they represent in rugby, are a lot further down the pecking order.

The irony is that it is only these “plucky losers” who make the tournament feasible by providing opposition for the big boys of world rugby. But now that we’ve reached the business end of the World Cup, the established elites can stop pretending to care about Fiji, Tonga, Portugal et al for another four years.

And yet after dispatching the last of what World Rugby might prefer to call “the rest”, Steve Borthwick, coach of an England team whose union turn over £200m a year, was the one claiming the world was against him.
“Let’s not forget this team was written off, and we will be written off again going to Paris,” Borthwick said
“I don’t really care what other people think of us. I care about the development of the team.”
His opposite number Simon Raiwalui does not have the luxury of not caring what other people think. What other people think is what defines Fiji’s future in the game.
“We have to put ourselves in the shop window with our performance and if we’ve got that infrastructure, we’ve got success, consistent success,” Raiwalui said.
“When the opportunity comes up, hopefully we will get a chance, but if we concentrate on the long term, instead of getting the short term right, you tend to trip up on yourself.

“We have to be proud of the last four years, and before that, eight years, what we’ve built in Fiji and I think it’s is there for long term success and sustainability. So if the opportunity does come up, but hopefully we’ve put ourselves in the front of the window.”

Fiji’s pound-for-pound contribution to rugby is probably the greatest of any country, never less true than at this World Cup. Always known for flair and physicality, they have retained those qualities (against England, they recorded 13 dominant tackles, joint-highest of the quarter-finals with Ireland, and 16 offloads) while adding a growing willingness to grind out results that has not always been part of the Fijian gamestyle. In the pool stages, only Japan conceded fewer penalties, and when they beat Australia, there were 17 points from the boot to go with just the one try.

Add to that victory that they were within one dropped pass of a win over Wales and were similarly a bounce of a ball away from shocking England, and in their three games against the elites of world rugby, they won one, and narrowly lost two. Scotland would have done anything for that outcome.

And perhaps if they had been in those situations more often, they would have been able to produce accuracy in those biggest moments. But they have only faced top-level opposition 11 times in the four years since the last World Cup, a fact that surely has to change as a Fiji squad ready to evolve prepares for the next tournament.
“I couldn’t be proud of this group terms of what they’ve put in,” Raiwalui added.
“They’ve built something for the next generation of Fijian rugby players. They’ve laid the foundation there that we can grow.”

World Rugby will point to the introduction of Fijian Drua into Super Rugby, which receives – together with Moana Pasifika – £1.2m of annual funding from World Rugby, as well as direct cash injections into the high performance schemes of the countries involved. But let us just remember those RFU figures: £200m a year in turnover, yet the entire rugby world can only spare £1.2m to make sure it is played professionally by more than 10 countries.
Charles Piutau, a former All Black who now plays for Tonga, says he has learned the difference between the haves and the have-nots since making his debut for the country of his parents last year.
“It’s the lack of resources. We come into the Tonga team and we hardly have any kit, one pair of shorts to train for the week, always having to wash everything every day,” Piutau said.

“We might not have snacks to replenish ourselves after a gym session. Sometimes we might have to cover our own flights to get to training camps. I think sometimes all of those off-field things can add up.
“Before we started in the Rugby World Cup camp, we were struggling to find rugby balls. We were using replicas from the regular shop and it wasn’t the real thing.

“What I have been a part of before with the All Blacks set-up, all you needed to worry about was playing that game and doing your role in that jersey. You could come [to training] naked and end up with enough clothes that you don’t need anything – and get a watch.”

Piutau was talking after a 59-16 defeat to Ireland in Nantes in which his side showed some of their naivety against the world No 1 team. It is hardly a surprise: it was only their fourth clash with a tier-one nation since 2019, and all of those had come in 2019.

“It happens every campaign. We go on three, four-week campaigns and the last game’s always our best game because we’ve had more time together and we’ve played some opposition,” said Toutai Kefu, Tonga’s departing head coach, after their final pool-stage match against South Africa.
His parting shot for World Rugby was an uncomplicated plea for more opportunity and funding.
“There are two simple things: we get to spend more time together, more preparation time, and the other one is playing more competitive games,” Kefu added.

“We play six games a year and maybe one or two tier-one games in that block. What do the tier-one teams play? They play more than 15, 20. It’s hard to compete against teams who are really well-oiled machines.”
There are willing lip-servants in the game to that cause.
“The more opportunities to play in bigger games, the better they’re gonna be,” said Andy Farrell, probably the northern hemisphere’s best coach.
“I know that they speaking to them they would have loved to have tier one nations played in a warm-up game  but that wasn’t to be.”
The phrase “wasn’t to be” doesn’t really cut it in the circumstances: Ireland’s RWC meeting with Tonga was the first time in 20 years that they had come up against them. Why not pick up the phone?

You can tell the same story over and over again too, but just switch out the names: Samoa, Uruguay, Chile and Portugal all produced performances worthy of the global stage in this tournament, but will not feature on it again until 2027.

And you cannot dismiss their claims by pointing out that most did not make it out of the group. This is a seven-week tournament that, were they not there at all, would be half as long and nowhere near as entertaining. Desperate to appear in that “shop window”, they almost all produced historically good performances, like Portugal’s first ever win at a World Cup or Uruguay’s spirited effort against home favourites France in Lille.

And yet World Rugby plans to narrow its focus, rather than broaden it. The “World League”, due to start in 2026, will provide a quadrennial dovetail with the World Cup. Reports state that it will feature the Six Nations teams in one group and the Rugby Championship countries in another, with two “invited guests”, likely to include Japan, making up the numbers.

So that’s one place at the top table for nations who have lit up France with their endeavour and their pride over the last two months, while the rest continue to starve on the measly scraps that the gluttons of England, Ireland, New Zealand and the rest allow to fall to the floor.
With concussion lawsuits and an ever-expanding sports entertainment market, rugby is at a crossroads that will challenge its very existence. It cannot afford to keep ignoring its best assets.

title: Man Utd takeover: The questions facing Jim Ratcliffe – and why deal is a triumph for the Glazers
lead: As Ratcliffe prepares to take control of football operations, the balance of power is still unclear and may well lie with the Glazers
author: Mark Douglas

body.text: Sir Jim Ratcliffe is the man who bankrolled an attempt to break the mythical 2-hour barrier for the men’s marathon, so we can assume the INEOS founder likes a challenge.
When he walks into Old Trafford to be anointed part owner of Manchester United in the coming days he will certainly get that.

Not only will he face a wall of suspicion from fans wondering why he’s gone into partnership with the unpopular Glazer family – he’ll also be assuming control of football operations at a time when United seem as far as ever from competing with the Premier League’s elite.

Ratcliffe and his advisors are not short of confidence and believe they have the answers. Expect significant changes and investment, sources close to INEOS have told . Just like the sub 2-hour marathon, they say, smart money can buy success.
There are a lot of unanswered questions here though, not least the structure of the deal and whether it comes with cast-iron guarantees that the Glazers’ majority stake will be phased out in time.

There are also practical, day-to-day concerns for Ratcliffe to contend with. If he decides to fire a coach or restructure the scouting department at great cost, does he have carte blanche to do so even when 75 per cent of the club is owned by others?

Are we really supposed to buy the fact that football operations can be guillotined from commercial ones? As the Mason Greenwood decision illustrated, quite often these things can straddle more than one area.
There will be a lot of voices in the room when Manchester United take big decisions now, and no shortage of egos. Power lines will need to be strictly defined if the club are to make progress.

Fuming from the sidelines are the Qatari bid team, led by the mysterious Sheikh Jassim bin Al-Thani. The uncertainty around him, his intentions and how closely the bid was linked to the Gulf state were never really cleared up and that probably didn’t help.

He felt he could be a dream owner and £1.4bn of investment was earmarked for the club. Sources talked of modernising everything, making Old Trafford a venue fit for purpose and putting a team on the pitch that would compete with any in the world.
“A new vision,” sources close to Sheikh Jassim said. But his refusal to pay a premium for the club or play the Glazers’ game means he walks away with nothing.

The big winners are undoubtedly the Glazer family. Reviled by huge sections of the club’s fanbase and presiding over an undoubtedly diminished Manchester United, they have nevertheless managed to secure more than £1bn to fund sorely needed infrastructure improvements while retaining a 75 per cent stake in the club.
It’s an astonishing triumph for the clan, with Ratcliffe’s desire to sort out the football side of things even giving them plausible deniability next time things go wrong on the pitch.

They are impressively calculating in their approach, immune to sentiment or what seems obviously best for the institution they own. From day one their motivation has been to drive the best deal for them, not for the club.

And they’ve certainly done that here, whatever the noises coming from the Ratcliffe camp about this being the start of the journey towards a full takeover or his INEOS group taking on football operations.
Underpinning their desire to cling on to a majority stake in Manchester United is their belief that the valuation of football clubs will sky rocket in the years to come.
Advances in technology, the growth of the game in the Middle East and future TV deals are all there to be exploited, they feel.

As their wholehearted enthusiasm for the European Super League shows, they will be ruthless if they feel there’s money in it for them and the £6bn valuation might end up looking skinny if the Premier League continues on its current trajectory.

In getting everything they wanted, they’ve played a blinder. If only they showed the same acumen for running a football club, United might not need the sort of repairs Ratcliffe will now take responsibility for overseeing.

title: Dylan Hartley: The Owen Farrell I know – great leader, family man and a phenomenal singer
lead: When Owen says all he wants to do is get better as a player, he means it
author: Dylan Hartley

body.text: Steve Borthwick had a huge selection call to make for England’s World Cup quarter-final, surrounding George Ford, Owen Farrell and Marcus Smith.
It’s the sort of dilemma pitched to many a English rugby fan – start one, bench one, drop one – what would you do? A perfect problem for a coach when you’ve got an embarrassment of riches.

Up to this point England’s selection policy at fly-half had been relatively straightforward, simply because Owen was unavailable at the start of the competition. But now Borthwick has had to choose and he has gone for Owen to start.

Here is where I think England stand. They are not like Ireland or South Africa, a heavyweight team so big, strong and dynamic that they are able to roll out more or less the same team in every match, because they know their best line-up. England are more like a cruiserweight – they have to select smart and box clever.

They aren’t able to bully their opponents and they can’t run them off their feet. They are finding ways to win through tactical nous, and as a result they are adapting week by week. So I don’t see an out-and-out first-choice XV.

Owen was Borthwick’s choice of captain for this World Cup, but he picked up a ban during the warm-up matches and the picture changed as a result. Matchday captaincy was picked up seamlessly and managed well by Courtney Lawes, England’s Mr Consistent. My guess was we would see the continuity of George Ford starting at No 10 with Owen and Marcus on the bench contributing to the game at the appropriate time.

Instead England have Owen starting at 10 and Marcus at 15. It is a big story outside the camp, Steve will know that. George took his chance with both hands and guided England through their darkest hour of the opening match with Argentina.

The outside world sees it as dropping him but internally it will be seen as utilising the best 23 over 80 minutes to beat a difficult opposition in Fiji. To have a player of George’s quality and experience to view the game from the sidelines, then come on and impact it when you most need it, is invaluable.

The difficult part for Steve was making the decision. Once it was made, I reckon the players will have gone “yep, that’s fine” – sure, a player who is not picked to start will feel their pride is dented but there will be no sulking.

There’s obviously a considered approach to starting Owen at 10 and Marcus at 15. Looking at Smith at full-back suggests England expect the ball-in-play time to be high and the game to be more fluid, with less targeted kicking. While Fiji have been brilliant in most facets thus far, it’s not in their nature to kick away possession and target a full-back of Smith’s smaller height.

If South Africa were the opponents I’d expect Smith at full-back to be targeted and bombarded with high balls and aggressive kick-chase. Nothing against Marcus, but Freddie Steward physically has a foot or so in height over him and can defuse those aerial threats more easily.
It looks like England on Sunday expect a looser kicking strategy to bring Marcus into his natural game of unstructured running rugby.

So what can I tell you about Owen Farrell? He is one of the greats of English rugby, let’s get that straight for starters. He has 109 caps, and isn’t that amazing? Only four other Englishmen have passed the century mark, and three of them are in this squad: Ben Youngs, Courtney and Dan Cole. So Ben, for instance, will now be passing his experience to Alex Mitchell at scrum-half. That is how generations work.

Owen is pretty much a closed book to the outside world. I played with him for England for six years, and we were made co-captains by Eddie Jones towards the end of that time, and Owen and I built a great relationship based on a mutual love of the team, but he was something of a closed book to me too.

A lot of young players get into the game for what they can get out of it. Owen could buy the flash car and be seen at all the happening places. But he’s not chasing money or status. I believe that doesn’t motivate him. So you could joke he is pretty boring. He is not an overt social-media user, he loves his family and he loves rugby. When he says all he wants to do is get better as a player, he means it.

We were room-mates for a long spell but by the time you get back to your room as an international player, it’s usually a case of winding down and getting some kip. It’s a bit like a couple putting their kids to bed – you don’t then start off a whole new day of sparkling conversation.

Owen is a phenomenal singer, belting out a tune in the shower, and as a good apprentice he always had a fresh-ground coffee ready for me in the morning, but we didn’t finish the day discussing philosophy or films or the affairs of the world.

Did Owen always show a desire to be captain of England? When you are given the chance to lead, maybe at your club first, or in his case in England age groups, you then want a crack at it with the national team if you can. To see if you can make things better. To see if you can make a difference by doing what you do. You conduct yourself in the role you aspire to have. Becoming captain was a by-product of his attitude, of his will to improve.

You may have seen Owen receiving his accolade after England beat Samoa last weekend for becoming his country’s top points scorer, surpassing the great Jonny Wilkinson. All he said was thanks a few times and credited the other people in the room – it’s never about him. He has this blue-collar work ethic, instilled in him by his family and northern roots.

I have no doubt his grandfather in Wigan, and his dad Andy – hard-talking, hard-tackling – have influenced his attitude to work. I remind people that performance is a habit; you can’t just turn up at the weekend, it takes day-to-day professionalism and years of application. That’s what people mean when they talk about Owen’s leadership.

Training for England at this stage of a tournament is likely to be very much player-led. If Steve and his coaches asked the team to do something overwhelmingly physical, I’d expect the likes of Courtney to say no. That is not player power, it’s just sensible, and I am sure these England coaches who are all recently retired players will recognise it. So they might spend no more than five hours on their feet this week.

It’ll mostly be honing the set-piece and a few moves, and intense analysis on how they are going to expose Fiji.Steve has picked a team to go at them up front, but England know Fiji have upped their game there. It’s fascinating.

I heard a story retold recently, of a heart-to-heart I and a couple of other players once had with Ellis Genge. It was in 2016 and he was young and new to the England squad. And, hey, when you are young, what are the qualities you bring? Rawness, energy, desire… Eddie Jones was coach at the time and it was on the Thursday before a Test match.

Eddie had been pumping the tyres of Ellis and his fellow young prop Kyle Sinckler, telling them they needed to go hammer and tongs at each other to raise the intensity, otherwise there was no point them being there. They did go hammer and tongs, training like it was the last day on earth. But Ellis was not getting picked to play.

Those of us with older heads had seen it all before – we’d been those younger hotheads too. It wasn’t exactly a heart-to-heart with Ellis, more of a debrief, post-training. It comes from a point of understanding that they are desperate to be there.
He and Kyle had bags of energy. Their will and want and determination – combined with physical attributes and technical and tactical nous – have made them pretty fine rugby players.

title: James Maddison’s delicious Spurs-Liverpool banter shows how much England have changed for the better
lead: Gone are the days of club cliques and genuine disaffection between players
author: Daniel Storey

body.text: For at least a decade, the dynamic in international camps held England back. Now, England’s players love playing in this team. For all the negativity that will forever swirl around them, that is a triumph and should be a source of great pride.

The first thing to say, and it is important: it was a delicious piece of banter, the sort of banter that was fun before banter went bad. On his Instagram feed earlier this week, James Maddison posted an image of him and Trent Alexander-Arnold, tagging his England teammate in, with the sneaky caption: “Still asking for a replay”.

It cut through the bullshit instantly. It demonstrated that players rise above the outrage and see it all for what it is: more than a little bit silly. If there was any suggestion that there might be any lingering bitterness between the Tottenham and Liverpool contingents, of which Maddison and Alexander-Arnold are the entirety in this squad, this made it look foolish.

It also offered an insight into the changing dynamic of this England generation. The blame for the underperformance of England’s Golden Generation can be attributed to poor tactics, poor performance and poor luck as you wish, but of greater significance was the lack of bond between component parts of the squad. Here’s Frank Lampard to explain:

“We used to turn up for England duty, having gone up against each other all season, and all the major players from the ‘Golden Generation’ were the same. Myself and John [JT, to you, me and himself] were massively behind Chelsea and it was the same with Steven Gerrard and Jamie Carragher from Liverpool, the same with Rio [Ferdinand] and the Manchester United players.

“You really felt, as you should for your club, those bonds and it was human nature that we stayed in our own groups. If we could go back in time, maybe I would not have sat next to John at the dinner table every time – maybe, with experience, we could have crossed that divide.” Lord knows Lampard would have at least enjoyed a more pleasant dining experience.

This was football as a Very Serious Business, a point of personality principles. “Crossing the divide” is a gloriously melodramatic assessment of some blokes sitting at one table and some at another, several feet away, but it mattered.

Players within those squads – high on talent, low on unity – had genuine disaffection for each other. If you underplay its impact, you haven’t spent enough time around elite sports teams. Sporting ambition can live and die by its harmony.

The 2018 World Cup was the great lurch in the opposite direction, the breakout of Fun England. Fifteen of the 23 players in that squad had just finished in the Premier League’s top four – that could have made a difference. It was a squad of nice boys under a nice manager using previous failure and their own decency to do nice things.

It continued into Euro 2020, with its cavalcade of longreads on how Unity the inflatable unicorn was the nation’s spirit animal and an Atomic Kitten re-release was the soundtrack of the summer. That was Gareth Southgate’s greatest achievement: creating a positive environment that made winning a major tournament quarter-final 4-0 was in any way a normal thing.

The next challenge was to find a middle ground between the two and we may just have managed that too. There is a competitive edge in the group: the Liverpool–Manchester City rivalry, Tottenham and Arsenal both in the top four, Liverpool and Manchester United representatives.

But spend any time around these players, listening to them talk, and they seem like a bunch of mates. Rivalry is fuelled not by club cliques but by the competition for places, particularly in attacking midfield. And if someone isn’t in the team, they wish those who are the best and mean it.

The World Cup in Qatar was, ultimately, a disappointment thanks to a penalty miss and unfortunate defeat (England had double the number of French shots and roughly doubled their xG). But the most salient comment of England’s tournament came from Bukayo Saka before the quarter-final.

“This World Cup has been quite a journey so far. I have enjoyed every moment of it and the last few weeks have been the best weeks of my life. When I come away with England, it feels like a family. We are all so happy for each other when one of us scores or plays really well and I just want to keep making memories with the rest of these guys.”

Saka is not a young man prone to hyperbole. He has a culture at club level that cherishes and champions him (and his comment is no slight on Arsenal). He has done so much, so quickly. So if he says that the best weeks of his life were with this group, this “family”, we should believe him.

This all rails against the general vibe. Tribalism has never been higher in domestic football – perhaps that is one reason why England feels like an escape. The climate around Southgate is now majoritively negative.

That’s partly due to the demand to make good on the talent of this crop, and partly because we have been shown a glimpse of glory. Emotionally, it was easier to just get knocked out by Iceland, angrily demand a root-and-branch review and then quickly go back to club football.

But Saka, Maddison, Alexander-Arnold et al implicitly plea for something impossible: just let them play. It’s a fallacy, of course. Letting a group of England players just be is like squeezing a tube of toothpaste into the sink and then trying to refill it, a sea of swears and wasted ambition.
But this England team is having fun, on the pitch and in each other’s company. It goes something like this: if they’re smiling, so should we be.

title: ‘Not always the club’s fault’: The truth about Newcastle’s biggest transfer misses under Mike Ashley
lead: Newcastle’s ex-chief scout Graham Carr on unearthing gems in France, Ashley missing out on Eden Hazard, Raphael Varane and Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang, and why Sandro Tonali will come good
author: Mark Douglas

body.text: He is the man who helped turned the black and white of Newcastle into the red, white and blue of the French tricolor.

But for Graham Carr, the former Newcastle United chief scout who recalls riding the Eurostar to buy four French players on one January afternoon ten years ago, there will be no split loyalties when Paris Saint-Germain come to town on Wednesday.

“I love French football, I felt like I spent half my scouting career on a Eurostar to Lille watching one match or another, but Newcastle United is my club,” he tells  over a riotous hour recalling his rollercoaster seven years on Tyneside.

Carr is 78 years old now and has been semi-retired for five years but the phone still rings. Earlier this week it was the man from , a newspaper he became very friendly with when he was trying to attract the best of Ligue 1‘s talent for Newcastle’s French revolution.

A judiciously placed story every now and then was one way of keeping the club on the back pages in France. The other was keeping black and white boots on the ground, and usually that meant Carr, notebook in hand, introducing himself to agents, rival scouts, taxi drivers. Anyone who spoke English and had a snippet of insider info, essentially.
“I lived between Northampton and Kettering station so within 50 minutes I could be at St Pancras station,” he explains.
“Then I was an hour and a half from Lille – which was easier than getting to Manchester – and the players we were looking at were a hell of lot cheaper than the ones we’d have seen in Manchester.”
And, in many cases, much better.
“It was a great market and it worked for us,” he says.

“Our wage structure was about £40,000-a-week. These lads were on about 20,000 Euros so a lot of them came to us for £30,000-a-week, which made a big difference to them but didn’t break the bank for Newcastle.”
Hatem Ben Arfa was his first big signing in 2011, persuading a sceptical owner Mike Ashley over a conference call that he was “a perfect number ten, able to come in from the left on his right foot”.
Then came Yohan Cabaye, a player he’d first seen playing for France’s U18s in a tournament in Belfast.
“Great attitude,” he recalls. “Not the biggest but a superb long range passer and a tough bugger.”

Moussa Sissoko was signed in 2013 for £1.5m from Toulouse and Mathieu Debuchy nicked the same year, like Cabaye, from Lille. For a time it felt like he could do no wrong but he still recalls the ones that got away.

There was a private plane ride with Ashley to Saint-Etienne to watch a 16-year-old Kurt Zouma and Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang. Carr told him both would be worth tens of millions but “nothing came of it”.

He alerted the club to a young Hugo Lloris, passed on a tip about an academy prospect called Eden Hazard and also remembers ringing managing director Derek Llambias excitedly about Raphael Varane, then a 17-year-old defender at Lens, and telling him Newcastle had to have him.
“It wasn’t always the club’s fault though you know,” he says.

“Newcastle is a fantastic place – and Northumberland is beautiful on its doorstep – but some of these lads, their first thought was how cold it is up there and why would you want to play there? And with some of them, you knew their agents had bigger things in mind.
“It’s why I’m so happy about where the club is now. You can sell them the Champions League and wanting to win things, which we couldn’t really at the time.”
Despite the tight budget he got on well with Ashley, understood what made him tick and has remained on good terms with his former employer who – he admits – “Looked after me when I left”.

Club meetings could be held on Ashley’s boat in Saint-Tropez and on one occasion, when a fed-up Carr was contemplating leaving, a helicopter landed close to his house and the owner turned up to talk him round.
“Mike’s first thought when you put a player in was ‘Will we get our money back?'” he admits.
He left when Rafael Benitez pitched up on Tyneside. “Rafa just wanted to run everything,” he says.

These days his football trips are restricted to Sixfields, where he is a director at Northampton Town. But he’s a regular visitor to son Alan, who he spent the weekend with in the company of Amanda Holden.
Alan is writing a second series of his successful  sitcom, the semi-autobiographical tale of growing up gay in a football mad household in which Graham was depicted by actor Shaun Dooley.
“I met him and the rest of the cast for lunch, he did a great job,” he says. “The second series is when I won the league at Northampton so I’m looking forward to that one.”
But the scout in him is never far from the surface. Before he hangs up he wants to chat Sandro Tonali and his mixed start in black and white and before long he’s selling him to me.
“Good player, good age, short and long range passer. He’ll come good, you know….”

title: Cricket World Cup 2023: Liam Livingstone on Ben Stokes, 2019 memories and why he thinks England can win it
lead: In an exclusive interview with i’s Chris Stocks, Livingstone explains why England aren’t taking anything for granted at the World Cup
author: Chris Stocks

body.text: Players are often insulated in their own bubble, unaware of the hysteria back home when they’re on duty at major tournaments. But Liam Livingstone, a key member of England’s squad for the upcoming Cricket World Cup in India, knows exactly what it’s like.

Asked where he was during England’s epic victory in the 2019 final against New Zealand at Lord’s, Livingstone tells : “I was in a pub in Manchester. I didn’t leave it until it was done. We said we were going to go out to watch the last 20 overs somewhere and obviously when you get stuck somewhere you don’t leave.
“It’s one of them moments you’ll always remember where you were. I don’t think anyone moved when that was going on.

“It was mad actually. I think any sort of sporting event whether it be football or cricket World Cups, the country always gets behind the team. I’ve got a feeling I watched it with [Australia international and Lancashire team-mate] James Faulkner as well. He must have been over as an overseas, so he was cheering on the Kiwis and I was cheering on England. It was a great time for English sport and hopefully we can do something similar this year.”

Three years on from that match at Lord’s, Livingstone had his first taste of a World Cup final for real when he was part of the England team that beat Pakistan to claim the T20 title in Melbourne. It meant England doubled up to become the first country to hold both the men’s Twenty20 and 50-over World Cups at the same time.
That record is on the line in India, where England open the tournament with a rematch of that 2019 final against New Zealand at Ahmedabad on Thursday.
England’s success at major tournaments means 13 of their 15-man squad in India have World Cup winners’ medals – with Gus Atkinson and Reece Topley the odd men out.
Livingstone believes that experience could prove key to the team’s chances of defending their 50-over title.

“It’s huge,” he said. “The experience of 2019 probably helped us last year in 2022 with the lads we had out there. Certainly Stokesy [Ben Stokes], in particular, having played a massive role in 2019, I have no doubt it gave him the clarity to do that in ’22. Like I said, we’ve got a lot of experience in our group, a lot of cricket played under our belts. The lads have got great memories of World Cups, the last two have gone well, so hopefully we can continue that.”
Stokes was key in 2019 in 2022, when he kept alive England’s hopes in both finals with nerveless innings with the bat.

And the 32-year-old’s decision to come out of ODI retirement for this World Cup has been a huge boost to England’s chances. The power of Stokes was on display during the recent series against New Zealand, when he smashed an England ODI record 182 in just 124 balls.

“It’s great,” says Livingstone, who grew up in Cumbria, like Stokes. “Any team with Ben Stokes in it is a better team. Everybody loves having Ben around, it’s not just on the pitch but in the changing room, away from cricket. He’s just a great competitor and I think anybody in the world would have Ben Stokes in their team. It’s a massive boost for us and I’m sure Ben’s looking forward to it.”
Livingstone also enjoyed a good one-day series against New Zealand, with his unbeaten 95 in 78 balls helping England recover from 55 for 5 to win the second ODI in Southampton.
It was a knock that secured his place in England’s XI for the World Cup, where he will be expected to bat at No 6.
Yet it is his spin bowling, and his ability to turn the ball away from both left and right-handed batters, that could prove key in India.

“My bowling is something I really enjoy,” he said. “It’s something very different, more of a challenge than my batting so whether it be with bat, ball or in the field, I’ve got an opportunity to affect the game. That’s what I want to do – win games of cricket for England.”
Livingstone is at pains to point out the value of Indian Premier League experience to England’s chances.
The 30-year-old, who has four IPL campaigns under his belt, says: “I guess having played IPLs, the experience most of our boys have of India will be huge for us.”

Of England’s squad, 14 out of 15 have played in the IPL, with a collective 372 appearances between them. “India’s a very different place to play cricket,” he says. “The conditions are very different to most places around the world. So even just knowing the grounds, how different wickets play is invaluable for us. We’ve got a lot of lads that have played at a lot of different grounds. It’s massive for us. We’ll know conditions. Just the experience of playing a lot of cricket in India will stand us in really good stead.”
As for that opening match at Ahmedabad’s 120,000-capacity Narendra Modi Stadium, Livingstone is taking nothing for granted despite England’s recent 3-1 one-day series win against New Zealand.

“I certainly wouldn’t see them as dark horses,” he says. “They’ve been an incredible international team for a while now. They’ve obviously got some world-class players who compete incredibly well in major tournaments. It’s going to be an incredible opening game – a rerun of the 2019 final, which is a cool one for us.”

So are England the second-favourites for the tournament behind hosts India? “Thankfully it’s not my job to pick out the favourites,” says Livingstone. “But we certainly believe in our own ability. Put it this way, I’d much rather be in the English dressing-room than any other one around the world at the moment. The boys are excited, we’ve got a lot of talent, a lot of experience and most of all we have a lot of fun playing together.”

That talent was evidenced by the late call to replace 2019 World Cup-winning opener Jason Roy in the squad with Harry Brook, the 24-year-old batting superstar who was left out of England’s provisional 15 amid much controversy. “Harry Brook is an incredible talent,” says Livingstone. “He’s probably going to be the best in the world for many years to come. I think there’s going to be a lot of World Cups for Harry. It’s great to have people like him. He’s an incredible talent, I love watching him play.”
Brook is also Livingstone’s rival for the title of biggest hitter in England’s squad. So who can hit the ball further? “Me,” says Livingstone. “If Brooky tells you anything different he’s lying.”
As for trying to defend their title over the next seven weeks, if England do make it to the final in Ahmedabad on 19 November will Livingstone’s mates be watching it in the same Manchester pub?
“Hopefully!” he says.

title: Makeshift England show lack of cohesion before Ollie Watkins saves the day against Australia
lead: Ollie Watkins spared England’s blushes with his third goal for the country as Gareth Southgate’s side edge past Australia 1-0 at Wembley
author: Kevin Garside

body.text: WEMBLEY — A strange night, or strangers in the night? A bit of both, perhaps, at Wembley, where few appeared to learn much of significance from something approximating to a football match. Though England preserved their dignity with a win, Australia were arguably the happier, and certainly the hungrier with a performance a notch or two greater than the Three Lions in terms of energy and purpose.

The evening was understandably overshadowed by the unfolding conflict in the Levant. A minute’s silence seemed insufficient to mark the horrors and suffering inflicted on the region. That said, would flags have carried any more force or weight?

The intractable conflict between Israel and Palestine is way beyond the reach of nations far removed no matter how profound the sentiment expressed. It is enough perhaps to report that the 60-second show of empathy and concern was beautifully observed, which is not always the case in this sporting crucible.

Though Jack Grealish, Trent Alexander-Arnold and James Maddison might quibble at being cast as understudies, none are preferred starters in England’s Hollywood XI, which was benched in its entirety in favour of a Wembley chorus line. Of the starters only Grealish, Alexander-Arnold and Jordan Henderson had more than ten caps.

That might have been considered both risk and insult against an Australian team that made it to the World Cup quarter-finals ten months ago in Qatar. Australia’s footballers are afforded none of the love and affection accorded to the nation’s cricketers or rugby players. As coach Graham Arnold bemoaned beforehand the Socceroos are barely an afterthought, forced to train at the Rugby League Oval.

The contest could never quite rise above the context or setting. A wet Friday at Wembley is no place or time for a match of nil consequence between teams from separate hemispheres, 11,000 miles apart. If we must fill gaps in the schedule, let’s take these games around the country. That might create some intimacy, relax the players a little and attract an engaged audience.

Though both teams went at it, the fixture lacked anything like the intensity required to warm a full house at Wembley. Perhaps Gareth Southgate overplayed the audition card. There was too much inhibition in the opening period, the players overly focused on impressing the gaffer instead of giving instinct its head.
The absence of familiarity didn’t help either. In that regard this was a demonstration of what might happen were you to throw your fantasy team into live action. Too little cohesion or pattern.

The first half was a bit of a trundle leavened by a smattering of goalmouth drama. Sam Johnstone made a decent save to keep out a rasping drive from Keanu Baccus. Ollie Watkins rounded the keeper but could not convert and Lewis Dunk did splendidly to divert Ryan Strain’s shot over the bar to safety.
All games need a goal, but this more than most. It came ten minutes in to the second half, and involved the fun boy three pushing for starting berths.
Its’ beauty lay in the instinctive contributions of the architects. Maddison was clipped making one of his trademark turns.
