For the 2024 Paris Olympics, modern pentathlon will remain in its current form, before the revamp ahead of the 2028 Los Angeles Games.

It prompted soul-searching within the sport’s governing body, the Union Internationale de Pentathlon Moderne (UIPM), which feared it could be removed from the Olympics altogether. Its executive board voted to replace the riding element of the event just three months after the Games in Tokyo.
The news is music to the ears of modern pentathletes all around the world, as well as administrators in the UK who were left fearing for the future if the sport was not readmitted to the Games.
“We receive circa £5.2million from UK Sport each cycle, every four years,” Pentathlon GB chief executive Trafford Wilson tells .

“And if we weren’t in the Olympics, it would be very difficult for them to justify their investment. That investment is critical in terms of funding our coaches, our athletes, getting them to international competitions, all the wraparound services for athletes. That’s arguably 80 to 90 per cent of our business.
“So if that was to disappear, I think modern pentathlon would still exist within Great Britain, but we would be a shell of what we are now.”

Wilson only came into the role last year, some months after the shocking moment at the Tokyo Games, and insists that the publicity it garnered accelerated, rather than triggered, change within pentathlon.
“There have been concerns about the quality of riding within modern pentathlon at prior Olympics,” Wilson adds.
“I believe that [incident] put some pressure on our sport and on the IOC, perhaps indirectly, to look at the riding element and whether there was a change that was necessary.”
That change has been swiftly researched and enacted, although not without some internal dissent.

“It’s fair to say that we’ve had some parts of our membership not wanting to see riding not be involved in the international programme and, on that basis, some resistance to obstacle sport coming in,” Wilson says.

“The feeling was that there will be more support for obstacle course racing than there was with riding and there was an expectation that the sport would change rather than present itself in the same way.

“So we’ve worked really hard on explaining that very point to our members and while I think there are still some members who will be very disappointed of course to see riding come out, I think there’s an overall acceptance that our sport needs to modernise.
“We need to be more inclusive, we need to be more accessible in order for us to stay part of the Olympic programme.”

The modern pentathlon will remain in its original format at the Olympics next year, the last time that showjumping will be included going forward. Instead, the changes to the sport have seen the UIPM introduce an obstacle course that was tested last year and will be fully included after Paris 2024.
At a test event in Ankara last year, the course shared many elements with the  TV show, including monkey bars, spinning wheels, large hurdles, balance beams and a warped wall to run up at the end.

The laser gun element will be combined with the run at the end of the event, with athletes required to shoot at targets 10 metres away with a specially designed laser pistol, a feature introduced ahead of the 2012 Games to increase accessibility in the sport.

The format has already been through the rigour of the Olympic programme commission, a 24-strong committee responsible for analysing sports and upholding “the fundamental core of the Olympic Games” and it is expected that the executive board and IOC sessions will concur with their decision to green-light the new-look sport, which has evolved since but was in fact part of the ancient Olympics in Greece.

Boxing and weightlifting have also had to go through the same process after being stripped of Olympic status since Tokyo 2020 due to governance and doping issues respectively. understands both sports have been told to expect a positive outcome at the session.

The IOC will also rubber-stamp the acceptance of cricket, squash, lacrosse, flag football and baseball/softball for the 2028 Los Angeles Games this weekend, all put forward by the American organisers, but there appears to be no room for breakdancing, one of the new sports at the Paris Olympics.
The event is part of the ongoing effort to modernise the Olympic movement and was well-received at the European Games this summer in Poland, where more than 3,000 people turned out for the final.

But it appears to have lost out in negotiations between LA bosses and the IOC, who are already having to balance the difficulties of 36 sports at one Games, which may mean several core sports being asked to trim their numbers.

title: Fiji have been the best team to watch at the World Cup – why does rugby treat them so badly?
lead: Teams from outside the elite of world rugby continue to struggle financially and tier-one sides won’t even play against them
author: James Gray

body.text: “Everyone’s second-favourite team.”
That was the rather patronising epithet ascribed to Fiji after they were knocked out of the Rugby World Cup on Sunday. They deserved better.

But in truth they would be more than happy to be more people’s second-favourite team, including those in charge of rugby union. Because at present, Fiji, and everything they represent in rugby, are a lot further down the pecking order.

The irony is that it is only these “plucky losers” who make the tournament feasible by providing opposition for the big boys of world rugby. But now that we’ve reached the business end of the World Cup, the established elites can stop pretending to care about Fiji, Tonga, Portugal et al for another four years.

And yet after dispatching the last of what World Rugby might prefer to call “the rest”, Steve Borthwick, coach of an England team whose union turn over £200m a year, was the one claiming the world was against him.
“Let’s not forget this team was written off, and we will be written off again going to Paris,” Borthwick said
“I don’t really care what other people think of us. I care about the development of the team.”
His opposite number Simon Raiwalui does not have the luxury of not caring what other people think. What other people think is what defines Fiji’s future in the game.
“We have to put ourselves in the shop window with our performance and if we’ve got that infrastructure, we’ve got success, consistent success,” Raiwalui said.
“When the opportunity comes up, hopefully we will get a chance, but if we concentrate on the long term, instead of getting the short term right, you tend to trip up on yourself.

“We have to be proud of the last four years, and before that, eight years, what we’ve built in Fiji and I think it’s is there for long term success and sustainability. So if the opportunity does come up, but hopefully we’ve put ourselves in the front of the window.”

Fiji’s pound-for-pound contribution to rugby is probably the greatest of any country, never less true than at this World Cup. Always known for flair and physicality, they have retained those qualities (against England, they recorded 13 dominant tackles, joint-highest of the quarter-finals with Ireland, and 16 offloads) while adding a growing willingness to grind out results that has not always been part of the Fijian gamestyle. In the pool stages, only Japan conceded fewer penalties, and when they beat Australia, there were 17 points from the boot to go with just the one try.

Add to that victory that they were within one dropped pass of a win over Wales and were similarly a bounce of a ball away from shocking England, and in their three games against the elites of world rugby, they won one, and narrowly lost two. Scotland would have done anything for that outcome.

And perhaps if they had been in those situations more often, they would have been able to produce accuracy in those biggest moments. But they have only faced top-level opposition 11 times in the four years since the last World Cup, a fact that surely has to change as a Fiji squad ready to evolve prepares for the next tournament.
“I couldn’t be proud of this group terms of what they’ve put in,” Raiwalui added.
“They’ve built something for the next generation of Fijian rugby players. They’ve laid the foundation there that we can grow.”

World Rugby will point to the introduction of Fijian Drua into Super Rugby, which receives – together with Moana Pasifika – £1.2m of annual funding from World Rugby, as well as direct cash injections into the high performance schemes of the countries involved. But let us just remember those RFU figures: £200m a year in turnover, yet the entire rugby world can only spare £1.2m to make sure it is played professionally by more than 10 countries.
Charles Piutau, a former All Black who now plays for Tonga, says he has learned the difference between the haves and the have-nots since making his debut for the country of his parents last year.
“It’s the lack of resources. We come into the Tonga team and we hardly have any kit, one pair of shorts to train for the week, always having to wash everything every day,” Piutau said.

“We might not have snacks to replenish ourselves after a gym session. Sometimes we might have to cover our own flights to get to training camps. I think sometimes all of those off-field things can add up.
“Before we started in the Rugby World Cup camp, we were struggling to find rugby balls. We were using replicas from the regular shop and it wasn’t the real thing.

“What I have been a part of before with the All Blacks set-up, all you needed to worry about was playing that game and doing your role in that jersey. You could come [to training] naked and end up with enough clothes that you don’t need anything – and get a watch.”

Piutau was talking after a 59-16 defeat to Ireland in Nantes in which his side showed some of their naivety against the world No 1 team. It is hardly a surprise: it was only their fourth clash with a tier-one nation since 2019, and all of those had come in 2019.

“It happens every campaign. We go on three, four-week campaigns and the last game’s always our best game because we’ve had more time together and we’ve played some opposition,” said Toutai Kefu, Tonga’s departing head coach, after their final pool-stage match against South Africa.
His parting shot for World Rugby was an uncomplicated plea for more opportunity and funding.
“There are two simple things: we get to spend more time together, more preparation time, and the other one is playing more competitive games,” Kefu added.

“We play six games a year and maybe one or two tier-one games in that block. What do the tier-one teams play? They play more than 15, 20. It’s hard to compete against teams who are really well-oiled machines.”
There are willing lip-servants in the game to that cause.
“The more opportunities to play in bigger games, the better they’re gonna be,” said Andy Farrell, probably the northern hemisphere’s best coach.
“I know that they speaking to them they would have loved to have tier one nations played in a warm-up game  but that wasn’t to be.”
The phrase “wasn’t to be” doesn’t really cut it in the circumstances: Ireland’s RWC meeting with Tonga was the first time in 20 years that they had come up against them. Why not pick up the phone?

You can tell the same story over and over again too, but just switch out the names: Samoa, Uruguay, Chile and Portugal all produced performances worthy of the global stage in this tournament, but will not feature on it again until 2027.

And you cannot dismiss their claims by pointing out that most did not make it out of the group. This is a seven-week tournament that, were they not there at all, would be half as long and nowhere near as entertaining. Desperate to appear in that “shop window”, they almost all produced historically good performances, like Portugal’s first ever win at a World Cup or Uruguay’s spirited effort against home favourites France in Lille.

And yet World Rugby plans to narrow its focus, rather than broaden it. The “World League”, due to start in 2026, will provide a quadrennial dovetail with the World Cup. Reports state that it will feature the Six Nations teams in one group and the Rugby Championship countries in another, with two “invited guests”, likely to include Japan, making up the numbers.

So that’s one place at the top table for nations who have lit up France with their endeavour and their pride over the last two months, while the rest continue to starve on the measly scraps that the gluttons of England, Ireland, New Zealand and the rest allow to fall to the floor.
With concussion lawsuits and an ever-expanding sports entertainment market, rugby is at a crossroads that will challenge its very existence. It cannot afford to keep ignoring its best assets.

title: Newcastle will reject any Man Utd approach for director of football Dan Ashworth
lead: Man Utd’s incoming minority owner Jim Ratcliffe is an admirer of Ashworth but sources tell i he remains ‘fully invested’ in Newcastle
author: Mark Douglas

body.text: Sir Jim Ratcliffe is expected to assume a “hands on” role in the restructure of Manchester United‘s football department – but any move for Newcastle United director of football Dan Ashworth will be met with fierce resistance at St James’ Park.
United’s board will meet on Thursday morning to vote on proceeding with Ratcliffe’s proposal to take a 25 per cent stake in the club in return for control over its football operations.
No issues are anticipated as the 10-month takeover process finally reaches a conclusion, even if it is one that comes with the contentious prospect of the Glazers remaining in majority control.
“We are in the end game now,” one source close to the process told . But in reality, the hard work starts here for Ratcliffe and his team of football advisors.

Although the INEOS camp are reticent to get drawn on the exact details of the agreement or how much work remains to be done on the structure of the deal, there is an acknowledgement that Ratcliffe has done his homework ahead of becoming a co-owner.
And he has strong ideas about what needs to be done at Old Trafford to make them competitive again.
While faith remains in manager Erik ten Hag despite a downturn in results this season, there are expected to be wholesale changes at executive level.

Ratcliffe’s due diligence on where the Red Devils are falling behind will have identified recruitment as a major failing and the spotlight will undoubtedly fall on director of football John Murtough and chief executive Richard Arnold.
The squad looks unbalanced and disjointed, the result of several different managers being backed expensively in the transfer market.

Worse still, many of those no longer in favour are on long contracts that interested clubs are not prepared to match. Ratcliffe himself accused the club of being the “dumb money” in 2019 and in truth little has changed since then.
A proposed restructure of football operations is one potential solution with a new director of football possible.
Likely candidates include Paul Mitchell, who has recently left Monaco and is based in Manchester, and former Liverpool sporting director Michael Edwards.

And Ratcliffe has been greatly impressed by the work done by Ashworth, who has overseen the second phase of Newcastle’s development after their 2021 takeover by the Saudi Arabia Public Investment Fund.

Any approach would most likely fail,  understands. The Magpies no longer see themselves as a stepping stone club and in addition to huge compensation that any rival would need to pay to poach Ashworth, there is confidence he would not be interested in leaving Newcastle at such an important stage in their development.
Indeed  understands that Ashworth is committed to his role in the North East and is “fully invested” in a sporting project that aims to secure the club a place in Europe’s elite.
Although Newcastle are playing Champions League football this season they remain – in relative terms – in the early stages of the club’s transformation.

Ashworth is engaged in a huge and well-financed restructure of Newcastle’s football operations, including a total overhaul of scouting systems and the integration of a new data department into decision-making.

He is also putting a new overseas scouting network into place. As Informfully reported last week, a new partnership with Northern Irish side Larne FC is a model the club are looking to replicate in other countries.

It is typical of the sort of challenges Ratcliffe and INEOS are set to face when they finally get the keys to Old Trafford. There are no easy wins and a pack of well-funded, smart rivals who have overtaken United in recent years are not likely to take any approaches for key men lying down.

title: Lincoln City: A club embracing its reality instead of dreaming about fairytales
lead: At Lincoln, Saturday afternoons are not the most important bit. CEO Liam Scully speaks to Daniel Storey about a club at one with its city
author: Daniel Storey

body.text: LINCOLN — I have arrived in Lincoln on an opportune day. This evening, they will host West Ham United in the Carabao Cup and the city has been talking about little else since the draw. Lincoln knows the magic of a cup run more than most. In 2017, they became the first non-league team to reach the FA Cup quarter-finals in over a century. The chairman, South African Clive Nates, was here in early September and, three weeks later, has flown back again. You don’t miss these nights.

If 2017 was a high watermark, you might argue that things have got much better since. Later that year, Lincoln won the National League title and, two years later, did the same in League Two. They are enjoying their fifth straight season in the third tier, their most since the mid-1980s.

There is always ambition – and occasionally impatience – from some supporters to strive for better. But Lincoln City are in a good place. They have signed one player for more than £100,000 in the last decade. They have one of the youngest squads in English professional football, with no player contracted over the age of 29. Over the last eight years, home attendances have more than tripled. That brings money to the club and the club closer to its city.

“We have a clear identity and a clear recruitment strategy,” says CEO Liam Scully. We are meeting in his office alongside Nates with the door closed on feverish pre-match activity. For nights like these, lower-league clubs seem to operate on triple speed as the circus rolls into town. They wouldn’t have it any other way.

“The thing that drives what we do every day is what we call win-develop. That’s in equal measures. We have to win, to keep people engaged and to drive enjoyment. We can’t be romantic and just concentrate on development and assume that the results will take care of themselves.

“Equally, we will have to trade our way through the football pyramid. So while the board and investors will back us, we have to evidence to them that we can bring players in, develop them, receive the benefit of them and then accept that they will move on in time.
“There have been many times over the last few years when we have had the youngest squad in the Football League.”

“At every professional football club, including [in] the Premier League, the great misconception is that the Saturday afternoon is the important bit. Of course it makes a difference, ultimately determining how much money is generated and therefore spent. None of us would be here without the starting XI.”

But a club’s importance to its community is best seen on any other day. It involves the work done by countless unheralded people to bring a football club closer to the bosom of its community and the community within the walls – literal and metaphorical – of the club. At its best, those elements dovetail.

Scully mentions something key here: tangible markers of progress. If Lincoln sell a player, they won’t necessarily simply buy a replacement – they will build something. The training ground, stadium facilities have undergone extensive work. More is planned and needed. All of it is for one reason: building a sense of community.

“This is a place where people gather. It’s similar to religion,” says Scully. “Being a place where people can be themselves, get out of the house, experience being part of a group – it’s all of that. The direct impact of a matchday is huge, but it’s the indirect impact that we can have through the work of our Foundation or wider community strategies. It’s not just improving lives – at times it’s changing and saving lives.”

“This week we buried one of our lifelong fans,” says Nates. “She was 91. She was a volunteer for years and years at the club. I’ve been a fan of English football, from South Africa, for many years. I’ve had bad weekends messed up because of their results. But it’s a different thing entirely when you come and you know somebody who lives down the road and understands what the club means to people like that.

“As a custodian, you can only look at people like that and know that you have to do the best you can. You don’t need to go to the EFL offices in London or Preston – you just need to talk to supporters like that to see what a club means. That is who it is all for.”

This is not an easy time to run an EFL club. Three years into his job, Scully was forced to push Lincoln City into survival mode as Covid-19 hit. He concedes that getting to the end of the month to pay the bills was the only short-term aim and, later in our interview, both Scully and Nates freely discuss the need for greater financial redistribution from English football’s financial elite if the pyramid is going to thrive in its current form.

It’s also harder than ever for supporters to demonstrate their loyalty in a tangible way: match tickets and replica shirts are a luxury during a cost-of-living and fuel crisis. But Lincoln’s attendances are good and the connection with the local community was reinforced by the extra connections made during the pandemic.

“What we always have to be careful of is that it’s not about extracting a pound from somebody,” Scully says. “It has to be more meaningful than that. We have to operate with transparency. That’s not because we expect everybody to agree with every decision that we make. It’s to explain and provide the context for decisions so that people can at least understand that we aren’t being blasé – we have thought about this and you.

“If I’m here for 10 or 15 years, that might sound like a long time in employment terms. But in the history of this club, it’s a mere dot. It has been through some turbulent times. We want to provide a level of consistency that supporters can trust. The fans here have had a rollercoaster over the last 130 years. It would be nice if we could provide them with some stability during our tenure here.”

Stability and sustainability might not strike as the sexiest terms, but in lower-league they are the oxygen. Being mid-table in League One might not be everyone’s idea of heaven, but 20 years ago Lincoln were close to going bust and they know the reality of non-league only too well. Losing to West Ham’s scrappy goal means that there will be no fairytale cup run this season. But then Lincoln are more than content to live their own reality for a while.

title: No Ben Stokes and too much golf: What’s gone wrong for England at the Cricket World Cup
lead: England are staring down the barrel of their most humiliating World Cup exit to date following defeats to New Zealand and Afghanistan
author: Chris Stocks

body.text: England‘s hopes of defending the Cricket World Cup are hanging by a thread after Afghanistan caused one of the biggest shocks in the tournament’s history.
Afghanistan set England a target of 285 after taking advantage of some loose bowling at the death, before Jos Buttler‘s men were bowled out for a mere 215.
The loss has left England in danger of missing out on the semi-finals and comes ahead of them having to face South Africa in Mumbai on 21 October.
Chris Stocks takes a look at where it has all gone wrong after such a disappointing start to the campaign.

From the moment Ben Stokes came out of retirement in August, England’s World Cup build-up was overshadowed by off-field issues. The news on Stokes, who had retired from ODIs in the summer of 2022, was good. But his selection forced Harry Brook out of the initial squad for the tournament in India.

That precipitated a weeks-long discussion about why the best young batter in the world could be overlooked for the World Cup. It proved a massive distraction and inevitably Brook scored serious runs in the T20 series against New Zealand that followed and was on the plane to India when Jason Roy’s back injury flared up again. Brook then ended up playing when Stokes picked up a hip injury and was ruled out of the start of the tournament – another huge talking point and yet another distraction.

The Jofra Archer soap opera hasn’t helped either, the fast bowler named as a reserve who could only play towards the back end of the World Cup and who will only arrive in India this week. He’s not near match fitness either but the narrative around Archer, one of the heroes of the 2019 World Cup win, isn’t helpful.

India is an unforgiving place to tour with conditions markedly different from the UK. The three ODIs against New Zealand in September were England’s first for six months and of little value in terms of preparing for India.

Having the first of two warm-up matches rained off once they arrived in the country didn’t help, with a sole match against Bangladesh the only run out in Indian conditions before England got their tournament underway. Fail to prepare and prepare to fail as the saying goes.

England’s players love a round of golf or five. Most spent the days leading into the Afghanistan match dragging their clubs around the DLF Country Club on the outskirts of Delhi where the course was designed by Gary Player.
Touring life is hard and the players deserve to unwind away from cricket.
But maybe if the players worked as hard on training as they do on their handicaps they wouldn’t be in this mess.

There’s no danger of naughty boy nets in Mumbai this week either given there is another golf day on Tuesday – a social fixture that has caused coach Matthew Mott’s long-awaited first press conference of the tour to be delayed until 5.30pm local time.

Somewhere along the line England have lost the aggressive intent that was the hallmark of their white-ball revival under former captain Eoin Morgan following their first-round exit from the 2015 World Cup in Australia and New Zealand.
There were moments before this tournament, namely during their defeat by Ireland in last year’s T20 World Cup in Australia and during the recent home ODI series against New Zealand.
But in India their defeats by New Zealand and Afghanistan have been characterised by uncharacteristic passive batting. On Sunday, not one player was caught in the deep.
This is reminiscent of England before the white-ball revolution and the buck stops with Mott and Buttler. They need to regain that no-fear approach or they will perish in this tournament.

The lack of aggressive intent can be linked to both Mott and Buttler. One dressing-room source has told  that Mott is very much a backseat driver and not one to lay down the law. Buttler by his very nature is never going to give Churchillian speeches or dressing-room dressing downs.
It’s telling that it was Stokes who spoke up in the dressing room after that Ireland upset in the T20 World Cup in Melbourne last year. The fact he has not played in India has surely had an effect.

Are England suffering from a lack of firm leadership? The results so far here would suggest as much and you cannot blame them for suffering from the loss of Morgan, whose iron-will and determination filtered down through the squad.

title: Jim Ratcliffe has no magic wand to fix Man Utd – but he differs from Glazers in one key way
lead: Already there is talk of Ratcliffe upgrading the technical department, starting with a new sporting director, rumoured to be Paul Mitchell
author: Kevin Garside

body.text: Manchester, the city of romance. Sir Jim Ratcliffe represents a first strike against the despised ownership of Manchester United by the Glazer family. One small step for Ratcliffe, one giant leap for supporters yearning for an end to an association with American owners spanning 18 years.

To what degree Ratcliffe might shape United’s destiny will be contained in the detail. Assuming Britain’s richest man has not lost his marbles, there must be some upside for shelling £1.4bn for a 25 per cent stake, which was twice the market value when the deal was agreed, a little less after the share price dropped on Monday morning.

The euphoria over Ratcliffe’s involvement is understandable across the United diaspora, which has seen its place in the order of things eroded in the decade since the end of empire. Whilst the deal sees one commercial player acquire shares from another, it is on balance a better option than being subsumed by the state apparatus of another expansionist royal family from the Middle East scarred by a toxic human rights record.
Moreover, since the independence of the mysterious Sheikh Jassim bin Hamad al Thani from the ruling Qatari regime was hard to establish, an unwanted layer of duplicity has been avoided.

The nature of the proposed deal arrived at with Ratcliffe demonstrates how the club was always about profit and not glory for the Glazers, an admission that they had no sense of the emotional contract with the fans once central to football ownership.

That Ratcliffe does understand that emotional connection is his big selling point among the fans. And though he is, first and foremost, a man of commerce, it is in this wider understanding of the culture of United that hope resides.

Ratcliffe hails from Failsworth, a satellite barrio along the main artery from Manchester north east to Oldham, a route that connected the commercial centre of cotton manufacture to the industrial bits where cloth was made. He is, therefore, immersed in United lore.

The wise men unpicking the details of the deal advise that the six members of the Glazer family own 67 per cent of the club, whilst a third is in the hands of myriad financial investors. However the division of shares into Class A and B gives them 95 per cent of the voting rights.

Only Class A shares are traded on the stock exchange. Class B shares can only be traded between Glazer affiliates, presumed to be family members. It is in Class B shares, which carry ten times the voting rights of Class A shares, that power resides and which the Ratcliffe bid is targeting.

How he achieves that will come to light when the vote by 12 board members on Thursday rubber stamp his offer. The assumption is the Glazers will authorise a rule change to permit the transfer of Class B goods. Acquiring control of football operations is ultimately the mechanism by which to achieve the absolute removal of the Glazers. It would appear this will happen incrementally, with Ratcliffe taking an ever-increasing share of the club over an agreed period.

That in itself will not be enough to restore United to the summit of the game. The fans understand this but are investing in Ratcliffe’s sensitivity to the primacy of the team in driving the business, born of a romantic connection that the Glazers never had.

Already there is talk of Ratcliffe upgrading the technical department, starting with a new sporting director, rumoured to be Paul Mitchell, ex of Southampton, Tottenham Hotspur, RB Leipzig and latterly Monaco. Infrastructure improvements to a leaky Old Trafford and an outdated Carrington training complex, are also part of the dreamscape.

Ownership is only ever an issue when times are bad, of course. In the first eight years of Glazer control United won five Premier League titles and appeared in three Champions League finals, winning one and losing two to peak Barcelona. There were no green and gold protests then.
Subsequent events revealed them to be the speculators they always were, the nature of their ownership geared only to returning profit not trophies.

The game has changed since the Glazers assumed control in 2005, an acquisition sandwiched between the purchase in 2003 of Chelsea by Roman Abramovic and of Manchester City in 2008 by the Abu Dhabi royal family, transactions which flooded the football market with unaccountable billions.

Neither Chelsea nor City had to take account of the bottom line. United were about little else, debt payments on borrowings now approaching £1bn coming from profits once the envy of other clubs. Even in that domain United are now threatened by City.

In addition to his ownership of the Ineos Grenadiers cycling squad and his shares in the Mercedes F1 team, Ratcliffe has a football portfolio that includes FC Lausanne in Switzerland and OGC Nice of France.
In none of these associations has Ratcliffe proved to be the alchemist of sporting dreams. But hope costs nothing, and any move that lessens the Glazers’ hold on Old Trafford is manna in Manchester.

title: Who will England play in Rugby World Cup 2023 semi-finals? Opponents, fixture schedule and route to final
lead: England are two games from glory after a tense victory over Fiji
author: Katherine Lucas

body.text: Underestimated before the tournament had even started, England now stand one game away from another World Cup final after a pulsating 30-24 victory over Fiji.

The quibbles with their style will remain; glamour has fallen to grit over the past four weeks. The final throes were a case of digging in and for all the questions over whether he would start, it was an Owen Farrell drop goal and penalty that finally tipped the quarter-final in England’s favour.

Fiji, who will be remembered as everyone’s second team out in France, were in need of a converted try in the last seconds but fell short. Where they did not disappoint, however, was in their willingness to take the game to England, from Viliame Mata’s audacious try to the moment Vilimoni Botitu put them on level terms and for a brief moment, allowed Fijians to dream.
“This is a different Fiji team and it’s the start of something special. I couldn’t be prouder of the group,” coach Simon Raiwalui told “They wanted to create a new identity, they’ve done that.”

Instead it is Steve Borthwick’s side who head into the semis. That will be accompanied by a sense of relief having witnessed Wales’ shock exit at the hands of Argentina and Ireland losing a thriller to New Zealand on Saturday.

Borthwick revelled in the number of people he said had written his men off, many of whom did not even believe they would get out of their group. They have defied expectations again – though the real tests are just around the corner.
Farrell hailed a “controlled performance”, but admitted “there is plenty we can do better” having let a 24-10 lead slip in the second half.
“But you see the power of the Fijian team,” Farrell added. “They were a man down but it was a tough, tough battle.
“People talk about the changes, about people being in the starting team. It’s just a role change. Everyone from one to 33 has a massive role to play and that will continue.”

England will face a sterner test in the last four, where they will take on  – the side who beat them in the final four years ago. The Springboks claimed their place with a 29-28 victory over hosts France.
England are the undisputed underdogs but that is a mindset Borthwick is encouraging them to embrace.
Should England reach the final, they will play the winner of vs . That quarter-final is on Friday 20 October.
All the semi-finals will be shown live on ITV and can be streamed online via ITVX.

title: How unfancied England became World Cup semi-finalists after solving their biggest problem
lead: Owen Farrell has been shifted around England’s backline but was influential as a No 10 during the quarter-final win over Fiji
author: Hugh Godwin

body.text: Johnny Sexton, Antoine Dupont, Finn Russell… they are all bystanders now. Waisea Nayacalevu, Levani Botia and their fellow Fijians? They too are out of the World Cup, taking with them the love of a global rugby viewership and a burning sense of frustration at perceived refereeing bias.

And England? They now march on behind their captain Owen Farrell to Paris for the semi-finals, to a city they have so far only glimpsed from the air, jetting up and down from their northern base camp of Le Touquet during the pool stage. They overcame Argentina and Japan in Marseille and Nice, then Samoa and Chile in Lille, before squeezing past Fiji in Sunday’s breathless quarter-final back in Marseille.
The results tell us England are a World Cup team. Winners just once, yes, in 2003, but now into their sixth semi-final in the 10 editions of the tournament.

On the downside, those historical results also point to them eventually being knocked over by a stronger team, and most pundits this week will heavily favour England’s next opponents South Africa, but it is clear Steve Borthwick is utterly uninterested in entertaining other people’s narratives.

When the England head coach was invited to consider the mantle of underdogs after the switchback 30-24 defeat of the Fijians, which very nearly turned this campaign to stone and Borthwick’s short reign to toast, the implacable Cumbrian stuck to his script of the team getting better each week, and benefiting from Farrell’s leadership.
Across the 2019 World Cup in Japan, and this one in France, the team skippered by Farrell in both competitions has lost once in 11 matches, and that was the 2019 final to South Africa.
Something about the redoubtable Wiganer – who has 110 caps and a recently-minted record as his country’s all-time top points scorer – works for England.

They will now clash again with the Springboks, who also beat them in the 2007 final, and England supporters are no doubt scrambling to the resale sites to snap up tickets offered by their teary counterparts from Ireland, France, Scotland, Wales, Australia and the others who have not made it this far.

Everyone knew the draw made in 2020 for a competition three years later had delivered two distinctly different paths through: a kind one that has worked well for England and Argentina, and a cruel one that has seen New Zealand and the South Africans emerge as first among equals from Pools A and B.

England came here lacking the form to sail through without severe wobbles at the hands of middling opposition – a single point was the margin against Samoa, while it took a late drop goal and penalty by Farrell to do the job against Fiji, whose two dramatic tries to fight back from 24-10 to 24-24 with 12 minutes to go will live long in the memory.

If we are analysing what has worked for England, it looked like discipline might be a problem when red cards disrupted their build-up, and Tom Curry was sent off two minutes into the opening win over Argentina.

Instead that has been their only card, red or yellow, and they have been averaging the third-fewest penalties conceded per match; the tally is under 10 which has always been the benchmark of acceptability.
Ben Earl has played a team-leading 333 minutes for England and has proved a valuable release valve with his pace and ability to turn messy possession into an attacking launchpad.

As for Farrell, it is strange to note he has started in his favourite position of fly-half just five times in his 13 World Cup matches across three tournaments, and only twice in a knock-out game: the win over Australia in the 2019 quarter-finals, and now Fiji.
Even so, Borthwick has handed him the No 10 jersey almost constantly this year, and will now be expected to do so again in the semi-final.

There is an app for most things these days and it would be handy if someone clever could precisely map the source of, and reasons for, the boos for Farrell’s face on the big screens in Marseilles pre-match.

England’s attack coach Richard Wigglesworth, a former club-mate of Farrell’s, railed against the doubters, saying on Monday morning: “We are lucky to have him. As ever, [the] tallest trees catch the most wind, and he seems to catch a fair bit of it. [He is] proven time and time and time again, and I don’t understand why in England we feel the need to not celebrate that, not enjoy it, just because he is not sat in front of social media or media lapping all that up.
“He was brilliant for us, as we knew he would be. That was the maddening part of any noise – we knew what was coming.”
The on-field data shows England have led the World Cup averages for the most kicks in play, most box-kicks and most mid-field bombs.

Their use of the boot worked okay in the Fiji win, with a box-kick by scrum-half Alex Mitchell leading to the opening try by Manu Tuilagi, and another box-kick and a grubber to Farrell’s penalty for that 24-10 lead.
These straightforward plays now face the test for the first time of England meeting a higher-ranked team in the Springboks’ reigning champions.

One intriguing call will be whether Freddie Steward returns at full-back. Marcus Smith became the focus of the photographers’ lenses on Sunday when his nose was splattered into a bloody mess in an accidental clash with Vinaya Habosi, and the Harlequin who would prefer to be a fly-half than a full-back took a cut to the back of the head too.
Pre-match, Smith wore gold headphones as he paced the Marseilles pitch, blocking the outside world as he examined his lines of sight from the halfway line, 22-metre line and so on.

Once the action had begun, and with each amazing twist and turn your ears buzzed with the roars of the crowd, Smith was out of position for a Fijian line-kick, then bounced off by Semi Radradra, then goose-stepped into conceding a penalty – all contributions that may have been privately frowned on by Borthwick, although for public consumption the coach said: “Not many people talk about his [Smith’s] defence. It was magnificent tonight.”

Smith also showed frustration when he made a forceful point to Curry before giving the flanker a conciliatory hug. Neither man is having the World Cup they may have expected, and we now wait to see which roles they play under the Saturday night lights at Stade de France.

But England are there, as the sole survivors from the Six Nations contingent, and while logic and form suggest it may be journey’s end, Borthwick, Farrell and company are not the types to give up without a fight.

title: Why Maro Itoje and Joe Marchant are key to England beating South Africa
lead: South Africa’s 29-28 win over France shows they have few weaknesses, but this is how England can exploit the reigning world champions
author: Louis Doré

body.text: While Steve Borthwick pores over the footage of South Africa’s 29-28 victory over Rugby World Cup hosts France, looking for a gap in the armour, he may be rather dismayed at the extent of its coverage.
The World Champion Springboks looked a well-rounded, imposing side in their narrow victory over the home team in Paris who had been widely backed to go to the whole way in the tournament.

A reminder of the formidable qualities the Boks possess had been overdue after a 13-8 pool stage loss to Ireland in which they seemed a little less on-song, but this was a performance which suggested they’d sealed up the weaknesses the Irish had temporarily exposed too.

The Boks had a point to prove with their scrum on Saturday. It had been less than dominant against Andy Farrell’s side, but was a notable point of strength against France. They won seven out of eight on their own put-in won, nobbling four of France’s nine.

They felt so much in the ascendancy in that part of the game that at one point full back Damian Willemse opted for a scrum in his 22 after calling a mark – an option casual fans may even have forgotten is available to a side such is the frequency with which a clearance kick to touch is deployed. The Boks won a scrum penalty from that mark, by the way.
England’s scrum is by no means poor, but they will have to be on their game and clever in their communication with the referee to defuse the famed ‘bomb squad’.

Borthwick can also draw some element of predictability from their lineout – albeit with a pinch of salt. The Boks almost never throw to the back, presumably because sending RG Snyman up in the middle or front rarely results in a turnover.

If Maro Itoje is truly back to his disruptive, combative best as he claims, there may be some fruit to pick there. That said, the excellent French second row Cameron Woki didn’t manage to overwhelm the Springbok line, so the challenge is evidently fearsome.

When it comes to defence, England have a large problem. For the last year, England haven’t looked a side particularly potent at getting around an organised rush with ease, and looked a tad predictable about kicking behind it – though it must be said in recent matches there has been more variation there.
Matthieu Jalibert and Antoine Dupont reaped some rewards with a little chip over the top of the defence between front line and full-back – the sort of which Joe Marchant is excellent at chasing.

The problem England have is that the man recovering the kick is often Cheslin Kolbe, who was in simply electric form on Saturday. Two clean breaks and four defenders beaten, with a try and a charged-down conversion. That suggests he is a fast and agile man to whom one should maybe not give the ball in broken play.

Another ominous point was how the Boks responded to a France line break or half-break. The Springboks cover defence against France was simply immense. Only 12 missed tackles in a match against France is, in a word, astonishing.

In the words of head coach Jacques Nienaber: “We were broken up defensively, we were opened up a couple of times. But the amount of work rate and scramble and effort that the players put in was enormous.”

Captain Siya Kolisi added: “We scrambled a lot and we scrambled hard, especially when we were short of numbers. We talk about chasing lost causes as a group, and you don’t give up until they put the ball down on the tryline.”
England will need to be clinical when they get a half-break, because the Springboks have shown when they shut the door on you, they shut it hard.

Then to top it all off, they bring on the likes of Kwagga Smith. In five minutes he made two turnovers, effectively sealing the win for the Springboks. He has six in this tournament despite mostly operating from the bench.
When the play is broken late in the game and legs are tired, England need to be keenly aware of getting isolated in attack around Smith, who can end the game all on his own.

In attack, the Boks were adaptable and pacey. They were as comfortable relying on set-piece as forcing a high-tempo attacking game through the hands, as they were pumping high balls into the channel for the likes of Kolbe to rise high and catch for yardage.

When they brought on Faf de Klerk and Handre Pollard, they both calmed the game down and the latter looked impressively on-pace despite his long injury lay-off. This is a side that can play a number of ways to defeat a foe.

All in all there are no obvious weaknesses to exploit in a team that showed the fortitude to face down the tournament favourites in their back yard, in front of nearly 80,000 fans all bellowing to the referee to sway him.
Over to you, Steve Borthwick.

title: Triple lock will become redundant if Tories fudge state pension rise, says ex-minister
lead: Under the Triple Lock commitment, the State Pension is set to increase by 8.5 per cent in April, in line with wage growth figures
author: Callum Mason

body.text: The government’s triple lock commitment would “not be worth the paper it’s written on” if ministers do not up the State Pension by 8.5 per cent in April after summer wage growth was confirmed at this level, a former pensions minister has said.

Under its triple lock commitment, the government increases the State Pension each April by the highest of the Consumer Prices Index (CPI) level of inflation for the previous September, wage growth for the previous May-July or 2.5 per cent.
Wage growth in the period July-August was provisionally calculated as being 8.5 per cent back in September, and this figure has now been confirmed by the Office for National Statistics (ONS).

This is almost certain to be the highest of the three triple lock factors, with September’s inflation figure set to be confirmed as around 6.5 per cent tomorrow, and so Sir Steve Webb, the former minister behind the triple lock commitment, has said the government “has no choice” but to up the State Pension by this amount, if it wants to be seen as meeting its commitment.

There have been reports that ministers were considering adjusting the wage growth figure to strip out the impact of public sector bonuses on the earnings figure, which could mean an increase of around 7.8 per cent instead, but Sir Steve, who is now a partner at Lane Clark and Peacock, said this would be “fiddling the figures.”

“In any given year there are one off factors that determine exactly the level of wage growth. If every time the formula gives you the wrong answer you change it to give answer you want, then that commitment is not worth the paper it is written on,” he told .
“I really think the fact it has been broken once this parliament [when pay growth surged after the Covid pandemic] makes it very important that the commitment is kept this time.

“It’ll be damaging for their credibility if they don’t – the biggest predictor for voting is age and their Conservatives are down to their core vote now. If they don’t meet the commitment, a lot of those voters are not going to be very happy. Anything that looked like fiddling the figures would do far more political damage in my view that the benefit to them fiscally of using a lower number,” he said.
And he added that he expected the Government would meet the commitment, given this could be the final chance to do so before a possible General Election next autumn.

The new state pension, currently £203.85 per week, would rise to £221.20 in April if it went up by 8.5 per cent, while the basic state pension, currently £156.20 and paid to men born before 6 April 1951 and women born before 6 April 1953, would go up to £169.50.
The increase comes on top of the 10.1 per cent rise in April 2023 when the pension rise reflected the high level of inflation the previous year.
The cost of an 8.5 per cent increase to the Treasury would be more than £8 billion.

But Sir Steve added: “It is worth remembering that the UK still has one of the lowest state pensions in the Western World and there is some way to go before the value of the pension recovers from a thirty year period when it was linked only to price inflation.”
Inflation data for September, released tomorrow, could also determine the increase to benefits from April.
The figure is expected to be around 6.5 per cent, but the government has not yet confirmed whether or not it will uprate benefits – such as Universal Credit – in line with this figure.

A government spokesperson told  this weekend: “As is the usual process, the Secretary of State will conduct his statutory annual review of benefits and State Pensions in the Autumn, using the most recent data available.”

title: UK inflation rate to fall to 6.5%: What it means for your mortgage, savings, and  benefits
lead: Inflation has been falling steadily since the end of 2022 according to official figures
author: Callum Mason

body.text: The Office for National Statistics (ONS) is expected to announced tomorrow that inflation fell slightly last month, giving some  relief to those hit by the cost of living crisis and spiraling mortgage rates, and strengthening the view that interest rates will stay put.
The ONS will publish figures on Wednesday detailing how the average prices of goods and services changed last month.
The Consumer Prices Index (CPI), the official rate of inflation compiled by the ONS, has been falling steadily since the end of 2022, when it peaked at 11.1 per cent. By August it was 6.7 per cent.
Forecasters are expecting a slight fall again this month, with S&P Global Markets estimating it will nudge down to 6.5 per cent, and Deutsche Bank Research suggesting a rate of about 6.6 per cent.
S&P Global has said that continued deceleration in food price inflation will likely have contributed to the fall, and a spike in global oil prices will have prevented this fall being more dramatic.
Here’s what the falling rate means for you and your money.
Inflation is one of the main factors that influences whether the Bank of England chooses to raise or lower the base rate, which determines how expensive our mortgages are.
The base rate currently sits at 5.25 per cent, after the Bank opted to hold rates in its September meeting for the first time in more than 18 months.
The Bank generally raises rates to combat inflation. The logic is that if borrowing is more expensive, then people have less money to spend, and so there is less demand for goods and services.
After the recent hold, forecasters have suggested that, bar major surprises in inflation figures, rates should hold at their current level for now.

Ashley Webb, economist at Capital Economics, told : “We still think interest rates are at their peak. That said, as we expect core inflation to fall only slowly, we think the Bank will keep rates at their peak until late in 2024.”

One thing that will give the Bank of England food for thought though is the high wage growth rate. Officials figures suggest that average weekly earnings, excluding bonuses, grew by 7.8 per cent in the three months to August – a higher rate than inflation.

Paula Bejarano Carbo, associate economist at NIESR, explained: “On the one hand, this is positive in that it implies that workers in both the public and private sectors are seeing real average pay increases in for the first time in roughly two years; on the other hand, elevated wage growth continues to challenge monetary policymakers’ efforts to tame inflation.”
Mortgages are not directly affected by inflation, although many products are affected by the Bank of England’s base rate, which inflation influences.
Fixed-rate products are not immediately affected by any change in interest rates, although they do go up or down based on long-term predictions of where interest rates will go.

These mortgages – generally the cheapest – are already slowly falling, as banks and other lenders have forecast that rates are at their peak, and there is a small “rate war” between lenders to attract business after a slow property market in the first part of this year meant many were behind target for deals secured. If inflation falls steadily as expected, then this will likely continue.

Rates of below 5 per cent have returned to the market recently – Halifax launched a five-year deal at 4.73 per cent last week. Nick Mendes, mortgage technical manager at John Charcol brokers has said that we could see a return to five-year fixes of under 4.5 per cent by the end of the month on current trajectories.

Elliott Culley, director at Switch Mortgage Finance said lenders would be trying “to get as much business in as possible before the end of the year” and that the mortgage market was “likely to remain competitive” in the short term.
Peter Stamford, director at Moor Mortgages, said that if inflation dipped “we could see rates inching down as lenders hustle for year-end business.”

Inflation is bad news for savers as it erodes the value of money held in the bank. Even though the best paying easy access accounts are offering 5 per cent or more, inflation is still higher – meaning your savings are effectively worth less each year, comparatively speaking, even with the interest added.

The best two easy-access accounts are from Ulster Bank and Coventry Building Society, which each pay 5.2 per cent. You can get more money if you lock away your cash in a fixed-rate account. Ahli United Bank UK via Raisin has a one-year fixed account paying 6.1 per cent, but if you open this now you won’t be able to touch the money until October 2024.
Anna Bowes, founder of Savings Champion, has previously noted that falling inflation can help “mitigate” against this to an extent if interest on savings accounts stays the same.
September’s CPI figure is also typically used as the figure to uprate working-age benefits such as Jobseeker’s Allowance next April.
This is not guaranteed, and on various occasions in the past decade, the government had opted for lower increases.
Whether it does so this time will likely be announced in next month’s Autumn Statement.
Though Chancellor Jeremy Hunt has been warned that freezing benefits would result in more children being pushed into poverty.
So inflation nudging down is good news in this sense, though it’s set to be a relatively small change.
While inflation is a measure of price rises, it accounts for a wide range of goods and services – including petrol, insurance and other varying costs – and does not affect them all equally.

Food inflation has been running higher than average price rises, however. In August’s ONS data it stands at 13.6 per cent. This is expected to be lower in this week’s reading, partly due to lower production costs filtering through to consumers.

And there is hope inflation could fall further, as today it was revealed that prices charged by food and drink manufacturers fell last month at the fastest rate in over three years, according to the Lloyds Bank UK Sector Tracker.

Different foods are going up or down in price at different rates though. For example, data from the Office for National Statistics shows that the price of sugar increased more than 55 per cent between August 2022 and August 2023, while the price of butter went down by 3.2 per cent.
Although food inflation has been falling in recent months, this does not mean food prices are decreasing. It just means they are increasing in price at a slower rate than before.
That means that the prices you see on supermarket shelves are unlikely to fall any time soon – at least, not just because inflation is falling.

As with savings, higher inflation is generally bad news for people with pensions – or those currently saving for one – as it reduces the true spending power of their pots. If inflation is falling, that means that this effect is lessened.

For example, if you are 67 and plan to retire in a year, assuming you have a pot of £87,500 in today’s money – roughly the average someone older than 50 will have by retirement, according to Pension Bee – then one year later, if inflation runs at 10 per cent, and your investment growth is 5 per cent, your pot would be worth £91,263.
But in real terms, your pot would be worth the equivalent of £83,650, adjusted for today’s money.
However, there is a secondary effect of higher inflation. September’s CPI figure can be used to determine the State Pension increase for next year – although this is unlikely this time around.

Under the government’s Triple Lock policy, the State pension is increased in line with the highest of three measures – a flat 2.5 per cent rise, average earnings growth measured from May to July each year, and inflation measured in the year from September.
But inflation is set to be far lower than the average earnings metric – which was 8.3 per cent – and so this earnings figure will supersede the inflation reading.

title: How much you now have to earn to pay off student loan in full
lead: People’s student loans vary massively depending on where in the country they are from, how many years of study they complete and the amount they borrow to cover their living costs
author: Callum Mason

body.text: More and more graduates are earning enough to have to pay back their student loans – as data released this week expected to show that wages have risen again, despite the earnings threshold at which borrowers start to make repayments staying frozen.

Those from England going to university this year face paying off their student loans until their 60s, because of changes to the higher education finance system. The salary threshold – above which students pay 9 per cent of earnings towards their loan – will be dropped from £27,295 to £25,000 – and the length of the loans will be extended from 30 to 40 years, after which the balance will be written off.

And though the minimum threshold for paying off your loan – previously seen as a safety net preventing low-earning graduates from hefty repayments – has risen in previous years along with average earnings, under current government plans, it will be held at £25,000 until 2027. The threshold for older graduates is also currently frozen.

Wage growth has outstripped inflation in recent months, and data this week is expected to show they have risen further. So many see the freeze as a stealth tax rise, meaning more and more graduates are likely to have to make repayments and sacrifice a chunk of their wages to the taxman.
Students loans do not operate like normal loans. They’re often seen as more like a tax because many do not pay them off in full and you only have to do so if your wages reach a certain level.
But how much do you really have to earn throughout your life to clear the loan before the government stops your repayments and wipes the remaining debt?

With ever-changing rules and unpredictable inflation, putting an exact figure on this is hard, but with help from experts at the Institute for Fiscal Studies (IFS), we had a look at the sort of earnings you might need in order to pay back in full.

People’s student loans vary massively depending on where in the country they are from, how many years of study they complete, and the amount they borrow to cover their living costs. Broadly, the average debt is around £46,000 on graduation.

This is made up of £27,750 in tuition fees and just over £18,000 in maintenance loan money – £6,000 for each year. Each year, interest is added to the loan. For students from England starting university this year, this interest is in line with inflation (the government uses the Retail Prices Index measure.)
For those who started university between 2012 and 2022, the interest can be higher than this, depending on exactly how much you earn.

Kate Ogden, a research economist at the Institute for Fiscal Studies, says that working out how much you have to earn to pay back a student loan is not straightforward. Putting a figure on the amount you have to repay is fairly simple – as long as the government does not alter the interest charged in future.
For those starting university this year, you’ll pay back in real terms exactly what you borrowed, though the amount will be higher once you account for inflation over the next 40 years.

Beyond this, exact earnings are difficult to calculate, because people do not tend to earn the same amount throughout their career, and the government has the opportunity to change the thresholds at which graduates start repaying at some point in the next four decades.

Assuming the government does not do this, then someone who borrows the average amount, and starts earning £28,000 a year at the start of their career and sees their earnings grow by inflation plus an additional 1.7 per cent every 12 months, would earn around £1.5 million throughout their career, and pay off their loan just before the 40 years are done.

But there are different scenarios that could also result in them paying their loan off too. For example, if you earned £26,000 a year upon graduation and saw your earnings rise by 2 per cent above inflation every year you would pay off the loan in full, as you would if you earned £39,000 and saw your earnings rise only in line with inflation.
Of course, as Ms Ogden explains, this may not be a “realistic” scenario – but it’s impossible to account for all the things that may happen in someone’s 40-year career.
“We might expect faster earnings growth early in someone’s career, and slower growth later on, and some time out of the labour market,” she explains.

And what about someone who started university before this year? As explained above, they have different terms – starting repaying their loan at a higher salary and seeing larger amounts of interest applied. In this case, someone with a starting salary of £44,000 with earnings growth of inflation plus 2 per cent every year throughout the 30 years of their loan would pay back in full, as would someone with a starting salary of £57,000 and growth only in line with inflation.
If they started with a salary of £28,000, then they would be very unlikely to come close to paying off their loan – unless they had huge earnings growth later in their career.

title: Money Clinic: ‘I’m 63 and about to start taking my pension. Should I worry about rising gilt yields?’
lead: A reader asks if rising gilt yields and uncertainty in the stock markets will affect their pension
author: Tom Selby

body.text: I’m 63 and looking to start drawing down from my pension soon. I have read about rising gilt yields and uncertainty in the stock market in the news and I am wondering if this is likely to have any impact on my pension, and whether it should mean any change to my investments? Should I be concerned?

Let’s tackle the main bit of jargon in your question first – “gilt yields”. A “gilt” is essentially an IOU from the UK government. Investors in gilts, often large institutions or big pension funds, will pay a price for the gilt on the promise of receiving a certain interest rate (or “coupon”) each year until the end of the agreed period of time (“maturity”).

The “yield” on a gilt is simply the coupon paid by the gilt divided by the price, expressed as a percentage. For example, if a gilt is priced at £100 and the coupon is £5, the yield is 5 per cent. That means when gilt prices go down, as we have seen in the past 12-18 months, gilt yields go up.

If you are in a defined contribution (DC) pension, whether or not this drop in gilt prices will impact you will depend on the extent your fund is invested in gilts and how far away from retirement you are.

Most people with a DC pension will be invested in a broad range of globally diversified assets. As such, the impact of short-term movements in gilt prices should be negligible. Equally, in most cases a short-term dip in investment performance shouldn’t be a big concern because investing is a long-term game.

Provided you are comfortable with the risks you are taking and focused on those long-term goals, you should be able to ride out any short-term bumps in the road. There is also the danger that if you sell your investments when they go south, you will effectively be crystallising that loss.

Those most impacted by a general drop in gilt prices will be people approaching retirement who have a large proportion of their fund invested in those gilts. That will primarily be people in “annuity hedging” or “lifestyling” investment strategies, which are based around the assumption you are going to buy an annuity (a guaranteed income for life sold by an insurance company).

If you are in one of these funds and still plan to buy an annuity, the drop in gilt prices shouldn’t be a problem because your investments are set up as a hedge against annuity rate changes. This is because, in simple terms, when gilt prices go down, annuity rates tend to go up. This should, in theory, mean the guaranteed income your fund will deliver remains fairly static as you approach your chosen retirement date.

However, the issue comes where someone is invested in one of these funds but no longer plans to buy an annuity. In these circumstances, you might have seen your fund value drop by 30 per cent or more, but with no corresponding rise in the income your fund could produce.
This is a clear example of why it’s so important to engage with your pensions, particularly as you approach the point where you plan to take an income from your fund.
For those in this specific position, the most obvious options are:

Conversely, if you are risk-averse or planning to access your fund soon, investing in gilts or other cash-like instruments taking advantage of the high returns on offer might be attractive. Five of the 10 most popular investments made by AJ Bell’s DIY investors in September were government gilts.

Gilt yields also have an impact on defined benefit (DB) schemes, but again this is not something that should overly concern members. Broadly speaking, when gilt yields go up, DB liabilities (the estimate of how much it will cost the scheme to pay pensions to all its members) go down – and vice versa.

This means that, in terms of a scheme’s funding position, higher gilt yields should be good news (and lower gilt yields bad news). However, in the wake of last year’s mini-Budget, the dramatic spike in gilt yields resulted in a huge cash call from complex hedging instruments (Liability Driven Investments or “LDIs”) held by many DB schemes.

Although this led to lots of “pensions crisis” headlines, in reality there was no direct impact on most people’s pensions. Provided the employer standing behind your DB scheme remained solvent, you should still receive the pension you were promised. And even where an employer sponsoring a DB scheme goes bust, the Pension Protection Fund (PPF) provides a valuable compensation lifeboat, paying out at least 90 per cent of your promised pension (although you may lose some inflation protection).

title: Cheap ways to heat your home, according to experts
lead: With temperatures dropping this week, many are likely to turn on their heating for the first time in months
author: Callum Mason

body.text: Temperatures across the UK plummeted this weekend, despite highs of more than 20C a little over a week ago.
And with some parts of the country seeing the mercury drop to minus figures overnight, many households will have faced putting the heating on for the first time this Autumn.

Though energy bills have fallen slightly since the price cap fell at the start of the month, prices are still higher than before the Covid pandemic, and many will be concerned about racking up high costs.
So what the best approach is to keeping bills down: put their heating on in short bursts, or keep the radiators on a low temperature all day?
spoke to three experts to determine what the best approach is.

: “If you have gas central heating, it’s generally advisable and most cost-effective to turn your boiler on and off when you need it. It’s cheaper to reheat your home then it is to keep it on low all day when you’re not there.
“If you have thermostatic radiator valves, turn these higher in the room you want to heat and low or off in the rooms you’re not using.
“An exception is if you have a heat pump – these are more efficient if you leave them running for longer at a lower output.”

“Leaving your heating on for longer, even at a lower temperature, is likely to end up using more fuel and costing you more than turning it on and off. This is because some heat loss will always occur due to the difference between the temperature outside your home and the temperature you are trying to maintain on the inside.
“So, if you have your heating on all the time, your system will be using energy on an ongoing basis to manage any heat loss in order to maintain the inside temperature.

“The most efficient way of using your heating system is to set your thermostat for the temperature you want your home to be. The World Health Organisation suggests 18C is a reasonable temperature for people in good health.”

“For many people, it doesn’t make sense to leave your heating on all day. However, if you have excellent insulation then the wastage will be reduced and then it might start to make financial sense. This might also be the case if you have a heat pump where the advice is to keep your home at a constant temperature.
“Because every property is different, you can always try different approaches to see how much you spend on energy – if you have a smart meter this is relatively easy to keep an eye on.”
The exact cost of running your hearing for an hour varies hugely depending on the size of your house and the power of your boiler – but you can always do things to reduce your costs.

One thing you can try, according to energy supplier Octopus Energy, is setting your boiler’s ‘flow temperature’ – the heat of the water when it comes out of your boiler – to between 55 and 60 degrees. The firm says “your home will feel just as warm, but you could see real savings on your typical gas use.”
“It’ll take a little longer to heat up, but the gas and CO2 savings make it more than worthwhile,” it adds.
Another method to save on costs is strategic placing of furniture. Try and move sofas from blocking radiators or adjust curtains that hang over them.
If you’re really struggling with bills, another way to maximise efficiency can be by focusing on heating yourself rather than your home.
As well as turning off radiators in rooms that you aren’t using, it can include using gadgets, to increase your warmth.
A guide from Martin Lewis’s MoneySavingExpert.com suggests using USB gloves, USB hand-warmers and electric gillets as possible cheap heaters.

It explains: “We have tried to work out which is cheapest to run. Generally we found it was those which could be charged via USB, but these items tend to be smaller, and may only warm part of your body (such as hands or feet).”

title: Money Moral Maze: Our lottery syndicate won £3k. Should our friend who always forgets to pay in get his share?
lead: A group of friends have won thousands of pounds on the lottery – but should the winnings be split evenly?
author: Callum Mason

body.text: My friends and I have a lottery syndicate. Every month, the other five send me £10, and I add my own £10 to this.

I then use the £60 and buy a series of lottery tickets and scratch cards for the month. It’s a bit of fun, but of course, usually we never get anything out of it – so much so that they’ve started to question whether I’m using the money to enter (which of course I am!)
This month though, we did finally win. The full amount was just under £3,000 which between the six of, would be more approaching £500 each.

However, on checking my bank account, I haven’t received payments for the last five months from one of the group. I’ve still been entering with £60 on the assumption that everyone was chipping in, but in effect, I’ve been subbing his £10 each month with my own money.
This isn’t entirely isolated. He’s terrible at paying people back, whether it be for drinks, booked holidays, or anything else, even after you chase him.
So should he receive his share of the money, or should we split it between the five of us?
This is tricky dilemma, slightly sweetened by the fact that it is over something positive – winning money – rather than something negative.

Thinking logically, then really, your friend’s money has not actually paid for the ticket that resulted in you winning the money £3,000. Purely on that basis, it immediately seems to me like they shouldn’t receive their split.

There are a couple of extra factors that push me towards this as well. Firstly, you say this has happened for several months, and isn’t unusual. If they had forgotten to pay their share once or twice, or were late with it, this would be a different matter. But the truth is, if you hadn’t won the cash, would you have noticed that they hadn’t paid? Would they have owned up of their own accord? From what we’ve heard, it sounds like the answer is no.

The amount you have won is a large amount, but it isn’t life-changing. Cutting your friend out from receiving their share would be very harsh if you’d won a million pounds or a similarly high figure, where the original £50 or so that they had missed out on paying was small fry in the context of the prize. But in this instance, it’s a fairly large chunk of the pay out.

I’m inclined to say they at least don’t get an even split. Could you perhaps reduce the portion they receive of the winnings? Maybe this is the kick they need to start paying people back in the future.
Lottery syndicates are meant to be fun way to connect with workmates or friends – along with the chance of winning some serious cash.
However, it seems in this case you’re considering not extending that community spirit to those who don’t follow the rules to the letter.

I can understand why it might be a little frustrating to chase someone for money but we all have our quirks and it sounds like your friend’s might just be forgetfulness and perhaps a lack of organisation.
This may be irritating but as a supposed mate, I think it can be forgiven, especially when it comes to this situation.
Imagine you had forgotten to pay a couple of times and then a “friend” refused to hand over the cash after winning the syndicate? Not much of a friend, I would say.
You’ve said this is a “bit of fun” so if that really is the case I would dock the £50 off the £500 and give him the £450. It’s only fair and worth it for the sake of maintaining a friendship.

Going forwards, your mate is more likely to transfer the funds in a timely manner, and you can keep the peace for the group. Withholding the funds will only cause trouble and you have to ask yourself is it worth making things awkward for the sake of a few forgotten payments? Probably not.

title: Interest rates to stay high, but predictably so: welcome to the new normal for our finances
lead: Andrew Bailey votes to pause on rate rises, but leaves wiggle room to increase in the future
author: Jessie Hewitson

body.text: On Thursday we saw something happen last seen in November 2021: the Bank of England opted not to increase the base rate.

The effect in the press room at the Bank of England, where journalists got early sight of the decision, was immediate. There was a ripple of excitement and intakes of breath. Nothing was happening, but this was the best and most exciting nothing we’ve seen for close to two years.

Andrew Bailey and his colleagues at the Bank left lots of wiggle room to increase rates in the future if necessary – the Governor of the Bank of England repeatedly stated he was not being “complacent” to reassure the markets.
But he will be aware the message he’s sending: that the fastest period of increases to interest rates in modern times is likely to be coming to an end.
This is good news. It means we are moving from a period of uncertainty and financial shocks to a future where rates are likely to be more stable.
But let’s not get out the bunting just yet: mortgage rates won’t go down dramatically, they will just remain predictably high.

The markets are now predicting the base rate to average just above 5 per cent for the next three years, and the GDP data for the second and third quarter of this years show us uncomfortably close to a technical recession, another reason the Bank may not want to have pushed things too far on Thursday.

It will be some time before we get to the next stage of recovery, when the base rate will fall. Inflation is not expected to return to 2 per cent next year, and rates aren’t likely going to go down significantly before the middle of 2024.

So what are the key messages from today? That people with variable mortgages can breathe a small sight of relief that their repayments won’t go up too much higher in the near future and those on fixed rates can assume a rate of 5 per cent (ish) for the next three years or so.
