title: Quitting This Morning will save Holly Willoughby’s career – daytime TV is toxic and dying
lead: There’s no way This Morning will last as long as Holly Willoughby’s career could
author: Emily Baker

body.text: After 14 years of testing out beauty products, interviewing celebrities and meeting people who have married ghosts, Holly Willoughby has quit This MorningIt was inevitable, really, wasn’t it? Ever since her co-pilot Phillip Schofield left the series in May following the reveal of his affair with a younger colleague, the scrutiny has been piling on not just the show, but Willoughby too.

The intense focus on the behind-the-scenes machinations at ITV has blown things out of all proportion and I can’t blame her for wanting to cut ties. Last night, when Willoughby announced her departure, Sky News presenter Mark Austin interrupted his live, on-the-ground coverage from Jerusalem to announce the “breaking news”.
But if she plays her cards right, leaving could be the very thing that revitalises Willoughby’s career.

There’s no doubt that ever since the Schofield debacle spilled into public consciousness, Willoughby has become a bit of a laughing stock. Remember how we all giggled when she asked viewers at home, honestly and earnestly, if we were “OK” following the scandal? The “tributes” to her on today’s edition of  haven’t helped – Vanessa Feltz called her a “golden hearted real life Disney princess” and broke down in tears. Please. This doesn’t honour her contributions as a broadcaster, it makes her the butt of the joke again.

The show itself, too, was beginning to damage Willoughby’s reputation. had long been growing toxic, and reached its nadir in September last year, when she and Schofield jovially spun that now-infamous sparkly wheel hoping to win a year’s worth of paid energy bills amid a crippling cost-of-living crisis. Then the nation turned against the previously beloved presenters when they were seen to be skipping the queue to walk past the Queen’s coffin. While the event was excused by ITV bosses as “work” – Willoughby and Schofield were filming a segment – many have never forgiven them and sensed an air of snobbery from the hosts ever since.

You can see the perniciousness of infecting others’ careers, too. When Rishi Sunak appeared on the show post-Tory conference last week, Alison Hammond – heralded as an ally by much of the LGBTQ+ community – was slammed on social media for not challenging him on his comments about trans people. It might look like a cheery chat with the PM on the surface, but the segment did irreparable damage to the persona Hammond has spent years building.

Free from the politicised shackles of Willoughby, in time, could become one of our best entertainers. Her regular appearances on Keith Lemon’s blue (and painfully outdated) panel show (where she earned her nickname Holly Willough-booby, which gives you just an inkling of the tone of the series for those lucky enough to have never seen it) and her children’s TVdays – really lived up to its name – are evidence enough that Willoughby has so much more to her than the squeaky clean “Disney princess” she has evolved into since joining in 2009.

There’s a cheeky, rebellious side to the presenter that doesn’t exactly gel with the shiny, happy floral midi-dress-clad woman she must be at 10am on a Wednesday. I wish she’d let us see that Willoughby more; I don’t see why she couldn’t be a one-woman Ant and Dec.
Her decision might have been spurred on by scandal, but Willoughby is right to leave the sinking ship of behind, whatever the reason. There’s no way the series will last as long as her career could.

title: Interview with the Vampire, BBC Two, review: Bored of vampires on TV? This drama will change your mind
lead: Anne Rice’s bestselling novel makes for a toothsome drama even 47 years on
author: Neil Armstrong

body.text: Dubai has more hours of sunlight than any other city in Asia, so you have to question its suitability as a refuge for a vampire. Nevertheless, that’s where Louis de Point du Lac (Jacob Anderson), a former citizen of New Orleans who has been undead since 1910, has chosen to settle.

It’s also where, in the first episode of the BBC’s new American acquisition , veteran Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist Daniel Molloy (Eric Bogosian) journeys to meet him after receiving a summons in the post, despite the fact that their first interview, 49 years ago, did not end well.

It can feel as though there’s always at least one vampire show on television. Drama-wise we’ve had  and . The brilliant comedy  is about to enjoy a sixth season. But which aired on AMC in the US last year to great acclaim, has enough bite to stand out from the coven.
The gorgeous-looking drama is adapted from Anne Rice’s 1976 bestseller of the same name, which was made into a hit 1994 film starring Brad Pitt, Tom Cruise and Kirsten Dunst.

This TV version is set in a later time period, with Louis living in a luxury penthouse apartment with Francis Bacons on the wall. Prints? Probably, but not necessarily. He certainly seems to have accumulated a few quid in his century and a half on the planet. Now he wants to have second go at getting his life story down. “Truth and reconciliation,” he terms it.

Molloy starts recording and the vampire takes us back to early 20th century New Orleans when he was 33 years old and running a chain of “sporting houses” (aka brothels). Then he meets Lestat de Lioncourt (Sam Reid), a sophisticated and powerful French vampire who becomes obsessed with him.

The first three episodes of seven are hugely entertaining, covering Louis’s creation as a vampire as he becomes reluctantly accustomed to a very different way of being and settling into a tetchy love-hate relationship with Lestat. Troubled by his new bloodlust, Louis tries to cling to the vestiges of his humanity in vain. Meanwhile, haughty, volatile, old-school vampire Lestat has no time for Louis’s fad diets of small mammals.
But it is only with the arrival of Claudia (Bailey Bass), the child Louis and Lestat turn into a vampire in episode four that we realise the show has, up to that point, been holding back.
Disobedient and prone to histrionics, she’s an exasperating teenager – here older and therefore more wilful than in the film – who drives “Daddy Lou and Uncle Les” to distraction.

While the parents of human teenage girls might fret about their schoolwork or what they’re getting up to at parties, Louis and Lestat have to worry about whether the always-hungry Claudia is attracting unwanted attention by killing policemen or whether she’s properly disposing of the bodies of her numerous victims. Spoiler alert: she’s not.
Bass, Reid and Anderson are all terrific and play off each other brilliantly. It’s easy to believe in their relationship, no matter how weird.

Among the drama – regular family stuff and, you know, more murdery issues that come along with vampiric bloodlust – there are hilarious moments. “I’m not sure how I feel about that pleated skirt,” says the fashion-conscious Lestat, of Claudia’s outfit as she prepares for her first kill. “It’s chiffon. It has movement,” protests the no-less-stylish Louis. And Claudia is childishly delighted when she gets her own coffin, pink and lined with soft, pink satin.
But never strays too far from its horror roots. There’s an almost cartoonishly gory scene towards the end of the first episode and several more throughout the series.

It gradually becomes apparent that it’s going to be impossible for all three to live together and that Claudia and Louis need to be free of the domineering Lestat. The show does well to make us root for, essentially, a couple of inhuman amoral murderers.

The part of the story set in the present, in which Daniel Molloy is interviewing Louis, is also expertly handled. There’s a particularly disturbing scene as the pair dine together and it turns out Louis’s dinner isn’t dead.

Already a hit in the US thanks to its performances, compelling plot and handsome production design, a second series, which sees our anti-heroes in Paris, is expected to be released next year.  is a toothsome, moreish drama that proves there’s life in the undead yet.

title: Liam Gallagher tour 2024: Full list of UK dates and venues for Definitely Maybe shows, and how to get tickets

title: The Streets, The Darker the Shadow the Brighter the Light, review: Mike Skinner’s bravura comeback
lead: Nobody captures the head-wrecking drama of ordinary life like the Brummy rap laureate
author: Ed Power

body.text: Mike Skinner putThe Streets out to pasture in 2011, feeling he’d taken the nattering rapper formula as far as it could go. He’s since had a rethink and, after a number of comeback singles and a mixtape, now returns with the project’s sixth official album.

Witty, murky, twisting and turning, the record is a typically bravura salvo from pop’s resident everyman poet. It is also a reminder that nobody captures the head-wrecking drama of everyday life quite like Skinner chasing the rush of a killer couplet.

is more than just another Streets LP, however. It doubles as a soundtrack to a movie of the same name that Skinner – the star, director, producer, writer and financier – has spent the past decade attempting to bring to the screen.

The film is a heist flick that by all accounts lands like an arthouse Guy Ritchie. A similar sensibility ripples through its accompanying score, which blends bass-heavy and often ominous soundscapes with Skinner’s chatty rhyming.

Skinner’s stream-of-consciousness style has remained unchanged since The Streets’ 2002 debut, . On brisk opener“Too Much Yayo”, he still sounds as if he’s just tumbled out of bed, pursued by a dimly recalled bad memory from the previous night.

He shines, as ever, with his verbal agility and ability to make the personal universal. “My thoughts feel like cobwebs in a room no one’s been in,” he declares against a skittering dancehall groove on “Something to Hide”.

Skinner’s always been good at evoking the graininess of everyday life. It is in those snapshots that… excels. “She had the look of a fox that isn’t walking away/ when you catch them on your street and it’s almost day,” he declares on “Walk of Shame”, his voice bathed in a dusky acoustic loop.

Pop stars don’t always make the best filmmakers. Just ask Sia, whose reputation never recovered from her widely panned directorial debut Music. We’ll have to wait and see if Skinner’s cinematic odyssey was worth the effort.

But whatever about the accompanying movie, the new Streets album  – elevated by soulful vocals from Skinner’s long-time collaborator Kevin Mark Trail – is a confident and rewarding return. Two decades on, the buccaneering bard behind still has something to say.

title: The Wolves of Eternity by Karl Ove Knausgaard, review: 500 pages too long
lead: Norway’s biggest writer doesn’t write his books – he bleeds all over them
author: Nick Duerden

body.text: Karl Ove Knausgaard, Norway’s biggest writer, set out his stall early on in his career. In the first section of his breakout third book (2009’s  an autobiography that read like a novel), he recounted the Saturday night preparations of his teenage self getting ready for a party, and elected not to scrimp on detail but rather to magnify it over dozens of pages. The effect was either hypnotic or galling – literary Marmite. Here was someone who took John Updike’s mantra to “give the mundane its beautiful due”, but to do so in rather quotidian prose.  was merely the first part of his autobiography; five further instalments followed.

In 2021, he turned to fiction – although in the world of Knausgaard, the novel and the memoir is interchangeable – with  a 666-page monster that told the interconnecting tales of a group of people whose lives are thrown off course by the emergence of a bright star in the sky.

Now comes , which – while featuring some of the same characters – doesn’t really pick up from where that book left off, nor obediently follow it. Instead, it meanders around two people. The first is Syvert Løyning, a young Norwegian newly home from military service in 1986 and tending to his ailing mother while mulling over the consequences of the Chernobyl nuclear disaster. When he finds a cache of letters from his late father, written to a secret Russian lover, he discovers that his family line now extends towards the East.

The second section takes place in modern-day Russia, and features Løyning’s half-sister Alevtina Kotov, a single mother who lectures at a local university and is fascinated by the natural world, and how trees communicate. When the siblings meet, they recognise in one another the lingering ghost of the father Syvert continues to miss, and whom Alevtina never got to know. Their bond, instantly created, proves indelible.

For a book that opens with some rather guileless writing about a 1977 album by Status Quo (“I had it on cassette, and played it all the time on the black cassette player I’d got for Christmas the year before. It ran on batteries. Invariably, I sang along. How brilliant to hear [it] again now!”), it eventually, if slowly, grows into matters more existential.

There are a great many ruminations on death, loss and immortality, and the human need to get to grips with each as, between them, the siblings riff on God versus science and religion versus doubt. And if the author himself appears in no hurry to favour any particular side then that’s because, he suggests, life’s like that: an endless barrage of questions for which we spend much of our time seeking answers. He doesn’t so much write his books as bleed all over them, with no one on hand to offer bandages.

would have been far more effective at 500 pages shorter, but that’s not what this writer does. In failing to find happy resolutions to the biggest conundrums we face, the book finishes in open-ended ambiguity rather than satisfying climax. This is deliberate, of course, and indicates that, yes, there’s more micro-analysing discourse to come. Several sequels in this particular series are already in the works.
That sound? It’s Knausgaard, typing. He’s always typing. Some people just have so very much to say.

title: The Iliad, translated by Emily Wilson, review: Such dazzling clarity makes it perfect for modern readers
lead: From the first woman to translate the Odyssey comes this new way into the world of Achilles that brought me to tears all over again
author: Jennifer Saint

body.text: Emily Wilson’s translation of Homer’s , published to great acclaim in 2017, opens with the line “tell me about a complicated man”.

With this, it became immediately apparent that Wilson’s take on the Homeric epic was going to be revelatory: sparkling, fresh and deliciously nuanced. Wilson, a professor of classical studies at the University of Pennsylvania, was the first woman to translate the  into English, and now six years later she is the second to do the same for the It’s bound to open up the world of ancient epic with the same dazzling clarity as she did before, breathing vigorous life into the poem and inviting us as modern readers to feel the weight and grandeur of its tragedy.

Predictably, the fact of a woman translating Homer so very successfully has troubled the occasional commentator who frets that some mighty quality of masculinity in the epic will be somehow compromised. But that’s a reductive view not just of the skill of translation but also of the epic itself.

The  explores the hyper-masculine world of heroes with immense depth and richness, and Wilson conveys it all with unflinching vividness. The epic poem tells us the story of a man possessed of “cataclysmic wrath”. It is Achilles, perhaps the most famous hero of Greek mythology, legendary for the godlike immensity of his rage and nihilistic capacity for violence – but also for his deep love of his comrade Patroclus, his desperate grief and the inevitability of his fate.

The begins with Achilles, in the ninth year of the Trojan War, quarrelling with Agamemnon over the enslaved woman, Briseis, that Achilles has taken captive. When Agamemnon loses his own “trophy” – the word Wilson so aptly uses to describe the women who are abducted and enslaved as spoils of war – he takes Briseis from Achilles. Outraged, Achilles not only retreats from the war to his tent, but also entreats his goddess mother to turn the tide of war against his fellow Greeks.

In parallel, we have the story of the Trojan hero, Hector, leaving his loving wife and baby behind so that he can take advantage of the Greeks’ disarray in a series of bloody and terrible battles. All the while, the Olympian gods oversee and orchestrate the death and devastation with callous disregard.

In Wilson’s hands, the poem sings with the clash of bronze, the thundering of hooves, the savage holler of war-cries. Her use of iambic pentameter imbues it with irresistible pace and rhythm. It flows like music – exhilarating, tragic, beautiful and stirring – just as it should, because this was a poem that was heard, not read, when it was first composed around 700BCE.

Her use of language and imagery makes it a visual experience too; one of glittering metal and flame, full of searing light so that we feel entirely transported to an alien, ancient and terrifying world.

But she anchors us in the emotional reality of the epic. There are moments of humour as well as quiet peace and reflection amidst the chaos and violence and when we read this poem we are united across the millennia that separate us from its composition by the shared agony of grief.

Running throughout is a humane, expressive connection of a truth we all know – the shattering inevitability of loss. Rediscovering it through Wilson’s eyes brought me to tears all over again. Her translation is so thoroughly readable that whether you already love the  or are coming to it for the first time, you will be swept away in a story that has endured through the ages.

title: West End standing ovations are out of control. Please sit down
lead: A few years ago, an audience getting to its feet was a once-in-a-generation achievement. Now audience members seem to think it’s their duty
author: Fiona Mountford

body.text: Forget about French bedbugs for a moment, as there is a fresh international outbreak in town. This one is called Ovation-itis, and imported from the US, it is now running riot through our theatres.

A worrying new strain was spotted last week at the Savoy Theatre on the opening night of the revival of Andrew Lloyd Webber’s musical, starring former Pussycat Doll Nicole Scherzinger. Not only did the audience leap to their feet at the end of the show, as is now wearingly common, but up they got at the end of each of Scherzinger’s songs. At one point I, resolutely sitting down, feared that the show would still be going on come breakfast the next day.

Just a handful of years ago, a standing ovation in British theatre marked an Olympian feat, a once-in-a-generation achievement. Audiences awarded them so infrequently that when they did happen, they truly meant something. I can still recall with pinpoint clarity the very first preview performance of Alan Bennett’s play  which would subsequently go on to award-winning international acclaim.

There had been little fuss and even less publicity around the piece, and when the lights dimmed at the end of that first show in the National Theatre’s Lyttelton auditorium, there was a powerful silence in which a thousand audience members appeared to be holding their breath and processing the magnificence of what they had just seen.

Gradually an inexorable momentum, all but unheard of in 2004, swept down the stalls row by row until every single person was on their feet. That was a standing ovation that collectively acknowledged our presence at the start of something wonderful.

Compare and contrast that precious rarity with today’s situation, where standing ovations happen as a matter of course at the end of countless shows, especially in the West End. Audience members seem to think that it is their duty, even if they haven’t been all that taken by the production when they were watching it. No matter how little buzz of engagement and enjoyment there is, everyone gets up come the curtain call.

This causes me to wonder who it is that spectators are really applauding. I am by no means convinced that it’s always the performers. I suspect that they might well be validating themselves and their choice to spend hard-earned cash (not to mention travel, food and babysitting money) on this specific piece of entertainment. If we stand up and clap ferociously, the thinking seems to go, it must have been worth it.

Like many dubious cultural trends, this one has travelled from across the Atlantic, where large-scale communal emoting has long been the norm. It is not only standing ovations that Broadway loves, though; there is also a peculiar custom of applauding a big-name actor when they make their first entrance onstage. I dislike this habit for many reasons, not least for the way it tears through the magic of an audience’s precious collective suspension of disbelief. The story rather than the star should be our focus and performances should be acknowledged, preferably with lively clapping, at the show’s end.

To stand or not to stand is a question that has been the subject of lively debate among theatre critics recently. It is admittedly rather unsettling to be the sole person still sitting while everyone else is on their feet, but I hold out against it unless I feel it has been honestly earned; the gesture otherwise seems empty and cheapens those times, as with, when I stood in pure admiration.

Surely the performers, proud professionals that they are, feel this too? As in all spheres of life, praise handed out to everyone all the time has no worth and serves no purpose, but merely colludes in an atmosphere of collective deception.

Maybe the concept of delayed gratification, of saving ourselves for something special, is hopelessly old-fashioned in our on-demand world. We want it all and we want it now and decreasingly few have the patience to wait for elusive artistic perfection. Call me a stickler, but I plan to sit down for a while longer.

title: After 100 years, Disney’s music is now more important than the films
lead: From Snow White to Encanto, the soundtracks to Disney’s cartoons have included some of the most memorable songs of the past century. What makes them endure?
author: Emily Bootle

body.text: If you’ve ever been subjected to the “It’s a Small World” ride at Disneyland – which, of course, involves having the song stuck in your head for the succeeding four years – you may not have been in the mood to pause for reflection. Round and round it goes, the melody going up and up and up until eventually it comes back down again. Then the cycle restarts. Although this is a particularly irritating example, if you have ever had small children, or indeed, been a child yourself, there is a whole legion of songs about which you might feel similarly, from “Let It Go” to “Under the Sea”. The former alone has surely made casualties out of thousands of Amazon Echoes across the country.

The enduring love of Disney among children and certain factions of adults is as much about the music as the films. Disney Brothers Cartoon Studios was founded on this day in 1923; just as the characters and visuals have defined and pioneered animation styles for 100 years, creating a huge catalogue of iconic movies, so too have the soundtracks to these films created a rich genre. Over the past century the franchise has created not only some of the most famous films of the century, but some of the most memorable tunes.

Even the inclusion of “It’s a Small World”, “Let It Go” and “Under the Sea” in the same paragraph can show the sporadic breadth of the Disney canon. Written by a host of composers including Hans Zimmer, Alan Menken, Elton John and Lin-Manuel Miranda, Disney’s illustrious back catalogue of musical cartoon soundtracks has topped charts, filled stages, and swelled hearts for decades on end, and endures in the same way as classic pop songs. So what is it that makes this music work?

It was six years after Walt Disney founded the studio with his brother, Roy, that the company started producing their “Silly Symphonies”. After making short cartoon reels under the , 27 further mini-movies about Oswald the Lucky Rabbit, and in 1928, inventing Mickey Mouse, Walt saw a film with sound – and decided he wanted to branch out. The Silly Symphonies were constructed around music – short cartoons set to pieces of music that constituted a fully formed five minutes of entertainment.

But Disney wasn’t satisfied. Although the Silly Symphonies had sound and melody, it still felt separate from the cartoon. “Really, we should set a new pattern, a new way to use music,” he said, “weave it into the story so somebody doesn’t just burst into song.” Thus, with Disney’s first feature-length film which was also the first-ever feature-length animation – there also camethe first-ever movie soundtrack, featuring songs like “Someday My Prince Will Come” and “Heigh Ho”. From then on, Disney didn’t just make films – it made musicals.

Being written in 1938, the soundtrack to is virtually unrecognisable from the Disney soundtracks of today. It has warbling choirs, fuzzy strings and a sense of emotional restraint, all of which is emphasised by the inferior recording quality. But it laid the foundation for a quintessential Disney style – one that transfixes listeners with compelling narrative lyrics and melodic earworms. Disney songs are now in the canon of all-time classics, soundtracking car journeys, summer holidays, Instagram reels, weddings and funerals.

was a huge hit – at the box office, it quickly became the most successful non-silent film of all time. It was followed by the likes of (1940) – whose most famous song “When You Wish Upon a Star” not only won an Oscar but became a jazz standard – and (1942), which used a colourful orchestral soundtrack to bring life to the evocative images of the forest. Then came (1950), where songs like “Bibbidi-Bobbidi-Boo” enlivened our understanding of specific characters, and – following a few years of less musically significant films – (1967), which counted “I Wanna Be Like You” and “The Bare Necessities” among its hits.

But many of the best-known Disney songs come from the second wave of classic cartoons, towards the end of the 20 century – such as (1989), (1997),  (1994) and  (1991). It is difficult to overstate the importance of the soundtracks for these films. While previously the songs had been colourful additions to the main dialogue, in these, the music the movie: take the opening sequence of , for instance, in which a cast of Greek muses comes alive from a decorated pot and sing Alan Menken’s seductive, groovy “Gospel Truth” to introduce the story (creating a slight cultural dissonance, admittedly, between Ancient Greece and 1960s soul); or in , the gently lilting titular song by Menken that was, in the movie, sung by Angela Lansbury as an anthropomorphic teapot and later released as a single featuring Céline Dion. These are not simply ditties that spice up the action like “Heigh Ho” – they are part of the complete package.

This was the natural conclusion of Walt’s original plan to “weave [the music] into the story”. The songs in Disney movies are almost always used as exposition – a way of explaining plot, backstory or characters in a way that’s easily tangible by children. Using music, you don’t necessarily have to absorb and comprehend all the words of explanation – you just get the idea for who a character is, or what’s going on.

A classic example is ’s “Hakuna Matata” – a feelgood track of which the purpose is to introduce exiled Simba’s new friends, Timone and Pumba. Through its chilled, catchy beat and repetitive refrain (which, being in Swahili, also features the explanation “it means no worries for the rest of your days”), we get a feel for what Timone and Pumba are about, and instantly like them. Earlier in the movie, the song “I Just Can’t Wait to Be King” does a lot of heavy lifting: at a glance, it is simply a fun, bouncy number with kaleidoscopic animal visuals and a Jackson 5-style vocal from Jason Weaver as Simba; in reality, the characters are carried away by it as much as the audience, with Simba and Nala ending up in the elephant graveyard that sets up a key element of peril.

For young viewers, emotional exposition is as significant as the narrative. Disney songs can be cheesy and sentimental – but they are providing a turbo-boost of feeling in key moments of each film. Randy Newman’s classic “You’ve Got a Friend in Me” (1995) is catchy and jaunty but also has a slight vulnerability – conveying the risky hopefulness we need to feel in order to invest in Woody and Buzz’s friendship. In  (2017), “How Far I’ll Go” is adventurous and empowering, setting up the idea of a quest and imbuing the listener with youthful ambition. Just like the cartoons exaggerate human expression in the most emotive, relatable way, so the music, with its catchy refrains and satisfying harmonies, reflects back at us a distilled version of the emotion we’re supposed to be feeling.

In this way, Disney music has significant overlap with traditional pop and musical theatre songwriting, and has evolved in tandem with these genres over the course of the century. The early Disney style – in films like ,,and  – often featured a distinctive mid-century choir; the mid-style relied on jaunty tunes like “You’ve Got a Friend in Me” and “I Just Can’t Wait to Be King” alongside pretty, mournful heroines’ ballads (see: “Part of Your World”, “Colours of the Wind”). More recently, Gen-Alpha favourites like , and have employed the same big choruses and slick production that dominate the last two decades of bubblegum pop.
But listening to 100 years of Disney music, there are some idiosyncrasies that single it out, too – and they extend across the styles of different eras and composers.

The first is the use of creative harmony and modulation. While ’s “Let It Go” – which sold 11 million copies on its release in 2013 – has the soaring chorus and empowering message of a traditional power ballad, its tonality is highly unconventional, using modulation through the verses and choruses, combined with some unusual cadences, to manipulate the mood even more than usual. Similarly, 75 years previously, in ’s “When You Wish Upon a Star”, the use of a crunchy diminished chord (on the “wish”) pulls the listener and creates tension in what would otherwise be a conventional lullaby.

The second is the crucial role of the characters and chorus – such as the actual Greek chorus in – in the delivery. This is most obvious in Disney’s villain songs, which are often most dramatic on any given soundtrack (’s “Poor Unfortunate Souls”, sung by the sea witch Ursula, a giant octopus with a heavy cleavage and dreams of omnipotence, trumps “Part of Your World” every time). The tune can become a leitmotif for the character who sings it, making them even more memorable and distinctive.

And within all these frameworks, Disney has the capacity to be highly flexible with genre – a trait that has bolstered recent movies that have attempted to branch out beyond the white fairytale princess with an 18-inch waist.

2021’s , which is set in Colombia, is infused with Latin rhythm and – a Disney first – Spanish lyrics, while the lesser-known  (2009), which featured the first black Disney princess, has a go at New Orleans swing. These films, along with , are more outwardly focused on bringing cultures outside the white Western norm to light – but even in earlier movies, a playfulness with style and genre lent Disney soundtracks their unique atmosphere. uses snippets of Zulu (“Circle of Life”) and Swahili (“Hakuna Matata”) and draws from African harmony, melody and instrumentation; at the other end of the spectrum, Alan Menken wrote a thundering score for (1996) infused with the sounds of both haunting church choirs and eastern European Roma dances.

There’s nothing like a few rounds of “It’s a Small World” to make you feel claustrophobic – that yes, the world really is tiny, please get me out of it. Yet its chronic endurance in your head has nothing on the legacy and impact of Disney music, which is perhaps even more memorable and iconic than the films it features in. And in any case, even the idea of a “small world” is an anomaly. Really, the purpose of these songs is to make enthralled viewers – children and adults alike – think, and feel, a little bigger.

title: Feathers and boobs, but no live snakes: How the Moulin Rouge is fighting to stay relevant
lead: 134 years since the Moulin Rouge first opened, the world’s most famous cabaret is fighting to bounce back from the pandemic and bring in new audiences
author: Emily Baker

body.text: What comes to mind when you think of the Moulin Rouge? Glamourous mademoiselles performing the can-can? Ewan McGregor serenading Nicole Kidman atop an elephant à la 2001 Baz Luhrmann’s movie musical? Boobs? What you probably don’t ­imagine, however, is a troupe of Britons performing under the iron fist of an artistic director from Leeds.

A stalwart of the cabaret for more than 20 years, Janet Pharaoh, a brusque but intensely passionate woman, runs the performance ­aspect of ­Paris’s Moulin Rouge, and she’s deeply respected by those she oversees.

She’s tough, constantly has feedback for her dancers, and something about her makes you want to impress her even if you’re not one of them. Sitting next to her during one of the Moulin Rouge performances, I can almost hear her making mental notes of what the dancers are doing right, and more crucially, wrong. “I can see everything,” she says ominously.
Her meticulousness is warranted. The 80-strong troupe must put on two performances a night for an ­audience of 1,800 paying guests, sometimes not leaving work until three in the morning.

Dedication and a strong work ethic are required to not only pass the auditions for the Moulin Rouge, but to stay there. New dancers are hired on a year-long contract, which will only be renewed if they prove to Pharaoh they’re more than just a good dancer: they’re a Moulin dancer.

The uniforms might be ­sparklier, but the rules of being a ­Moulin Rouge dancer are akin to the ­military. They’re not allowed to get ­tattoos without permission, they’re not allowed to dye their hair, women must be at least 5’ft 9in″ and men must be 6ft ’1″in (a hard find in the dance world, apparently). In their contract it states that a dancer is not allowed to gain or lose more than 2kg (about four 4lbs).
“We have more problems with skinny dancers than with overweight dancers,” says head of PR Fanny Rabasse, conductor of my tour around the famed windmill-topped venue.
The Moulin Rouge, which ­welcomes 600,000 guests every year (each paying at least €113 [£98] for the ticket alone), is a ­serious business.
But as with most live entertainment venues around the world, shuttering for 18 months during the Covid-19 pandemic did a number on the cabaret.

“We were on eggshells when we reopened,” says Rabasse of the decision to restart the show three nights a week in September 2021. It couldn’t have gone better. “We sold out and there was a 15-minute standing ovation on the first night back.”

Still, the Moulin Rouge is on a mission to recoup its losses and get more people through the doors. It’s why BBC cameras have been allowed to film a docuseries, , currently airing on BBC Two on Wednesday nights and following a selection of new dancers joining the troupe. It’s also why I’ve been invited backstage to learn how the most famous cabaret in the world operates in 2023.

The venue stands on ­Boulevard de Clichy in the arty Montmartre district of Paris, its famous red windmill slowly ­spinning above the front doors. The area was once the stomping ground of Monet, van Gogh and Picasso, who would meet in bustling cafés and guinguettes (traditional Parisian taverns).It was home to the city’s first ­modern cabaret, the famous Le Chat Noir, and is the birthplace of the Belle Époque, an era of European history defined by its excessive love of beauty above all else.

While the Moulin Rouge hasn’t moved venues in its lifetime, the surrounding area is almost unrecognisable. Opposite the iconic venue is a Starbucks and if you didn’t shell out for dinner during the show, you’re in walking distance of three McDonald’s outlets.

Step inside, however, and you’re transported back in time to the cabaret’s heyday. Plush red velvet covers almost every surface, and post-impressionist artist Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec’s original posters for the first ever Moulin Rouge cabaret in 1889 hang on the walls (next to the gift shop, of course). Chandeliers hang from the ceilings and waiters in tails serve dishes so French it borders on pastiche: foie gras, veal and plenty of Champagne.

Backstage is a warren of ­brightly lit corridors, worlds away from the intimacy of the theatre. The dancers do their own make-up in crowded (but neat and regimented) dressing rooms, the 800 pairs of shoes and 1,000 different costumes – each costing as much as €18,000 to make – hanging around them.

In workshops on the upper floors, 33 costumières work tirelessly on creating, ­fixing and maintaining the costumes; the Moulin Rouge is home to the last remaining feather-makers in Paris, Maison Février, which also provides feathers for Parisian fashion houses Chanel and ­Balmain’s recent collaboration with ­Beyoncé. It’s hard not to get caught up in the allure and history of the place.

The show itself, however, is a time capsule to a more recent era. The current performance,  (which roughly translates to roughly “fairy play” in English), was first performed in 1999 and little has changed since then – including the topless dancers.

“It makes the costumes look ­beautiful, like statues,” says ­Pharaoh. “I suppose some people find Renoir and all those classical Roman and Greek statues outdated. It’s part of beauty. The same as the legs, arms, hands, face, hair…boobies.” She shrugs. From where I was sat, the boobs were the least offensive part of the show.

The music, originally ­composed by French musician Pierre Porte even earlier in 1986, is all ­cliché ­melodic synths. Some ­elements of the performance are undeniably outdated: the version of  I saw featured live snakes, although two months later the Moulin Rouge announced it would stop using any animals during the show. It all comes off a bit naff, unfortunately. More cruise ship than classic cabaret.

One element that does remain ­impressive, even after 100 years, is the iconic can-can. “It was the beginning of the liberation of women,” says Pharaoh of the creation of the can-can dance in the documentary series.

It’s here that the dancer’s talent is on display as they high kick and cartwheel their way through a breathless performance. It makes you wish that they’d go back to basics and present the traditional Moulin Rouge cabaret as it was in 1889. So why don’t they? Money.
“We put €8m into the show and spent €4m on the costumes,” says Rabasse. “Since then we’ve spent another €6m on maintaining the costumes.”
Creating and learning a new show would mean huge investment, an impossibility following the ­economic financial struggles brought on by the pandemic.

But without reinvention, the Moulin Rouge could struggle to survive. When Baz Luhrmann’s film set at the cabaret was released in 2001, the venue experienced a huge uptick in ticket sales, particularly among a younger crowd.

“People came just so they could have their picture taken,” remembers Rabasse. “They couldn’t believe they were stepping inside the Moulin Rouge.”The musical version of the movie, currently on stage in the West End, is having a similar effect, although to a much smaller degree.

Other Parisian cabarets were forced to close for good during the pandemic, but thanks to its historical importance, worldwide reputation and undying determination from Pharaoh and her team, the Moulin Rouge is clinging on.I hope it will stay remain open for ­another 134 years – but the only way it will stay alive and kicking the can-can is with a revamp.

title: BBC Asian Network radio boss shared ‘Gaza genocide’ posts
lead: BBC Asian Network radio boss Ahmed Hussain shared Frankie Boyle tweet calling Israel’s military actions in Gaza ‘genocide.’ His tweets breached BBC social media ‘due impartiality’ rules
author: Adam Sherwin

body.text: The head of BBC’s Asian Network radio station retweeted posts calling Israel’s retaliation in Gaza over the Hamas attacks “genocide”.

Ahmed Hussain, who runs the BBC’s news and entertainment station for young British Asians, shared a post by comedian Frankie Boyle that read: “A lot of artists and commentators in Britain who’ve spent their careers foregrounding their empathy and humanism, apparently unable to muster a single word about the genocide in Gaza.”
“This matters because Britain is providing political and military cover for these actions. If you have a voice, please use it to call for a ceasefire, and the lifting of the blockade.”
Hussain also shared a post calling comments made by Israeli President Isaac Herzog “pure insanity”. Herzog had implied that all citizens of Gaza were responsible for the attack perpetrated by Hamas.

Hussain, whose Asian Network has 500,000 listeners and 2.4m social media followers, also reposted messages that questioned reports that Hamas killers had beheaded babies. Israel’s government subsequently shared graphic images of dead children following the raids.
In the months before the Hamas attack, Hussain had shared criticisms of actions taken by Israeli police during violent confrontations with Palestinians at the Al-Aqsa Mosque compound in Jerusalem
Hussain’s reposts appeared to breach the BBC’s new social media guidelines, which require “senior leaders” to follow the same strict neutrality rules as news journalists.

Responding to the ’s questions about the posts, a BBC spokesperson said: “Our social media guidance sets out clear expectations for staff, including the particular responsibility for all senior leaders to uphold the BBC’s impartiality.
“Any breaches of the guidance are taken seriously, and we have spoken to Ahmed and reminded him of these responsibilities. The retweets have been removed.”
Hussain was approached for comment.

The lapse is particularly serious for the BBC, which is already investigating claims that journalists working for its Arabic network appeared to support Hamas and endorsed its attacks, on social media.

The social media posts reportedly “liked” by BBC Arabic journalists include a video on X, formerly Twitter, that showed bodies and kidnapped civilians being loaded on to a jeep under the caption “proud moment”. In one case, a BBC senior correspondent reportedly appeared to make fun of the Israeli relatives of a grandmother who was abducted by Hamas.
It is understood that all of the journalists have now been taken off air pending the results of the investigation. All of the tweets have been removed.

BBC Director-General Tim Davie has made “impartiality” across news a central feature of his leadership, telling staff if they want to become political activists they should not be working at the broadcaster.
The Israel-Gaza conflict is the first test of updated social media guidelines introduced after the Gary Lineker row.

They give freelance presenters – like host Boyle – and non-news figures more leeway to express political views while maintaining that journalists and bosses “have a particular responsibility to uphold the BBC’s impartiality.”

However, the BBC has refused to bow to pressure from senior figures across the political spectrum to call Hamas – a proscribed terrorist group – “terrorists” in its news coverage. BBC guidelines say the broadcaster can let contributors use the term but its own news reports must not use “value-judgements” made by others.
The broadcaster has received complaints that its reporting has been biased against both Israel and Palestinians.

In a statement on Monday responding to its critics, the BBC said: “Careful consideration has been given to all aspects of our coverage to ensure that we report on developments accurately and with due impartiality in line with the BBC editorial guidelines, which are publicly available.”
It added: “BBC News has provided our global audiences with coverage and first-hand testimony of the atrocities committed by Hamas and the suffering in Gaza.”

Speaking about its decision not to describe Hamas as a terrorist organisation, it said: “The BBC, along with many other UK and global news organisations, does use the word ‘terrorist’, but attributes it. We have made clear to our audiences that Hamas is proscribed as a terrorist organisation by the UK and other governments.”

title: Richard Curtis’s romcoms might be bad for women – but I’ll never stop watching them
lead: In an interview with his daughter, Scarlett, Richard Curtis said his depictions of women were “stupid and wrong”. That doesn’t mean he should be cancelled
author: Emily Bootle

body.text: About five years ago, it was very fashionable to rat out old bits of culture as being “problematic”. Nothing titillated Twitter – it was still Twitter back then – quite like the (sometimes legitimate) revelation that a much-loved film or TV show was Bad, Actually. From the homophobic jokes in to Danny trying to grope Sandy in , nothing was immune to 140-character excoriation.

Equally, nothing enraged Middle England like the headlines about quite how titillated Twitter was – and that, as a consequence, nobody is allowed to enjoy things. Now, though, we have all grown rather bored of this dance – largely because progressive identity politics is no longer a fringe movement, and most reasonable people are agreed on what is marginally eyebrow-raising (Martin Scorsese’s convenient erasure of normal-looking women), what is genuinely offensive ()and what is probably a passable joke (’ “The Germans”).

Over the weekend, though, this rather vintage conversation was revived at the Cheltenham Literature Festival, in an interview with the film director Richard Curtis, conducted by none other than his own daughter. Curtis is known for making some of the best-loved romcoms of the late 90s and early 00s, including , , and . Over the years, these films have come to be known by some people for their whiteness, poshness and conventional heterosexual romances, alongside their cosy, slightly literary, extremely “British” form of macrocosmic ASMR.

And so Curtis’s daughter Scarlett, 28, gave him a grilling. “In the last few years there has been a growing criticism around the ways your films treated women and people of colour,” she said, following up with specific accusations of “multiple accounts of inappropriate boss behaviour in , including the prime minister”, “a noticeable lack of people of colour in a film called — one of the birthplaces of the British black civil rights movement” and jokes about women being fat. Curtis said he regretted much of the work and that the jokes about women – for instance, that Martine McCutcheon’s depiction of the prime ministerial love interest Natalie had “thighs like tree trunks”, or that Bridget Jones will “always be just a little bit fat” – were “stupid and wrong”.

If you, too, are unsure whether it’s more boring to decry all of Curtis’s work as insensitive bile or to denounce woke society as the death knell of culture, welcome to the safe space: here, we are allowed to whisper that some of the material was a little wince-worthy, and we should discuss the impact that had on people at the time. At the same time, we are all grown up enough to continue to enjoy the films we love with appropriate insight. As a feminist whose favourite film, no question, is , I feel comfortable with articulating this position.

As Curtis said to his daughter, nobody at the time felt that any of these unsavoury references were malicious. This is, of course, part of the problem with them. The women internalising the fact that Renée Zellweger as Bridget Jones was “a little bit fat” as a size 10 didn’t think it was malicious, either – they thought it must mean they were fat, and that that was bad. But it’s also true that these movies were part of a broader landscape: one in which women were under intense pressure to be thin and to get married, and, to speak to broader matters of “diversity”, where having an accent like Hugh Grant’s in was inherently charming. As for the “inappropriate boss behaviour”: I need not point out that sometimes, in films, people are murdered, nor that Grant’s flirting in  is a deliberate object of humour and sexiness, nor that Bridget Jones specifically flirts with her boss, Daniel Cleaver (also played by Grant), by asking: “How dare you sexually harass me in this impertinent manner”.

It is clear, therefore, that much of these so-called indiscretions were satirical, or at least self-aware; reading them kindly, they were observations of the very real standards they were subjected to at the time. When films age they become artefacts, vignettes of the period in which they were made, that can be enjoyed or not according to audience choice. When I watch , or , I am aware that I’m watching something made 20 years ago, that it’s going to be very middle class, that it’s going to have a posh, rogueish male lead, and that its female cast are going to be hung up on love and body image – in the same way that when I read a Jane Austen novel, I know that its characters are going to be a lot more concerned about finding a husband by age 23 and getting a dowry than it would be acceptable to be in 2023.

If all this sounds a little bit “these days, if you say you’re English you get thrown in jail”, let me clarify. I started watching Richard Curtis movies in my early teens, and my friends and I internalised plenty of messages I’d rather we hadn’t – on bodies, female sexuality, expectations for how many times in one’s life one will be kissed passionately in softly falling snow, and, yes, the whiteness of Notting Hill.

But rather than lambast them for their oversights, it would be more productive to ask whether the films we are making now are interesting, relevant, new and representative. Spoiler alert: old ones rarely meet those criteria. But they are still funny, heartwarming and comforting, and give us valuable insight into the times that have now passed, so that we can, if we feel it necessary, go on to be better.

title: What time is Madonna on stage tonight? When London’s O2 gates open and when music will begin
lead: The Queen of Pop has begun the London leg of her Celebration Tour with a six-date stay at the O2 Arena where fans will be whisked through a musical tour of Madonna’s career.
author: Sally Guyoncourt

body.text: The Queen of Pop has begun her reign at the O2 Arena in London as Madonna brings her Celebration Tour to the Capital.

Marking her 40-year career in music, the US singer has much to celebrate not least her survival earlier this year from a serious bacterial infection which hospitalised her and delayed the start of the tour.

Now with her London dates underway, the 65-year-old master of reinvention is taking the audience on a musical and visual journey through her life reviving old costumes and images as well songs from her past.
She has also made it something of a family affair , with five of her six children joining her on stage for performances.
And if previous tours are anything to go by, it could become yet another jewel in the artist’s crown.

According to Ticketmaster, Madonna has, to date, performed about 700 shows across 11 concert tours, generating more than $1billion in ticket sale, and is the highest-grossing female touring artist of all time.
The Celebration Tour is in town at the O2 for six dates, from Saturday 14 October to Sunday 15 October, Tuesday 17 October to Wednesday 18 October and then Tuesday 5 December to Wednesday 6 December.
Here’s what to expect from the Material Girl during her time in London.
With an 11pm curfew at the venue on most nights and a two-hour show to squeeze in, the star is expected to be on stage at around 9pm.
So far, she is reported to have been on stage in her previous London shows between 8.50pm and 9.05pm.
Doors open at the O2 Arena in Peninsula Square, North Greenwich at 6.30pm.

Based on the set list from her first night performing at the O2, it looks as though Madonna will be storming though her back catalogue of hits with the odd cover thrown in such as Gloria Gaynor’s I Will Survive.
But the list may be subject to some change.
